Subject: Market Failure Clarification – Econ 101
Hello [Friend’s name]
I hope all is well for you despite the unexpected circumstances. I understand that market
failure can be a confusing concept, so I’ll do my best to clarify it alongside using a recent news
article as an example. The term market failure described by Dudley “occurs when the market on
its own fails to be efficient with no outside or government intervention” (Dudley). The market
fails to be efficient because it fails to maximize total surplus due to a misallocation of resources.
Market failures that we have learned in class so far are externalities, common resources, public
goods, and artificially scarce goods. I will explore externalities using an example where the
actions of producers or consumers have consequences for third parties not involved in the
market.
There are two types of externalities: negative and positive. A negative externality results
in an external cost due to an individual or firm imposing an uncompensated cost on others
(Dudley). In a market with a negative externality, the market equilibrium results in too many
units of the good compared to the efficient level (Dudley). However, for positive externalities,
the same reasons instead cause an external benefit, and market equilibrium results in fewer units
of the good compared to the efficient level. The efficient level would be the optimal quantity that
maximizes total surplus, but since it is at market equilibrium, the market fails to be efficient,
therefore a market failure occurs.
To clearly illustrate the concept, I will go into an example of a real-world example of a
market failure. In the article, Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns, it discusses
how the issue of microplastic pollution is becoming a bigger issue due to the increase in plastic
waste, as it is affecting various environments and the human body. The article addresses how
microplastics in recent studies pose potential health risks, such as an increased likelihood of
heart attacks and strokes associated with microplastics in the cardiovascular system. The market
failure in this article would be the production and consumption of plastics. This would be a
negative externality, as the environmental and health costs of microplastic pollution impose
external costs on third parties not reflected in the market. Furthermore, it is a negative externality
as the article addresses “very little of it has been recycled” and “microplastics are everywhere”
(Jacobs). The market fails to recognize the external costs of microplastics, leading to
overconsumption and market equilibrium not being at the socially efficient level. To address this
market failure, the government can intervene. They can impose taxes or regulations on plastic
production to “internalize the external costs” of pollution and ultimately reduce plastic use to the
optimal efficient quantity (Dudley). This may be challenging due to the scale of the issue, but if
the transaction costs of making a deal are low the economy can reach the optimal quantity.
Hopefully this gives you a better understanding and if you have any questions or need
clarification, feel free to let me know.
Best regards,
*******

Subject: Market Failure Explanation
Hey Friend,
I hope this email finds you well despite the unexpected family emergency. During your
absence, we covered market failure in Econ. I am writing to you to explain it through an article
that I found: “Moderna Looks to Pare R&D Spending Even as It Pivots From Covid V accines”.
Market failure occurs when the free market doesn’t produce the best outcome for society
or in other words is inefficient. One common reason for market failure is the presence of
externalities, which are unintended side effects of economic activities that affect parties not
directly involved in the transaction. Specifically, positive externalities occur when the benefits of
a good or service translate into third parties that are not directly involved in the market.
In the context of this article, Moderna, a biotechnology company has decided to expand
its research and development efforts to other vaccines beyond COVID-19, which presents a clear
example of a positive externality. If one gets a vaccine, not only are they more immune to the
disease, it helps others who aren’t vaccinated as they are less likely to spread it to those people as
well. This spillover into the workforce as a healthier population results in a more productive
workforce and lower absenteeism due to illness, which can lead to a more robust economy and
increase productivity, positively impacting not only individuals but also businesses and the
economy as a whole.
But despite these positive externalities associated with Moderna’s vaccine research
expansion, the free market does not naturally consider these benefits which leads to the market
equilibrium resulting in underproducing vaccines for diseases because the private benefits to
Moderna do not capture the full societal benefits generated by this expansion of research and
development. For example, if the consumer's marginal benefit or the conventional demand is $10
less than the social marginal benefit, the external marginal benefit gained from Moderna’s efforts
would be $10.
As a result, government intervention or other policy measures may be critical to address
this market failure and ensure the optimal allocation of resources to Moderna’s research and
development in vaccines. The most obvious example of this would be a government subsidy
which could incentivize Moderna and similar companies to invest in research and development
for vaccines that provide positive externalities to society.
In summary, market failure involves situations where the market does not account for all
the costs and benefits associated with economic activities. In the case of vaccine research,
positive externalities lead to the underproduction of the vaccines, and corrective policies such as
vaccine subsidies are necessary to rectify this market failure. I hope my explanation and the
usage of the article helps you grasp the concept of market failure. (448 words)
Best,
ECON 101 Student.

To: Friend

Thursday, March 21, 2024
Subject: Market Failure
Good afternoon friend, I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to explain the
concept of market failure that we are currently learning in economics, as well as share a good
example I found that could be helpful.
First, It is important that you understand what market failure is. As you already know, a
market is in equilibrium when the quantity of supply and demand are equal. However, if a
market is in equilibrium it does not necessarily mean that it is efficient. This is where the concept
of market failure comes in. If a market in equilibrium is not efficient, then total surplus is not
being maximized. This would mean that the equilibrium quantity is different from the efficient
quantity, which is the quantity at which marginal benefit intersects marginal cost as you may
recall from marginal analysis. This can happen as a result of several different factors:
externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. An externality is an
indirect cost (negative) or benefit (positive) that is an unaccounted for effect on society. Common
resources are rival in consumption and non-excludable, which can result in overuse. Public
goods are both nonrival in consumption and non-excludable, which can result in a lack of
incentive for providing these goods as no one has to pay. Artificially scarce goods are excludable
and nonrival in consumption, and led to inefficiency because the marginal benefit would be
maximized if they were free for everyone, yet must have a price. These market failures can be
fixed by government intervention in the form of a subsidy or taxes and restrictions based on what
kind of failure it is. For positive externalities or public goods where the efficient quantity is
higher, the government may subsidize these goods so that more are produced. For negative
externalities and common resources, the government may impose regulations or Pigouvian taxes.
A solution for artificially scarce resources could be an alternative revenue stream that would
allow all consumers to enjoy the benefits.
One real example I found that demonstrates market failure is in an article called “Major
Sources of Air Pollution: Farms” that I will cite below so you can access. This article is about the
pollution that farms generate and the negative impacts that pollution has on the environment.
This demonstrates market failure in the market for produce specifically due to a negative
externality because the pollution generated by farms is an uncompensated cost that they are
imposing on their environment. This uncompensated cost of pollution is not accounted for in the
market equilibrium, meaning that the efficient quantity for produce will actually be less then the
equilibrium. The government could help this market reach efficiency by directly focusing on the
pollution by setting environmental standards or taxing the amount of pollution emitted, or by
focusing on the production by setting production quotas or taxing the produce.
I hope this was helpful and urge you to reach out if you have any more questions.

Dear Friend,
I am reaching out to clarify any confusion you may have regarding market failures. A
market failure occurs when absent any intervention, including government, the market fails to
reach the efficient outcome (Dudley). This means that resources aren’t allocated efficiently.
Market failure can be demonstrated by externalities, artificially scarce goods, public goods, and
common resources. Specifically, I will be focusing on externalities to address this concept.
Externalities are uncompensated benefits or costs that an individual or firm puts on others. For
example, let’s take the market for personal medical use devices and the negative externality it
poses. In the market for personal medical use devices without external impact, we have our
consumer and producer surplus being maximized at equilibrium. However, this does not account
for the fact that we have the issue of excessive plastic from medical devices causing damage to
the environment (Alcorn). This develops into greenhouse gasses, toxins, and harm to the world’s
oceans that in turn affect the surrounding communities (Alcorn). We have third parties that were
not involved in the production or consumption of the good having to deal with an additional cost
of the good. When we consider this in the context of our supply and demand model, we see that
we now have a social marginal cost curve that is exceeding the producers' marginal cost curve.
This is because the social marginal cost curve takes into account the external cost, which is the
cost of the environmental damage. The intersection between the social marginal cost curve and
our social marginal benefit curve (in this case, the demand curve), becomes our efficient
quantity. So in this representation, we can see that when we follow the market quantity that
doesn’t take into account the external cost, we have a deadweight loss that would have been
taken into account at the new equilibrium. That essentially shows the inefficient allocation of
resources. When the cost isn’t being compensated by the producers, there is inefficiency in the
market. With the production of personal use medical devices, producers aren’t accounting for the
negative impacts of plastic during production causing environmental impact, so they are
producing more than they should be. That is why the efficient quantity is lower than the market
quantity. Referencing back to our knowledge of government controls, a possible way this can be
addressed is through a tax at the price of the external cost or a quota at the efficient quantity.
While this is just one example of a market failure, it can be used as a framework to understand
the way society can be affected by them.
Sincerely,
Y our Peer

Dear Friend,

I hope this message finds you well. I understand that the concept of market failure has been difficult to understand, so I want to clarify it by focusing on a recent example highlighted in The Wall Street Journal. 
Market failure is when the free market is left alone and fails to distribute resources efficiently, leading to social welfare loss. Externalities are a common cause of market failure, occurring when third parties are adversely affected by unaccounted for costs or benefits. These externalities can be positive or negative, but negative externalities often lead to market inefficiencies.
A negative externality is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others, as described in the article, "Climate Change Has Hit Home Insurance, Is Health Insurance Next?" from The Wall Street Journal. This article explains that fire damages are not paid by those causing climate change but by homeowners through higher insurance prices. 
The article describes a classic case of negative externality. In addition to carbon emissions from industries, vehicles, and deforestation, other activities contribute to climate change. As a result, these actions come with broader societal costs, like increased wildfire risks, that don't show up in the prices of the goods and services they produce. Therefore, the true cost of these goods and services is higher than what is paid for them, leading to overconsumption and increased carbon emissions.
There is a huge impact on the insurance market. This situation has resulted in a sharp increase in home insurance prices and insurers withdrawing from the California market as a direct result of these wildfires. It is clear from this scenario that there has been a market failure as homeowners and insurance companies are left to deal with the financial consequences of climate change, a cost to which they did not contribute. The market fails to take into account the true cost of climate risks, resulting in an inefficient allocation of resources where insurance prices do not accurately reflect the risk of wildfires.
A market failure in this context is the difference between the private costs paid by homeowners and insurers and the social costs associated with climate change. Because the external costs of climate change are not internalized into the decision-making processes of those who contribute to carbon emissions, the market does not naturally correct this inefficiency.
This example shows how externalities, particularly negative ones, can lead to market failures. Consequently, interventions are necessary in order to correct these inefficiencies and realign market outcomes with social welfare. To reduce the effect of climate change and other environmental challenges, it is crucial to understand how externalities and market failure are related.
I hope I helped you understand the concept of market failure and its relevance to current environmental and economic challenges. Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

Dear Friend,
        While you were absent, we covered the concept of market failure in Economics class. In simplest terms, market failure is when the resources in a market are inefficiently distributed or used. Graphically, this would be seen when the equilibrium point is different from the efficient point, which creates deadweight loss. Oftentimes, the  efficient quantity/price can be seen due to the presence of a social marginal cost/benefit curve; these are the additional cost or benefit incurred by society by producing an additional unit of the good in question, and they are either seen below the supply or demand curves. There are several concepts that can contribute to and cause market failure, such as externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. One such concept, in particular negative externalities, is a prevalent cause of market failure and can be seen in real life examples. An externality is an uncompensated cost or benefit that an individual or a firm imposes on others, usually an uninvolved third party. This can be seen in a real life example in the Wall Street Journal article “Electric Cars Emit More Particulate Pollution” by Michael Buschbacher and Taylor Myers. In this article, the authors describe how electric vehicles in California may be deceptive in their marketing and how they may not be as environmentally friendly as described. Specifically, small tire-wear particles that are emitted during use are shown to be as detrimental as exhaust emissions. In fact, “Electric cars weigh far more than gasoline-powered ones, so their tires degrade faster”, causing more emissions than even some gasoline powered cars (Buschbacher and Myers). This illustrates the effects of a negative externality when uninvolved third parties are factored in; for example, people who live in the areas in which these electric car drivers commute through. They had no involvement in the production or consumption of these vehicles, but they may have to bear the health effects of being exposed to this pollution. In a market sense, experts may calculate the cost that these emissions have on society at a dollar value, which is known as the external marginal cost. This cost is factored into the supply and demand of the market and forms a curve above the supply curve known as social marginal cost (SMC). It is important to note that the efficient point in this market is where this SMC intersects with demand, or social marginal benefit. This efficient quantity will be below the equilibrium one because society produced too many of these electric cars and needs to scale back to properly compensate for the harm done. As a reminder, this indicates market failure as the current equilibrium price is not the efficient one. This can best be resolved with a tax, which will help the market reach this efficient point. I hope that this example was able to help clarify the concept of externalities and market failure and that you have a good understanding of the topic now.

However, since the negative effects of dumping wastewater into the river isn’t technically taken into account, or internalized, by Chemours, the market continues to operate at an inefficient level, failing to produce as much total surplus as possible and creating a deadweight loss. 
	Chemours could take the wastewater issue into account and move the market toward an efficient equilibrium by either targeting the externality or the market (Dudley). For instance, targeting the externality could include a tax on the amount of wastewater dumped. Or, targeting the market could involve a production quota where the quantity of good that Chemours produces is limited to reduce the effect of the wastewater dump. Either way, the negative externality must be acknowledged and reduced to remove the market failure and move to an efficient equilibrium.

Hi __________,
I hope everything is well with your family, and I’m glad to help you understand the concept of market failure. A market failure occurs when the market equilibrium produces an inefficient outcome. An efficient market maximizes total surplus, while an inefficient market fails to reach this maximum.
Here’s an example: the attached article identifies groundwater depletion as a primary cause of rising sea levels along the East Coast (Rojanasakul & Hernandez, 2024). A market failure occurs due to negative externalities caused by the overuse of groundwater.
Groundwater is a common resource, thus being non-excludable and rival in consumption. This means that it is consumable and accessible to everyone, but individual consumption reduces the total amount available. Simply put, groundwater is a shared resource that can be depleted by overconsumption. 
Groundwater depletion causes sea levels to rise, which produces adverse effects including increased flood hazards, storm surge risks, and significant damage to coastal structures (Rojanasakul & Hernandez, 2024). These unintended consequences are called negative externalities because they negatively affect society altogether, besides just consumers and suppliers of groundwater. These externalities are measured by external marginal costs.
By failing to account for external marginal costs, the groundwater market equilibrium does not maximize total surplus. Thus far in class, we assumed consumers, producers, and the government to be the only participants in the market model, where the supply and demand curves represent the producer marginal cost and consumer marginal benefit. To accurately reflect the real-world, we must consider externalities affecting all others. Consequently, the social marginal cost is the sum of the producer marginal cost and external marginal costs, and the social marginal benefit is the sum of the consumer marginal cost and external marginal benefits. Whereas market equilibrium occurs where supply and demand intersect, market efficiency occurs at the intersection of social marginal cost and social marginal benefit. At this point, society’s net gain, or total surplus, is maximized.
Back to the article’s example: without accounting for the external marginal cost of groundwater use, the supply curve does not reflect the true social marginal cost of groundwater with negative externalities. This means that the current market quantity of water is inefficiently high while the market price is inefficiently low. Government intervention can reduce negative externalities by regulating groundwater exchange. For example, price floors and taxes levied on groundwater suppliers can raise the price of water to reflect the marginal social cost, therefore reducing consumption. Additionally, quotas can limit the quantity of groundwater consumed. 
Overall, market failure happens when the market does not maximize total welfare in equilibrium, resulting in inefficiency. As the article demonstrates, market failure can be caused by negative externalities, due to external marginal costs (i.e adverse effects of depleting groundwater), and overconsumption of a common resource.
Let me know if you still have questions. I’m happy to clarify any other confusion in ECON 101 as you figure things out with your family.
Best,

Hope you’re doing well. Let me help you catch up on your coursework by explaining market failure.

In general, a market failure occurs when absent of any type of intervention, the market fails to reach maximized total surplus. This means that it doesn’t reach its true equilibrium price and quantity. In an efficient, competitive market, prices and production levels are set such that the marginal social benefits, the satisfaction experienced by all consumers from another unit of a good, equal the marginal social costs, the total cost that society pays for when producing another unit. However, market failures disrupt this equilibrium, leading to an inefficient allocation of resources. One of these types of failures is in the form of externalities, which is when production or consumption imposes external costs or benefits on others not accounted for in the market price. Externalities happen because producers/consumers do not bear the full costs of these externalities on society, so they tend to over-produce/over-consume more than the socially optimal level, leading to an inefficient market outcome. There are negative externalities, where the full cost to society is higher than just the producer's marginal cost, implying the efficient quantity should be lower than the current level. Conversely, positive externalities occur when demand exceeds the accounted amount due to an external marginal benefit, so the efficient quantity should be higher than the current level. If this is confusing, let me provide a recent example of an externality. 

In the recent New York Times article titled "Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns", it discusses the growing research showing microplastics are being found inside the human body, including in our blood, lungs, and even placentas of pregnant women. It cites a one study that found patients with microplastics in their blood systems were 4.5 times more likely to experience heart attacks, strokes, or death. (Jacobs, 2024). This demonstrates a significant negative externality - the production and use of plastics by companies imposes huge external health and environmental costs on society that are not reflected in the market prices of plastic goods. Since producers don't have to pay for these externalized social costs, too much plastic is being produced and consumed relative to what would be optimal when considering all costs to society. In this case, the social marginal cost is greater than what is currently accounted for. This is the essence of a market failure due to externalities. 

There are ways for the government to address this market failure. It could enact emissions taxes and tradable emissions permits like a license to produce or use plastic. These methods are the least costly way. It could also create environmental standards in the form of laws specifying actions. These methods could be done on either the externality itself, or the market of plastic. Any of these methods would increase producers’ marginal cost, accounting for the externality and decreasing the quantity to efficient equilibrium and address the market failure.

Hopefully this caught you up.

Writing Assignment 3: Market Failure
Dear Friend,
I am writing today to help you better understand the concept of market failure, in the hopes that
you can keep up with the Econ 101 course work. In essence, a market failure occurs when,
without any intervention and even in equilibrium, the market fails to reach efficiency and
therefore does not maximize total surplus. Total surplus is the combined value that consumers
and producers receive from market transactions. Market failure could be measured by calculating
the difference between the total surplus at market equilibrium and the efficient outcome.
One of the main sources of market failure is the presence of externalities, unintended side effects
that affect those not directly involved. A positive externality, also known as an external benefit,
is a gain that an individual or firm provides a third party without receiving compensation. In this
situation, all the benefits that actions could have on society are not considered, so the market
underproduces. An example of a positive externality is how education not only benefits the
person directly receiving that education but also benefits society because educated individuals
bring more economic value to a community.
On the other hand, a negative externality, also known as an external cost, is an uncompensated
cost that an individual or firm imposes on an unrelated third party. In this situation, the market
overproduces because all of the costs are not valued. An example of a negative externality could
be the indirect burdens faced by stakeholders as a result of initiatives aimed at reducing
pollution. In an effort to prevent numerous premature deaths each year, the Environmental
Protection Agency (EPA) implemented stricter regulations for power plants and factories to spew
fine particulate matter (Friedman, 2024). However, manufacturers and 24 states sued the EPA as
a result of this rule, claiming that this would increase costs for manufacturers, utilities, and the
public. This situation demonstrates a negative externality within the market for goods produced
by power plants and factories. While the EPA aimed to address public health concerns, the
indirect burden imposed on stakeholders, such as increased costs, highlight the presence of
market failure resulting from negative externalities.
In addition to externalities, market failure also relates to public goods, common resources, and
artificially scarce goods. A good is excludable when the supplier of the good is able to prevent
nonpayers from consuming that item and a good is a rival in consumption if the same unit of that
good cannot be consumed by multiple people at once. When goods are nonexcludable, the
market will encounter the market failure of free riders, which are consumers who utilize the good
without directly paying for it. If there are too many free riders, the market could fail because the
resources could become economically infeasible to produce without enough consumers paying to
utilize it.
In general, recognizing these market failures can be extremely beneficial in understanding how
to correct inefficiencies and ensure the overall wellbeing of our society. Hopefully, this
explanation has helped better clarify the course content.

Dear Friend,
	As you know, efficiency occurs when a market is able to maximize it’s total surplus. Market failure occurs when the market equilibrium is not efficient and therefore unable to maximize total surplus. There are multiple reasons that a market can fail, in Econ-101 the causes that we have gone over are externalities, artificially scarce goods, common resources and natural resources. All of these can cause the market equilibrium to be inefficient. 
	A negative externality is when there is an impact on a population or people who are not directly consuming a product. When a negative externality is present, it means that the true cost of a unit or item is higher than the market price. This difference between the actual cost and the market price is what we call the Social Marginal Cost. On the opposite side, when a positive externality is present, there is a benefit to a population or people who are not directly consumers of a product. As you can guess, this means the true value of a unit or item is greater than the market price. The difference between the actual value and market price is called the Social Marginal Benefit. In both cases, the market price, while in equilibrium with our supply and demand curves, is not actually efficient. When the market is not efficient, we end up with dead weight loss, which can be described as the surplus that neither consumer nor producer gains but could become surplus if the market was efficient. When a negative externality is present, the efficient quantity is often actually less than market equilibrium, while a positive externality indicates that the efficient quantity is greater than market equilibrium.
	Now that we have a firm understanding of externalities and the roles that they play in market failure, I would like to apply this to the cigarette industry and an article I found in the Wall Street Journal that demonstrates market failure.  Traditionally, cigarette sales represent a negative externality, as secondhand smoke has negative health ramifications on people who do not smoke themselves. outcome; that is, without intervention from an outside party–like the government. It’s important
to remember that a market can be in equilibrium without it being at its efficient outcome. We can
tell if a market is at its efficient point by seeing if total surplus is at its maximum, meaning
consumer surplus and producer surplus are at their highest points and deadweight loss is at its
lowest. Markets fail if maximized total surplus, or a maximized societal net gain, is not achieved.

negative, is a direct effect on a third party unrelated to the market in question by the actions of
the participants of a market that are unintentional and are uncompensated. In Canada’s logging
industry, for example, deforestation of Canada’s largest forest–The Boreal Forests–is directly
affecting the surrounding ecosystem. The elimination of the trees means that there are less
habitats available for its ecosystem, there is more carbon released to the air affecting the entire
globe’s climate, and is currently only leaving younger trees whose bark is less protective against
wildfires than their older counterparts. (Austen, Vjosa) These effects are unintentional; they are
cutting down trees to make profit, not with the goal of affecting the environment. They are also
uncompensated meaning the logging industry is not forced to to fix these effects.
As mentioned earlier, this is a negative externality. A negative externality is an
externality that puts a cost on a third party, while a positive externality gives a benefit to a third
party without requiring compensation from the third party back to the market participant. This is
a negative externality because what’s happening to the third party–the environment and
ecosystem–is a cost and a burden to them.

benefits, or society’s net gain. Society’s net gain and total surplus looks at everyone affected by
the market, not just the producers and consumers of the logs. While the producers and consumers
gain from the logging market, there is a loss of welfare to the environment that is not considered
when the market is in action. Since this loss of welfare is unaccounted for, the point at which the
market settles without intervention is not optimal and does not maximize total net benefits; this
means the logging market has failed due to the negative externality.

To: Gabe
From: Econ 101 Student
Subject: Market Failure & Externalities, Explanation and Example
Hey Gabe, sorry you missed class, I’ll help you out and explain what we learned about
market failure. At a high level, market failure is defined as when the market on its own (without
government or outside intervention) fails to be efficient. Remember also that a market is efficient
when total surplus is maximized. Up to this point, the only examples of inefficient markets that
we have seen are from government intervention. However, externalities are another concept that
can make a market fall out of efficiency.
An externality is something that has impacts outside of its own market, or rather a third
party, not simply the buyer or the seller, is affected by the happenings of the market. There are
two separate kinds of externalities, positive and negative. A positive externality is a benefit that
an individual or firm confers on others without receiving compensation. A negative externality is
an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others.
When a negative externality is measured and placed overtop a supply and demand graph,
it is called the social marginal cost. A new line is added to the graph, above and parallel to
supply. In between the supply and SMC is the total external cost, the area of total surplus it
covers is subtracted from the original total surplus. Similarly, positive externalities also add a
new line to the graph, called external marginal benefit. It lays parallel and above the demand
curve. The area that this takes up is added to the total surplus. Deadweight loss lays in between
the quantity of the market and quantity of efficiency.
I found an article online that might help you conceptualize the idea of how an externality
is a market failure: Climate Change Has Hit Home Insurance. Is Health Insurance Next? In this
instance, the large controllable for your own health insurance prices would be individual health
choices, like choosing not to smoke. But because of the negative externality that climate change
and wildfires are, you no longer have the choice to not breath smoke. Then your insurance rises
to componsate for hospitalizations caused by something you, nor the insurer could control.
In class, we had a few examples for each. A common positive externality would be
vaccines. Even if you aren't vaccinated, and most people around you are, you still get most of the
benefit of being vaccinated because less of the disease is being passed around without paying for
a vaccine. On the contrary, a negative externality is something like pollution. Let's say that a
leather factory dumps its waste into a river that people use for agriculture and drinking water,
that water is now polluted and causing harm to those who utilize it. They neither produced nor
purchased any leather, but are being hurt by the leather market.

Dear Friend,
I would love to help you understand the concept of a market failure. The definition of a market
failure is anything that causes a market for a good or a service to lose efficiency. In economic
terms, efficiency is when total surplus is maximized, or when both consumers and producers are
receiving their respective “best” outcomes. I’ll give you an example of a specific market failure.
The article I have attached in this email pertains to the concept of a positive externality. This
article describes a curious effect that has been occurring throughout major American cities. It
appears that an increase in street art has been associated with an increase in public safety. It is
mentioned in the article that this may be because drivers are more aware and cognizant of their
surroundings when their surroundings stand out. Specifically, pedestrian crashes were reduced by
50% and drivers began to yield to pedestrians 27% more in cities such as New Y ork, Seattle, and
Portland. It may not seem intuitive that something with a good effect on society would be
deemed a market failure. However, because this occurrence does not account for the benefit this
art provides to third parties in the form of increased pedestrian safety, reduction in property
damage, and/or reduction in traffic congestion, it is considered a failure of the market. An
externality is defined as a market that confers an effect (this can be a benefit or a consequence)
on an unrelated third party. Negative externalities impose consequences, while positive
externalities impose benefits. Intuitively, as a positive externality, if street art provides value
outside of the street art market (meaning it provides value to more than just consumers and
producers in the street art market), then there should be more street art in the world – the optimal
quantity of street art is less realistically than it should be. The optimal price of street art also
increases, as logically it is “worth” more than it is in the market itself. This optimal quantity is
what we find when we consider the added benefit street art brings to society. The optimal price
and quantity are found where the social marginal benefit (found by adding the social benefit to
the marginal benefit, or demand, of consumers in the street art market) intersects the social
marginal cost (supply of the producers in the street art market). I hope this helps!

Market Failure
Hi,
I heard that you traveled home due to a family emergency, I am so sorry to hear that.
Since you missed class, I will get you up to speed on the new topic we learned which is market
failure. This whole idea of market failure relies on your fundamental knowledge on when a
market is efficient. As you recall from our past unit, a market is efficient by maximizing its total
surplus which, in other words, is maximizing society’s total net gain. This allows the optimal
allocation of goods/resources so there is no waste. Market failure is just the inefficient allocation
of these goods/resources which results in waste. Market failure can be caused by externalities,
common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods.
Before we look at the specifics of the space exploration market, I want to teach you about
externalities. Externalities come in two forms, positive and negative. A positive externality is
caused due to unforeseen/unaccounted for benefits that create inefficiencies in the market. At a
more technical level, the Societal Marginal Benefit curve (SMB) is greater than the free market
demand. This leads to an underproduction of the correct number of goods society wants. On the
other hand, a negative externality is caused due to unforeseen/unaccounted for costs that create
inefficiencies in the market. In this case, the Societal Marginal Cost curve (SMC) is greater than
the free market supply which would lead to an overproduction of goods.
With the space exploration market, there is a ton of pollution that gets generated as we
push our limits. As Hall states, “In the past few years, the number of rocket launches has spiked
as commercial companies…and government agencies have lofted thousands of satellites into
low-Earth orbit.” This market has consistently grown over the past few decades, but it has not
come without a cost. As more rockets are being launched, they continuously pollute our
atmosphere which results in a variety of concerns like its effects on the environment and human
health. In fact, a study found that the soot from rockets is “nearly 500 times as efficient at
heating the atmosphere as soot released from sources like airplanes closer to the surface” (Hall).
As you can see, this market is exhibiting the traits of a negative externality. To be more
specific, the pollution that is generated from space exploration will be the specific reason why
this market is held back. It is clear that many producers in the market are not really concerned
with or accounting for the effects of pollution. If we would draw this market, we would see the
SMC curve is greater than the free market supply. This would result in a market that is
overproducing which creates inefficiency (i.e. Deadweight Loss). However, with government
intervention, this market can become efficient again. A tax on the producers will result in the free
market supply to be shifted towards the SMC curve creating a societal efficient market.
Best,
Jawad

conditions face higher health risks, resulting in increased healthcare costs. While individuals may
bear some of these costs, a significant portion is covered by health insurance companies, which
then impacts premiums and coverage for all policyholders. In this case, the supply and demand
of insurance are unchanged, but insurance companies are facing a higher social cost due to
climate change uncertainty.
The inability of insurers to accurately predict and plan for these increased costs due to climate
change-induced health impacts results in inefficiencies in the insurance market. In this case, the
true social costs of climate change-related health impacts are not fully internalized in insurance
pricing, leading to the misallocation of resources and welfare losses for society. Moreover, the
lack of historical and detailed data on how climate change affects health outcomes further
complicates the situation. This data deficiency makes it challenging for health insurers to build
accurate predictive models, which are crucial for setting premiums and allocating resources
efficiently. Such a loss of economic efficiency is called deadweight loss.
Overall, the article highlights how externalities associated with climate change disrupt the

Hi Friend,
I heard you’re struggling with the concept of market failure in our Econ class. I’m happy to help!
For basics, a market failure occurs when a market, without government intervention, fails to
reach its efficient outcome. Remember, an efficient market maximizes total societal surplus. So
to put it in other words, a market failure occurs when the market fails to maximize societal
surplus. It is important to note that equilibrium does not mean efficiency, so a market failure can
occur while said market is in equilibrium.
There are four types of market failure, but for now I will focus on one: Externalities. An
externality is a benefit/cost that an individual or firm imposes on an unrelated third party. There
are negative and positive externalities; negative externalities are associated with a cost, and
positive ones with a benefit. For example you receive a positive externality when someone else
gets vaccinated because it contributes to herd immunity. I have attached an article containing an
example of a market failure due to a negative externality. In this scenario, our market of focus is
agricultural goods in developing countries, specifically for female farmers. Farmers in these
countries are losing profit due to increased global temperatures from the burning of fossil fuels
by industrialized countries. Female farmers already have difficulty competing with male farmers,
who generally have better access to technology, and now the increasing temperatures make these
disparities even greater. Women in these countries lose nearly a third more of their income than
men do when the global temperature rises by one degree celsius. From a market perspective, the
burning of fossil fuels by industrialized countries (the firm) is creating a negative externality on
the completely unrelated agricultural market in developing countries (the third party).
Monetarily, this lost profit from the externality is called an external cost, and this external cost is
incorporated into the calculation of total societal surplus. With this additional cost, total surplus
in the market decreases, ultimately preventing the market from being efficient.
It is possible for a market failure to reach its efficient outcome by eliminating the externality,
however it requires some effort. In order for an externality to be eliminated, every member in
both involved markets must come together to discuss and find a solution that both sides are
satisfied with. For a small scale externality, this may be a reasonable possibility. However, for
large scale situations, a fair solution can be very hard to find; in my example it would require
industrialized countries to find an environmentally clean fuel alternative that is at most the same
cost as the fossil fuels they currently use. Additionally, transaction costs to find this solution can
become astronomically high. Transaction costs are the costs of bringing these people from both
markets together in order to discuss. Examples are transportation or housing for these people. As
you can imagine, the transaction costs of bringing whole countries together to discuss is far too
high to ever be considered a feasible solution, so unfortunately many negative externality market
failures, including the one attached, will never reach their efficient outcome.

Dear Econ 101 Friend,
I heard you needed help understanding the concept of market failures. The overall idea of
a market failure is that a market for a good or service is not operating at an efficient level. This
means that there is some factor that isn’t being accounted for at the current market equilibrium
that would shift the price in some way, whether that be up or down. This factor is usually the
result of the consumer getting some sort of added/lessened marginal benefit from the good or
service that isn’t taken into consideration when forming the current equilibrium price. This
results in the market failing to produce an optimal outcome and creates deadweight loss hence
the name market failure.
One prime example of this can be found in the New Y ork Times article, “Microplastics
Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns”. This article talks about a new film highlighting the
dangers of microplastics to human health as highlighted by the quote, “It doesn’t matter if you’re
rich or poor, there’s no sheltering yourself from this kind of new pollution.” (New Y ork Times).
This article represents a term related to market failure called a negative externality. A negative
externality is a negative effect a good or service has that imposes additional costs on society that
are not reflected in the market price. In this case, the negative health impacts illustrate the
adverse costs imposed by plastic products. This means that the market for plastic products is not
operating at an optimal level. To get to an efficient price, the supply curve would shift right to
account for the added price of the health effects on society. Some examples of market failures
other than negative externalities include positive externalities, public goods, and common goods.
A positive externality is effectively the opposite of a negative externality where a product has a
positive effect on society that isn’t reflected in the price. Public goods can result in market failure
due to the free-rider problem. The free-rider problem occurs when a good is non-excludable and
some consumers opt not to pay because they can benefit from the good without doing so which
shifts the efficient price but not the equilibrium price. Common goods can cause market failure
through a phenomenon called the tragedy of the commons. This occurs when there is a limited
amount of a non-excludable good. Consumers will act only based on their own benefit and
deplete the good once again shifting the efficient price but not the equilibrium price.
Overall, a market failure occurs when the equilibrium price of a market does not coincide
with the efficient price. This can be caused by externalities, public goods, and common goods as
shown by the real-life example in the New Y ork Times. Hope this helped.
Sincerely,
Y our Econ Friend

Dear John,
Of course, I would be more than happy to explain market failure to you. A market is
experiencing market failure when, at equilibrium, it fails to maximize society's total surplus
(Dudley). One way a market can fail is externalities, which can be either positive or negative. An
externality occurs when a third party not directly involved with a transaction either benefits
(positive) or is harmed (negative) by consequences of the transaction (Dudley). Positive
externalities are unaccounted for societal benefits, resulting in an equilibrium quantity and price
that are too low to maximize total surplus. Negative externalities are unaccounted for social
costs, resulting in an equilibrium quantity that is too high and a price that is too low, creating
deadweight loss (Dudley).
In an ideal market, the consumer marginal benefit is equal to the social marginal benefit, the
producer marginal cost is equal to the social marginal cost, and a graph of total surplus is the
supply and demand curve. Positive externalities shift the social marginal benefit rightward, while
negative externalities shift the social marginal cost leftward. Importantly, supply and demand are
not changed (Dudley).
Another cause of market failure are goods incompatible with our idealized market model. Ideally
a good is excludable, its access can be restricted (outside of government control) and is a rival in
consumption, meaning multiple people cannot use the same good at the same time. When a good
is non-exclusive, free riders who do not contribute to the upkeep/production of a good cause
market failure through unaccounted for benefit (Dudley). When a good is non-competitive, the
marginal cost of allowing access to the good is zero, so the efficient price becomes zero dollars.
The market fails because the marginal cost of producing another unit of the good is not zero, so
producers must charge a non-zero price to stay in business (Dudley). Competitive, non-
excludible goods are common resources, whose unlimited access but limited supply causes over
consumption which leads to negative externalities and free riders whose marginal benefit is not
accounted for. Non-excludable, non-rival in consumption public goods cannot restrict access to
free riders and have an efficient price of zero, resulting in an undervalued marginal benefit and
an inability to sustain production at an efficient price (Dudley).
Finally, excludable, non-rival in consumption goods are artificially scarce goods. In an example
of this type of good, “Spotify Earnings: Losses Narrow amid Subscriber Growth, Price Increase.”
Anne Steele discusses how Spotify has struggled to remain profitable but has been succeeding
since their decision to raise prices. Because it costs Spotify nothing to allow one more person to
listen to their music, the efficient price for Spotify is zero dollars, and the price change decreased
consumer surplus, increasing deadweight loss and lowering total surplus. However, the marginal
cost of creating one more unit, Spotify’s cost of licensing and producing music, podcasts, and
audiobooks, is not zero. Thus, the only way services like Spotify can exist and create new
products while maximizing total surplus at market equilibrium would be a government subsidy
that completely covers the cost to the consumer.
I hope that helps, feel free to reach out with any further questions,
Your Classmate

Hi!

Here’s what I know about market failure from class and outside research -- hopefully you find it helpful. 
Basically, a market failure occurs when, without any government intervention, the free market fails to reach an efficient outcome even in equilibrium. This means that even if people inside a market are making the right choices for themselves, they’re likely failing to make the best choices for society as a whole. If you remember our unit on marginal costs and benefits, you can think of it this way: a market has failed when it doesn’t maximize total surplus. 
It’s a lot easier to make sense of market failures with an example, so let's talk about a specific type of market failure: externalities. An externality occurs when a market creates a completely unrelated cost or benefit for a third party group that doesn’t include producers or consumers. There can be positive externalities or negative externalities. An example of a negative externality is pollution -- I found a great article in the New York Times about mercury pollution that we can use as an example. 
In the article, the author talks about how the production and consumption of fossil fuels like gasoline expel mercury into the atmosphere. This mercury settles into the ocean where it is eventually consumed by fish. After these fish consume the mercury, it stays in their bodies and can be ingested by humans, causing horrible side effects (Tabuchi). 
Mercury pollution is a great example of a negative externality because the fossil fuel market in the United States is completely unrelated to how people consume Bluefin tuna in Japan. Nevertheless, the fossil fuel industry still harms those people without their knowledge. 
In essence, this means that the fossil fuel industry is incurring something called an external marginal cost (a marginal cost that isn’t accounted for by producers and consumers in the original market). During the production and consumption of fossil fuels, the industry doesn't account for the costs of mercury poisoning, which, when added to the original marginal costs of fossil fuel producers, completely changes how we understand total surplus. 
Without accounting for external marginal costs, even in equilibrium, the fossil fuel market won’t be efficient. You can imagine external marginal costs like an extra line above the classic supply line on a graph (this is even more helpful when you remember that supply embodies the marginal costs of the producers). The space between the supply line and the external marginal cost line represents total external costs, which will always be a negative number. Basically, when we deal with negative externalities, we subtract the total external cost from total surplus, which means that unless the externality (in our case, Mercury pollution) is corrected, then total surplus will never be maximized, and the market will never be efficient. 
There are a few other types of market failures, including positive externalities, that I don’t have time to explain in this email, so let me know if you need more help!

Dear friend,
I hope everything is okay with you and your family. I’m writing to help you understand the concept of market failure that we learned in Econ 101, using a recent news article as an example.
First, let me introduce the general concept of market failure. Market failure occurs when the free market, without intervention, fails to achieve efficiency even in equilibrium. Essentially, it's when the market doesn't maximize the total surplus of society (Dudley, 2024). This can happen due to several reasons, such as externalities, common resources, public goods, or artificially scarce goods. I found an article in New York Times that involves the problem of plastic pollution caused by plastic medical devices (Ted, 2024). This is a classic example of market failure in the form of externalities.  
Externality means a cost or benefit to an unrelated third party that arises as an effect of consumer or producer activities in a market. Generally, externalities are categorized as positive or negative, based on their impacts. Positive externalities refer to benefits experienced by a third party without them compensating the market, while negative externalities refer to costs imposed on a third party without the market compensating them (Dudley, 2024). In the news article, negative externality arises from the market of medical devices such as inhalers and insulin pens. For instance, when consumers purchase and use plastic inhalers, the resulting plastic waste can contribute to pollution by leaching toxins into oceans and land. Additionally, the production process can generate pollution through the burning of fossil fuels and emission of greenhouse gases. People living near the polluted areas may suffer poor air and water quality, as well as the presence of microplastic in their bodies, even if they are not consumers or producers of plastic inhalers. These external negative effects add to the society’s total marginal cost related to the market and lead to a social marginal cost curve above the market’s supply curve. Meanwhile, the social marginal benefit curve remains identical to the demand curve. In this case, the market equilibrium, where supply and demand curves intersect, fails to capture the maximized total surplus, which occurs at the intersection of the social marginal cost curve and the social marginal benefit curve. Thus, efficiency is not achieved at the market equilibrium.
To internalize externalities and mitigate market failure, government intervention is often necessary. The government can directly address the externality (in our example, plastic pollution) or engage with the associated market (market of inhalers). The news article mentions that “Some countries have been drafting a treaty proposal that might ban select single-use products”. This is an example of government intervention through setting production quotas in the associated market. Other intervention methods include establishing environmental standards, imposing Pigouvian taxes on pollution emissions or polluting goods (Dudley, 2024).
I hope this explanation helps you understand the concept of market failure better.

The concept of market failure is relatively simple. Market failure is when a market on its
own fails to produce the efficient quantity of a good. That is, the market will not produce the
greatest total surplus possible. There are many ways this can happen, and I wanted to share an
example of this with you.
One way that many markets fail is due to externalities. Externalities are the effects of
producing a good that are not directly related to the market for that good. Externalities can be
either positive or negative and are most often the effects of a good on those who did not buy that
good. Because these effects are not on the buyer, they are “external” to the market. Those in the
market do not consider these external costs or benefits, and therefore will purchase too much or
too little of the good, causing deadweight loss. When externalities occur in a market, the most
common way to get the market to the efficient point is with government intervention.
The article “The Planet Needs Solar Power. Can We Build It Without Harming Nature?”
discusses an example of a negative externality in the solar panel market. Placing solar panels
comes with a cost to the animals in the areas where they are placed, because large swaths of land
are fenced off and covered up with solar panels. When these areas are covered with solar panels,
animals lose their habitats. Habitat loss is the main cause of the large global decline in
biodiversity, which has become a crisis.
Because the effect of solar panels is not on those buying the panels, but on the wildlife in
the surrounding areas, those animals are not being considered when purchasing land to put solar
panels on. This means that the external cost of the solar panel market is the cost to the wildlife
that lose their habitat when solar panels are placed. It also means that the social marginal cost is
greater than the producer’s marginal cost.
There are three different ways to solve a negative externality: Climate regulations,
Pigouvian taxes, and permits or quotas. Climate regulations only apply to the negative
externality of pollution, regulating the amount of pollution that can be produced. Pigouvian taxes
are taxes meant to change behavior, so in this example those would be taxes on land in that area
or taxes on solar panels. The last, and cheapest way to solve a negative externality is a permit or
a quota, which in our example would be a set limit on the number of solar panels that could be
placed in a certain area. If these are set at the right level, the producer’s marginal cost curve will
rise to meet the social marginal cost curve, and the market will then produce the efficient
quantity of solar panels.

I am writing to you to help you understand this new idea of market failure from lectures this past week. The definition of a market failure is when absent of intervention the market fails to reach efficiency. Until this point in Econ 101 we have always assumed that the market equilibrium is the same as market efficiency but this is simply not true. A key way to differentiate equilibrium and efficiency is that equilibrium occurs when the marginal benefit of consumers equals the marginal cost of producers whereas efficiency occurs when the social marginal benefit equals the social marginal cost. Efficiency is when society’s total surplus or net gain is maximized. A market failure can occur for a lot of reasons including but not limited to externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. Despite this difference in the market there are ways to intervene in order to get to market efficiency. The government could intervene by placing a tax, quota, standard or subsidy on the goods or service to change the quantity. The other option is that both parties could meet, and negotiate in order to account for the discrepancy. 
To help you better understand the idea of market failure in the real world, there was a New York Times article explaining that microplastics are accumulating in humans causing health issues. The article highlights a negative externality because the consumer and producers of microplastics are harming everyone, even those not consuming or producing the plastic. At the current equilibrium, the plastic industry is producing an annual quantity of 400 million metric tons of plastic, far exceeding the socially optimal level, as it fails to consider the costs to society (Jacobs, 2024). To maximize total surplus, the industry should produce a lower quantity. 
In order to fix this market failure the government needs to intervene since both parties are too large to negotiate a way for them to take on the costs that they are placing on society. The government can either focus on the market or the externalities. In the case of the microplastics the government should focus on the pollution (or externality) since the size of the plastic market would be hard to regulate and enforce. The most effective way to solve this problem is either a Pigouvian tax (a tax on the pollution) or a tradable emission permit. Personally, I would recommend a tax based on the quantity of pollution emitted because it would incentivize producers to reduce pollution. The advantages of taxing the pollution would provide flexibility for businesses to choose how they reduce pollution, and target the specific plastic polluters that are making microplastics.
I hope this explanation helps you understand what a market failure is, how to spot one in the real world and different ways to make the market efficient.

Hi friend,
Sending well wishes to you and your family. I hope you will be able to return to class soon, but in the meantime, I can explain the concept of market failure to you. 
In an ideal market scenario, when the market reaches equilibrium (when quantity demanded equals quantity supplied), society’s total net gain is maximized. Since total surplus is maximized in this scenario, the outcome is efficient. Market failure happens when, without any intervention (including government intervention), the market does not read the efficient outcome, even at equilibrium. Several concepts can play a role in market failure: Externalities, Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods. There are two types of externalities. A positive externality is a benefit conferred on others without compensation. A negative externality is an uncompensated cost that is imposed on others. In market equilibrium with a negative externality, the social marginal cost equals the sum of the producer marginal cost plus the external marginal cost. The external marginal cost at market equilibrium produces a negative total surplus. Failure to maximize total surplus occurs because the market equilibrium only considers the producers’ private marginal cost, failing to consider the societal external cost. Due to this external cost, the market fails to read where societal marginal benefit intersects societal marginal cost, so society’s total net gain is not maximized.
To illustrate the concept of a negative externality, I will use the market failure in the article “The Planet Needs Solar Power. Can We Build It without Harming Nature?” as an example. This article is about the negative effects of solar panel farms on nature. Animals need humans to solve climate change, but they also need a place to live. Solar panels present an ecological challenge because “up to a third of potential solar development in the United States could overlap with areas that have high value for wildlife movement, according to one study, as animals move to adapt to climate change” (Catrin). This overlap is a major issue because “loss of habitat is the top driver of a staggering global decline in biodiversity” (Catrin). Building solar panel farms in the American West is intended to protect nature by mitigating the climate crisis, however, it causes animal habitat loss. The market failure in this article is caused by the negative externality of animals losing habitat space. In the market for clean electricity, when the market reaches equilibrium, the outcome is not efficient. Total surplus is not maximized because producers and consumers fail to consider the negative externality of habitat loss. For instance, consumers who want to protect the environment would probably demand less solar energy relative to other forms of energy if they knew the negative impact solar farms have on biodiversity. The negative externality of the loss of animal habitat is not usually a cost accounted for in the market price of clean electricity. This discrepancy between the private and social costs leads to the overproduction of solar energy, thus creating a market failure.

To: Friend
Subject: Market Failures in ECON 101
Currently in ECON, we are learning about market failure: when market equilibrium does not produce the
efficient outcome. So far in the course, we have assumed that market equilibrium achieves the efficient
outcome, but this is not always the case. Recall, the efficient outcome occurs when total surplus is
maximized. This means that consumer and producer surplus are also maximized, but what happens when
the consumer negatively or positively affects others based on their actions? The total surplus experienced
by society is different from the surplus experienced by the individual. Thus, the market equilibrium does
not produce the efficient outcome for society. When the consumption of one good provides benefit for
others, we call this a positive externality. On the other hand, when the consumption of one good produces
a cost for others, we call this a negative externality.
Let’s apply these concepts to a real world situation: cars. Gas cars produce air pollution as they are driven,
and this air pollution negatively affects society. Generally, we associate cars to produce some level of air
pollution, so the pollution itself is not necessarily considered a negative externality. Only cars that
produce excessive amounts of pollution (i.e. pick-up trucks, vans, etc.) have a negative externality
associated with them, since the negative externality represents the additional cost society takes. Thus, we
can identify a market failure within the market of gas vehicles.
Taking this example a step further, a New York Times article Are You a Super Driver? Some States Want to
Help You Go Electric states,
“the top 10 percent of motorists in the United States… account for roughly
one-third of the nation’s gasoline use”
. This fact alone does not necessarily indicate a market failure,
however there exist cars that do not use gasoline: electric vehicles. Suppose these 10 percent of motorists
switched to electric cars and trucks. The United States would consume much less gasoline and produce
significantly less air pollution. Since society would not have to clean up this pollution later, it is saved
from the expected cost of a gas car. Therefore, electronic vehicles provide a positive externality. In fact,
this positive externality is provided by all consumers of electric vehicles, but we gain a disproportionately
larger benefit when “Super Drivers” consume and use an electric vehicle. Since we are able to identify an
unaccounted positive externality in the market for electric vehicles, there exists a market failure.

I would love to break down market failure for you!
Market failure is a situation where there is an inefficient distribution of goods and services on the free market. Market failure is caused by externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. Externalities are uncompensated costs or benefits that firms impose on parties who are not consumers of the product or service the firm produces. Artificially scarce goods are non-rival but excludable goods. This causes efficiency problems, as the marginal cost would be zero. Common resources are non-excludable but rival. These resources are available to everyone but decrease in value or quantity the more people use them. Lastly, public goods are nonrival and nonexcludable because services are provided to everyone in society, at no cost, which can lead to free riding. 
Epipens and plastic pollution are market failures. According to a New York Times article, epipens, inhalers, and insulin pens have a large impact on the environment (Ted Alcorn, 2024). Negative externalities describe a situation where a good or service harms parties who aren’t involved. When negative externalities are present the social marginal cost exceeds the marginal private cost, and the equilibrium quantity will be higher than the efficient quantity, which may result in excess production. On the other hand, positive externalities helps a third part inadvertently, the marginal private benefit is less than the social benefit. Therefore the equilibrium quantity will be less than the efficient quantity, which can lead to underproduction. Single use medical products that lead to plastic pollution are considered as a negative externality, bystanders are negatively impacted by climate change due to overproduction of plastic, even if they don't use the medical products. The prices of these medical products do not accurately represent the cost of the pollution, and consumers aren’t charged the full cost of the negative effects of pollution. As a result, plastic pollution will negatively affect the ecosystem due to excessive use of these products. 
When thinking about the graph of the single-use medical product market, the demand curve represents the consumer’s marginal benefit, and the supply curve represents the producer’s marginal expense. Due to the negative externalities caused by pollution, there is an additional line called the social marginal cost. The social marginal cost is the cost to society as a whole, for producing one further unit. Since there is a negative externality, the external cost adds to the producer’s marginal cost. Since there is no positive externality, the consumer’s marginal benefit is equal to the social marginal benefit. 
The efficient quantity is where the consumer’s marginal benefit equals the social marginal cost. Total surplus isn’t maximized, so this is classified as market failure. There is a positive total surplus between demand and social marginal cost, and deadweight loss is associated with market equilibrium. To fix this negative externality the government should impose a tax on these medical products that is equivalent to the external cost of the negative externality.

operating on its own, does not distribute resources efficiently, leading to a loss of economic
welfare. Basically, the efficient allocation of resources is not achieved, which causes producers
and consumers o t be worse off than they could be with a different allocation.
To further explain this concept I’m going to focus on “externalities” which is an external cost or
benefit that results from a certain activity that affects a third party who did not intend to receive
that cost or benefit. An example of a positive externality would be mowing lawns. Not only does
it make your lawn look better, but it can actually benefit your neighbor's mood and home value
since looking at a well-kept lawn is nice. A negative externality could be producing cars, which
is great for consumers to buy, however, this process produces toxic pollution, negatively
affecting air quality and potentially leading to sickness. These are both unintended effects that
we don’t consider at first glance.
I’m going to break down this news article I found about electric cars and how they have a
negative externality of pollution associated with their use as an example. Initially, we would
think of electric cars as having a positive externality associated with them since they reduce
tailpipe emissions, however, since eclectic car batteries are so heavy they cause more wear on the
rubber tires. As the tires wear down, they release tiny toxic particulate pollution that can cause
harm to humans and the environment. We can also take into account that the production of
electric cars is incredibly unsustainable and causes many pollutants to be released into the air,
causing humans and the environment to become ill.
In economic terms, this would mean that the supply curve shifts upwards to a new price and
quantity. Originally, the market price or “equilibrium” represents the cost the private producers
incur in producing the good or service which in this case is electric cars. When the supply curve
shifts upwards the social marginal cost creates a new optimal quantity where the price rises and
the quantity supplied decreases. Here the government needs to intervene and implement a
pollution tax on the electric car producers to reduce the consumption and production of electric
cars. Since the cars emit particulate pollution, the cost of polluting must be accounted for, so the
government essentially says to the producer “Y ou need to pay for all that damage you’re causing
from the pollution.” This way the price reflects the full cost of production including the
externality.
To summarize, a market failure is when the market fails to allocate goods and services in an
efficient or fair way. This article shows how a seemingly positive product can still have negative
effects on the market.
Hope this helps!

Writing Assignment #3 – Market Failure

Dear friend,

	In an ideal world, the market operates efficiently at the market equilibrium point, but what happens when the market fails? Market failure is when the market acts at an inefficient point—either above or below the equilibrium point. 
	A market can fail when it does not take the side effects of a decision into account; this is called an externality. Since the market does not account for the externalities, the market does not generate the maximum total surplus. Externalities are positive or negative. For example, if there was a beautiful home on the market, but the home was next to a house with an unmanicured lawn, the property would sell for less than it was worth. This side effect is a negative externality since the untrimmed landscape would present a cost for the neighboring property. Conversely, if the property was in a neighborhood of homes with manicured lawns and fresh paint, the house could be sold for more than what it was worth. This is an instance of a positive externality since the home is receiving a benefit as a side effect of the neighboring homes. Additionally, the externality may be internalized using the Coarse Theorem; in other words, the person who is causing the costs pays those affected. However, the theorem is unrealistic since it is related to transaction costs. Transaction cost is the cost of bringing all parties together. In an instance such as the neighborhood, the Coarse Theorem is more feasible since a neighborhood meeting could be called to settle a price, but in the real world, parties in the past and the future would be affected, and it is impossible to meet with those parties. Moreover, governments can correct externalities and bring the market to efficiency using quotas, taxes, permits, etc. These tools would correct the externality and bring the market to efficiency. 
	Like the example, property values are an easy place to spot externalities. Typically, homes near unsafe environments or eyesores are lower in value than those in prime locations. In the city of Hamburg, NY, citizens attempt to transform their water tower into an attraction rather than a detraction. Currently, the water tower acts as a negative externality; grey, chipped, and weathered, the water tower stands as an eyesore for the community. In an article written by Joseph Pisani for the Wall Street Journal, a citizen of Hamburg notes that he has asked the city to tear it down since he can see the “drab” structure from the windows in his home (par 19). By painting the water tower to look like a hamburger, the city hopes to capitalize on its name and turn its negative externality into a positive one. The bright and unique design will raise the price of properties in Hamburg, drawing people in and creating a benefit to living in the town.
	
I hope this helps your understanding of market failure and externalities.
