Subject: A deeper dive into Market Failures
Hello, hope all is going well. I heard that you are confused on the topic of market
failures, and wanted to get a deeper dive on it. A market failure can occur when there is no
market/government intervention, leading the market to fail to reach an efficient outcome. With
this, the market does not maximize total surplus, even at equilibrium.
In society, there are many market failures, including negative and positive externalities,
public goods, artificially scarce goods, and even common resources. However, this does not
provide a definite example of a market failure in our daily lives, with that I would like to present
an article published by CNN about the new flu vaccine. This example of a market failure is a
positive externality, defined as a benefit that an individual or firm confers on others without
receiving compensation (Dudley 2024). Positive externalities do not just include vaccines, but
they can include things such as a well-maintained front yard and education. In this article, the
specific market failure identified would be the people who take the vaccine, as they do not
realize the social implications of the new flu vaccine. People take it to either protect themselves
from the virus or as a work complaint. Many people disregard the fact that when they take the
vaccine, they protect others as well from getting that same virus, even though those other people
might not take it, creating an external benefit.
With this, you might ask why this is considered a market failure. In the market for
vaccines, at equilibrium, there are too few units of the good compared to the efficient level. With
this, since we fail to account for the externality, it does not generate as much total surplus as
possible (Dudley 2024). To ultimately get to the efficient level, we must shift demand to the right
to offset the “too little” of the goods we have. If this were a negative externality, we would shift
supply left as we were overproducing. With this now, our social marginal benefit, which is
consumer and external marginal benefit, is higher than consumer marginal benefit, intersecting
producer marginal cost at the efficient point. In a positive externality, there is going to be
deadweight loss associated with the market equilibrium because the marginal social benefit is
greater than the marginal social cost.
However, there are ways to pursue efficiency in the market to help correct this
externality. With a positive externality, the government can subsidize the vaccine, as they realize
it prevents both multiple strains of the flu and even COVID-19, protecting people who take it
and those who cannot, reaching an efficient outcome. However, in reality, this might not be
possible due to the Coase theorem. This theory states that with externalities an economy can
always reach an efficient solution, provided that the transaction costs of making a deal are
sufficiently low (Dudley 2024). We cannot do this due to the normally high transaction costs
associated with certain externalities and how uncertain we are about them.
Sincerely,
Econ 101 Classmate

Hello Friend, 
In response to your question on market failure, Market failure is when “without any intervention, the market by itself does not reach the efficient outcome of total surplus by not fully accounting for the costs and benefits in the decisions it makes” (Dudley). Addressing market failures is crucial for getting towards market efficiency, which will reduce the waste of scarce resources. A recent real-life event that demonstrates market failure is the potential oil spill off the coast of Huntington Beach, California. This type of Market Failure in economics is defined as a negative externality, which is an external cost that affects third parties not directly involved in the market, where the environmental costs of oil production and consumption such as environmental pollution from the oil spill to the marine life, coastal ecosystems, and local economies are not fully reflected in the market. The failure of the market to internalize these external costs of environmental damage leads to inefficient resource allocation as consumers may not fully consider the environmental impact of their oil consumption such as oil extraction and transportation. Not to mention, since oil producers do not bear the full cost of production activities, such as pollution cleanup, the market incentivizes them to care less about allocating funds to prevent pollution. As a result, there is a misallocation of resources, distorting both production and consumption decisions in the market by incentivizing behaviors that harm the environment and efficient outcomes for society. Inefficiencies means that the total surplus is not maximized, and as the negative externality is reflected on the market, it is simply added onto the supply line, or the marginal costs, as an external cost. The total surplus at market equilibrium then because the sum of the total surplus and the negative total surplus subtracted. The total surplus with the external cost is less than the total cost at market equilibrium which means the market is currently inefficient since total efficiency is not maximized. The Oil Spill in California example presents the importance of recognizing and addressing market failures in our society that are happening right now. Addressing this misallocation often requires government interventions through regulations and taxes to internalize external costs and ensure that producers and consumers bear the true costs of their actions. By understanding the causes of market failures and implementing appropriate policy responses, the market can become efficient and making the most out of its limited resource by maximizing the total surplus.

Hello, sending my best regards to your family. Here’s an update to help you understand Market Failure while you’re away, I hope it helps.
In class, we learned that a market failure occurs when the economy, without government intervention, fails to reach an efficient outcome even when in equilibrium. In other words, the market simply cannot maximize total surplus. To visualize, let’s refer to a graph like we often do in class. We can determine the market failure by identifying the total surplus at market equilibrium, identifying the efficient outcome (maximum total surplus, or society’s net gain), then measuring the difference between the two. Market failure can be caused because of a negative externality, which is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others. This causes an external cost, which can be seen through an additional leftward supply curve behind the original supply line on a graph, labeled “social marginal cost.” This represents the overall consequences of the negative externality on society; it forces a tax to be placed on the source that is negatively impacting the economy indirectly. This causes the price of the source to shoot upwards, hence the redrawn leftward social marginal cost curve which correlates to a higher price than the original supply curve. As we’ve learned, this tax on the negative external source is called a Pigouvian tax, which is necessary to stabilize its negative effect on the world, discourage its production, an inspire manufacturers who produce harmful emissions to look elsewhere for cleaner production techniques. One article written by Lydia DePillis, “We’re All Climate Economists Now,” pinpoints the significant negative externality of carbon emissions released from production factories, which contributes to market failure. The author stresses how global warming and carbon emissions negatively impact the economy by slowing down the gross domestic product (GDP). This has an overall detrimental effect on the economy because as the GDP is lowered due to climate change which is caused by excess carbon emissions released into the air, taxes must be put on those carbon emissions to discourage their production. Thich proves that market failure is inevitable, as total surplus cannot be maximized with a Pigouvian tax placed on the negative externality. To clarify, carbon emissions are classified as a negative externality that can cause market failure because air pollution is an unaffiliated subject that directly impacts the market. Overall, market failure can be summarized as when the market fails to reach an efficient outcome, making a maximized total surplus unreachable. Negative externalities such as carbon emissions released from factory production contribute to this market failure, by increasing the social marginal cost as a result of climate change, which once again creates the need for a tax on the carbon emissions due to their overall negative environmental effect which directly impacts the economy. Dear Friend,
Market failures occur when the market equilibrium outcome is not actually the efficient
outcome as a result of externalities within the market that have either negative or positive effects
on individuals uninvolved in the market. An externality is an effect caused by the production or
consumption of a good or service that impacts parties unrelated to the market. Externalities are
measured as a social marginal cost or a social marginal benefit, the social marginal cost is
subtracted from the supply curve by the measure of the externality cost for the production of one
unit, and the social marginal benefit is added to the demand curve by the measure of the benefit
of the consumption of one unit of the good.
Market failures are often present with pollution, the production of goods and services in
many industries creates pollution that is not measured within the market, thus exemplifying a
market at equilibrium but not efficient. Pollution is a negative externality and to account for it
within the market the social marginal cost of the production of one unit must be identified and
subtracted from the supply curve, which would lead to an efficient market outcome that would
likely lower production and increase price to mitigate the externality.
However, market failures are not always negative, externalities from a market may
produce a positive effect on the uninvolved population. A good example of this is vaccinations,
vaccinations positively affect the population by decreasing the likelihood of a disease spreading
with every vaccination. This presents a social marginal benefit, even if not everyone is
vaccinated the more people there are the less likely a disease will spread.
The electric car industry also presents a positive market failure, the increased competition
between electric car industries has created the positive externality of boosting the production of
sustainable energy vehicles rather than gas and diesel vehicles which produce much greater
environmental harm due to emission pollution. As competition to produce the most innovative,
sustainable, and accessible electric vehicles rises between automotive companies like Tesla,
BMW, General Motors, and more, supply becomes more accessible and demand rises due to the
increase in accessibility and decreased prices resulting from the competition (Ewing, 2024).
Individuals who own gasoline cars or who may not even own a car are both benefitting from the
decrease in vehicles that produce pollution. This presents a social marginal benefit to the whole
of society where the consumption and production of electric cars are growing.
Market failures are present in almost every market, but unlike the word suggests they are
not always negative. Market failures can be adjusted into market efficiency when the social
marginal benefit or cost can be measured according to the production or consumption of a good
or service, this measure will either be added to the the demand curve or subtracted from the
supply curve to locate the efficient outcome for the quantity and price.
From,
Y our Friend

and they built a 900-acre monkey farm housing about 43,200 monkeys. Texans who bought their
land in this county were not happy and said they are being disturbed by noise, the threat of
diseases spreading from the testing facility, and property devaluation. These effects of the
monkey farm do not negatively affect the biomedical research firm but instead are imposed on
the neighbors and residents in Brazoria County. This is a negative externality because the entity
(the residents of Brazoria County), are being negatively affected by a market that they are
otherwise unaffiliated with (the Biomedical Research market). The market failure in this
situation is that the decision of the firm to house 43,200 monkeys in a residential area does not
negatively affect the firm but instead negatively affects the neighbors.
Since this is a negative externality, we can measure it using supply (producer marginal cost),
demand (consumer marginal benefit and social marginal benefit), and social marginal cost (the
supply curve plus external marginal cost) which looks a leftward-shifted supply curve. This
supply/demand curve will have a market equilibrium where the supply and demand curves
intersect but this market is not efficient. The efficient market equilibrium is where the social
marginal benefit intersects the social marginal cost. This situation creates negative total surplus
which is also the deadweight loss at the market equilibrium.
To internalize this negative externality and move to the efficient market equilibrium you can
either focus on the externality or the market for the good or service. If you focus on the
externality, you have three options: environmental standards, noise pollution taxes, and to create
tradable permits. If you focus on the market, you also have three options: environmental
standards, taxes on the good or service (Pigouvian taxes on medicine developed by the firm), and
production quotas. Since it is almost impossible to focus on the externality when dealing with
pollution (noise pollution created by the monkeys) because you cannot perfectly measure it and it
can be very expensive, we should focus on the market. In this market, we should put Pigouvian
taxes on the medicine developed by the firm and the tax should be equal to the external marginal
cost. This tax will move the producer’s marginal cost leftward to the social marginal cost,
creating market efficiency.

Market failure is when a market fails to reach efficiency on its own. This means that the
market fails to independently maximize total surplus. When discussing market failure, there are
three parties to consider: the producer, the consumer, and a third party affected by the production
or consumption of the goods or services in the market. When taking all three parties into
consideration, the efficient outcome of the market is the intersection of social marginal cost and
social marginal benefit. This is simply either the producer’s marginal cost plus total external cost
or the consumer’s marginal benefit plus total external benefit.
One cause of market failure is artificially scarce goods which are goods and services that
are excludable but non-rival. This means that the producer of the good or service can prevent
those who don’t pay for the good or service from using it but multiple people can use the same
good or service at the same time. This also means that allowing one additional person to use the
good or service does not cost the producer anything. Therefore, the social marginal cost for the
producer is nothing and because the efficient outcome is the intersection of social marginal cost
and social marginal benefit, the market is most efficient when the producer charges nothing for
the good or service. Total surplus is maximized when the producer charges nothing for an
artificially scarce good because it costs them nothing to allow another consumer to use their
good or service and then each consumer’s entire willingness to pay becomes surplus.
Recently, Disney+ announced plans to crackdown on password sharing. This could force
millions of users who rely on password sharing, an illegal activity, to either create subscriptions
of their own or to not watch the content on the platform. This is a great example of an artificially
scarce good. Disney+ is a platform that is excludable, meaning you must pay for the service to
access it, but it is also non-rival, as millions of consumers are able to use it and watch the same
shows and movies at the same time. In the streaming market, the efficient price would be $0
because, in this example, it costs Disney nothing to let one more person use their streaming
service. So why don’t they? Because it is not sustainable for the business. While allowing
another consumer to access the service costs the company nothing, licensing content, creating
content, and marketing content does cost a lot. If Disney+ cost $0, total surplus would be
maximized but the business would likely go out of business because they would not be
generating any profit. It is still however considered market failure because independently, the
market is not maximizing total surplus and the price for the platform is not at the efficient level.

describes a situation which often occurs when the allocation of goods by a free market
is not efficient enough, leading to a deadweight loss of the society net gain. Market
failures can be caused by several factors, including Externalities, Common Resources,
Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods.
One recent example of market failure is included in a news article from The New
York Times, titled “E.P.A. Sets Limits on Carcinogenic Gas Used to Sterilize Medical
Devices” (Friedman, 2024). The article discusses the EPA’s new regulations on the use
of ethylene oxide, a gas used to sterilize medical devices. Though this gas is essential
for medical purpose, its use has caused a lot of health issues in communities
surrounding sterilization facilities.
The market failure that occurs here is related to negative externalities. Externality
refers to a cost or benefit caused by a producer that is not financially received by that
producer. In the case of ethylene oxide, the companies using this gas did not need to be
responsible for the full costs of its emission. Instead, the surrounding communities
suffered from increased cancer risks due to air pollution. Therefore, we can regard the
ethylene oxide as a kind of negative externality. The external cost of its emissions is not
reflected in the market price of medical device sterilization, resulting in overuse of
ethylene oxide and higher future cost of curing cancer. It means that the current
equilibrium of this free market cannot reach to a maximum net gain, and will lead to a
deadweight loss due to its potential future cost.
In addition, we can also view this market failure considering the role of common
resources. Clean air can be considered a non-rival and non-excludable common
resource, which means that it’s available for everyone to use, and one person’s use
doesn’t diminish another’s. However, when these companies emit pollutants like
ethylene oxide, they make clean air rival. They consume the quality of this common
resource freely, transferring the cost to those who have to compete for using clean air
resource, finally leading to a market failure.
The EPA’s intervention to limit the use of ethylene oxide is an attempt to correct
this market failure. By imposing stricter regulations, the EPA attempt to internalize the
negative externality, making the companies responsible for the impact of their actions.
It is crucial because the free market failed to cover the health costs imposed on the
public, which should have been included in the cost of production.

any questions, feel free to ask me.

Dear My Friend,
A market failure occurs when, absent any intervention including government
intervention, the market fails to reach the efficient outcome even when the market is in
equilibrium. Failing to reach the efficient outcome occurs when the market does not maximize its
total surplus.
One way in which a market failure can occur is due to externalities. An externality as an
uncompensated effect that an individual or firm imposes on others. Essentially, a third party who
does not act as a producer or consumer is inadvertently affected. There are negative externalities
which harm this third party and positive externalities which benefit the third party. Positive
externalities occur when the third party benefits by the actions of the producer and consumer.
The market overproduces when there is negative externality and it underproduces when there is a
positive externality.
A real world example of a negative externality would be the wildfires in the Texas
Panhandle that were caused by the company Xcel Energy’s power lines. A powerline explosion
in the region caused an unprecedented fire in the state.The fire destroyed more than one million
acres of land and killed tens of thousands of livestock (Xcel Energy). This is a negative
externality because Xcel Energy as producer supplies energy for their consumers who demand it,
but unfortunately the third party acting as ranchers in the Texas Panhandle have been negatively
affected. Not only have the rancher’s land been destroyed, but many of their product, being the
cows, have been killed.
When there is a negative externality, there is a negative total surplus which can also be
referred to as deadweight loss. This deadweight loss acts as a representation of the cost that
society must face due to market inefficiencies. A representation of this cost that society has faced
due to the fires is loss of land and cattle. In market equilibrium, by failing to account for an
externality, the maximum total surplus is not generated. Particularly, when there is a negative
externality such as in the case of the Texas Panhandle fires, the market equilibrium will result in
too many units of the good compared to the efficient level. In this particular case, the good would
be the livestock, so there would be an increased amount of cattle than what the efficient level is
deemed to be.
In summation, the Texas Panhandle fires represent market failure because they act as a
negative externality. Land in the region and cattle were harmed by the fires and they act as a
third party to the Xcel Energy Company and their consumers.

From: Friend in Economics 101
Date: 26th March 2024
Subject: Explanation on Market Failures
	Good afternoon!
I am happy to provide some insight on market failures. Up to now, we have addressed market equilibrium as the efficient price and quantity of the supply and demand curves. However, certain unique events may occur in the market, that cause the market quantity and price to be different from the efficient quantity and price. Economists identify these cases as “market failures”, where a lack of government intervention causes the market to be unable to reach maximum total surplus (Dudley 5 March 2024). 
	In lecture, Professor Dudley covered six different market failures: negative externalities, positive externalities, private goods, artificially scarce goods, common resources, and public goods. Recently, I read an article from the New York Times titled Big Companies Cashed In on Mississippi’s Water. Small Towns Paid the Price. that is an excellent example of a market failure occurring because of a common resource. The article details how citizens from Jackson, Mississippi experienced inadequate access to water after dysfunctional water meters were installed by a German Company, Siemens. 
To understand this market failure, you must understand common resources. Common resources are defined by two factors, excludability and rivalry in consumption. The term “excludable” means a supplier of a good or service can prevent people who have not paid for it from consuming it. The term “rival in consumption” means the same unit of the good cannot be consumed by more than one person at one time (Dudley 12 March 2024). In the context of the water crisis in Mississippi, water is a common resource because it is non-excludable and a rival in consumption. This is because citizens cannot consume the same exact unit of water, but they are able to freely access it regardless of whether they paid for it. 
A primary issue resulting from non-excludable goods is the “Free Rider Problem”. Free riders are individuals who benefit from a good while not contributing to its upkeep. In the case of public waterworks, some citizens don’t contribute monetarily to the upkeep of water infrastructure. The actions of these free riders’ impact common resources, so there is a change in the supply and demand curve. The supply curve will present as the private marginal cost for the government to supply the water. The impact of free-riders and rivalry in consumption will create a social marginal cost curve above the private marginal cost curve that signifies the cost which Mississippians face. The intersection of private marginal cost and demand is the market equilibrium, and the intersection of social marginal cost and demand is the efficient level at which the market produces. This is where the market failure occurs because the efficient quantity is less than market quantity. So, there is an overconsumption of the common resource.
 Public water works are an important societal issue since they are consistently underfunded and mismanaged by companies like Siemens. I hope this example provided you with ample information on market failures, but please reach out with any questions. 
Bests,
Your friend in Economics 101

between these terms, you can better understand when market failure occurs.
Market failure occurs when absent intervention, the market fails to reach the efficient outcome,
even in equilibrium(Dudley). In order to reach an efficient outcome in a market, the market must
maximize total surplus without intervention. There can be many causes of market failure,
including externalities, which are unconsidered costs, known as negative externalities, or
benefits, known as positive externalities, unconsidered by decision-makers in the market.

industrial particle pollution output(Friedman). In this case, we can identify pollution as the
negative externality causing market failure. Particle pollution can be classified as a negative
externality because pollution is an external cost imposed on society that decision-makers do not
consider when choosing how much to produce. With this external cost, the market fails to reach
efficiency because it does not combine external marginal costs with the consumer’s marginal
costs to produce. The combination of producer’s marginal cost and external marginal costs can
be known as social marginal cost.

the impact of these externalities on a graph. At market equilibrium, where the externality is not

in the market and thus, limits total surplus from being maximized. As I explained earlier, if total

Market failures occur when the market fails to reach an efficient outcome, absent of any intervention (government intervention included). There are a few different ways that a market failure can manifest. There are externalities, which are external benefits or costs that impact a third party that is not accounted for by the market. This either results in the overproduction or underproduction of said externalities. The production of goods can also be a market failure. Goods can be classified according to two attributes: excludable and rival in consumption. Excludable means that one can not access the good unless they pay the set price. Rival in consumption means that the same unit of the good cannot be consumed by more than one person at the same time. A good that is rival in consumption and excludable is called a private good. These goods are set where the market may handle them efficiently, so they are, therefore, not market failures. A good that is rival in consumption but not excludable is called a common resource. A good that is neither rival in consumption nor excludable is called a public good. Lastly, a good that is excludable but not rival in consumption is called an artificially scarce good. 
        Market failures can often be found in news articles. In an article published in the Wall Street Journal titled New Streamer Aims to Fix Watching Sports? There is discussion over a potential new sports streaming service, which is also an example of an artificially scarce good. Dear Classmate,

	Market failure happens when the market fails to reach the efficient outcome absent any government or other type of intervention. The efficient outcome means that Total Surplus in the market is maximized. Efficiency is not the same as equilibrium, meaning that market failure can occur even when the market is in equilibrium. There are multiple types of market failures: Externalities, Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods. 
There are two types of Externalities. A Negative Externality is when another party’s economic activity indirectly imposes an uncompensated cost (called an External Cost) on a seemingly unrelated third party. A Positive Externality is when another party’s economic activity indirectly confers an uncompensated benefit (called an External Benefit) on a seemingly unrelated third party. When the market in equilibrium does not account for the externality, it fails to maximize Total Surplus and therefore results in market failure. With negative externalities, the market equilibrium results in too many units of the good compared to the efficient level, and vice versa for positive externalities. 
Common Resources are non-excludable, meaning that consumers do not have to pay producers for the good, and rival in consumption, meaning that the same unit of the good cannot be consumed by more than one person at the same time. Public goods are non-excludable and non-rival in consumption, meaning that one person accessing the good does not prevent others from using it at the same time. Artificially Scarce Goods are excludable, meaning that the supplier of the good can prevent people who do not pay from consuming it, and non-rival in consumption. Common Resources result in market failure as the Social Marginal Cost of using the good exceeds the user’s marginal cost, leading to the market overusing the common resource in equilibrium. Public Goods result in market failure because, by nature, goods that cannot be bought and sold by people cannot be efficiently allocated by the market. Artificially Scarce Goods result in market failure because although the efficient price to consumers for goods that are non-rival in consumption is zero, producers must charge a positive price in order to generate revenue and maximize profit. As a result, the market equilibrium results in a higher price and lower quantity than the efficient outcome.

This, in turn, creates more particulate pollution from the rubber tires, negatively impacting those with weak immune systems to be at greater risk of being harmed.

Dear Friend,

	Since you missed our recent class discussions, I wanted to help you catch up by teaching you about “market failure.” To begin, market failure occurs when, absent of any government intervention, the market fails to reach an efficient outcome. In a perfectly competitive market with ideal conditions, prices and quantities are determined solely by supply and demand, and society’s welfare is maximized. This occurs when the marginal benefit, the satisfaction gained from consuming one more unit of a good or service, is equal to the marginal cost, the cost of producing one more unit of that good or service. 
	The efficient outcome of a market occurs when the market reaches equilibrium, where the price of the good or service reflects its true value to society, and the quantity produced maximizes total societal welfare. However, in the real world, various market imperfections and externalities often lead to market failure, when resources are not properly allocated. One common form of market failure is a negative externality, when the market equilibrium results in too many units of the good compared to the efficient level. In the presence of a negative externality, the production or consumption of a good or service imposes costs on third parties who are not directly involved in the transaction. 
	Negative externalities lead to market failure for several reasons. Firstly, resources are not allocated efficiently because the price of the good or service does not reflect the full social cost. Producers and consumers make decisions based on this incomplete information and therefore too much of the good or service is produced and consumed, resulting in overproduction and overconsumption. Furthermore, the presence of a negative externality leads to deadweight loss, representing a loss of potential economic efficiency, and inefficiencies. One extremely prevalent type of negative externality in our society is pollution. In this article As leaders fly to Davos, how do private jets fuel climate change? | Context, the “super-rich” are critiqued for their excessive use of private jets. The emissions from private jets impose third party costs on society in the form of air pollution, climate change, and public health impacts. 
	There are a few ways in which the government can help the market get back on track. Because only a select group of people are able to use private jets, it is unfortunate that the average citizen still faces the same social and environmental costs of this luxurious service. Therefore, the government can get involved by either interacting directly with the externality or with the market for private jets. If engaging directly with the negative externality (pollution), the government can create environmental standards and rules, impose taxes based on the quantity of pollution produced, or distribute permits that limit the amount of pollution. If engaging with the market for private jets, the government can set technology requirements, tax the service, or set a production quota to limit the quantity of available private jets. 
	I hope this information helps you to better understand the concept of market failure.

Dear Friend, 
This week in class we discussed market failures and how they play a role in the economy. First, a market failure takes place when, absent any government intervention, the market is not able to achieve the efficient outcome and therefore does not maximize total surplus. Market efficiency occurs when the maximum total surplus is reached and social marginal benefit intersects social marginal cost. There are four types of failure that we learned – externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce resources. 
Externalities in the market can be either positive or negative. A positive externality, also known as an external benefit, is a benefit given to an unrelated third party making them better off without any compensation for doing so. A negative externality, also known as an external cost, is when there is a cost imposed on a third party making them worse off. The reason as to why externalities cause market failure is because the price of the goods or services does not accurately reflect the costs or benefits of that good or service in a given market. 
Types of goods are another area of market failure and includes four different categories of goods depending on whether they are excludable, non-excludable, rival in consumption, or nonrival in consumption. A good is excludable when there is a price that stops certain people from consuming the good, and is non-excludable when there is no price to pay. A good is rival in consumption when it cannot be consumed by more than one person at a given time, and is non-rival when it is available to anyone at any time. Common resources are non-excludable and rival in consumption, public goods are non-excludable and non-rival in consumption, and artificially scarce goods are excludable and non-rival in consumption. Due to the fact that these non-private goods are only one of the two, but not both excludable and rival in consumption, they cannot be efficiently allocated by the market. Thus, total surplus is not maximized, resulting in market failure. 
To help you further understand market failure, I found an article that described a negative externality - pollution. Published by The NYT the article, Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warms, highlights the dangers microplastics have in regards to human health. According to the article, scientists have discovered an abundance of microplastics found in living creatures, specifically the seafood that we eat. Microplastics were also found in human lungs, blood, feces, and even breast milk. The market failure type that is shown in the article is externalities, and the health consequences as a result of the microplastics are considered a negative externality - an external cost provided by plastic manufacturers and imposed on third party individuals. The cost of plastic goods does not account for the imposed negative health effects society is facing, proving to be an externality and therefore causing a market failure. 

Sincerely, 
Your Friend

I recently heard you needed help understanding market failure and everything involved.
First, I’m going to explain what market failure is. In general terms, market failure is when the
market fails to reach an efficient outcome, meaning it does not maximize total surplus, without
any intervention occurring within the market. An inefficient outcome could occur even when a
market is in equilibrium. A market failure could be identified by looking at the total surplus of
equilibrium, and then looking at the total surplus of the efficient outcome, and comparing them.
If they’re different then the market is failing. One way this could occur is if the market is
affected by externalities. A negative externality happens when an uncompensated cost is imposed
on another, while a positive externality is when an individual or firm benefits another without
receiving compensation for the benefit. Another way a market failure can occur is from the type
of good it is. For example, if the good is non-excludable( so either a common resource or a
public good), there is a high chance of having a free-rider problem. A free-rider problem is when
people who did not pay for the construction of the good use it. When this occurs, the markets
equilibrium no longer aligns with the efficient outcome as the maximum total surplus is being
altered by the free-riders. A similar issue happens when there is an artificial good, it is once
again difficult to maximize total surplus as it virtually costs no money to provide the good(for
example Netflix), but they still decide to charge money, which once again changes the efficient
outcome from the equilibrium price.
To demonstrate this, I will talk about a recent event that happened in Texas, which
exposed a market failure. This article was updated on March 7th, 2024, but the actual incident

Thanks for your kind email the other day. I’m really sorry to hear about your family emergency—I know homework help can’t make up for it, but hopefully it’ll ease your struggles a little.  
Anyway, I’ve been looking for examples of market failures, and I think this New York Times article is a really interesting one. As you can see, the article talks about how commercial space exploration could potentially have major negative effects on the environment because of the pollutants, soot, and emissions space exploration creates. This touches on two of the market failure examples we’ve discussed in class so far—namely, externalities and non-private goods. 
Before we start, we need to define our terms. A market failure refers to any scenario where the market outcome doesn’t maximize total surplus for a particular good (social marginal benefit doesn’t match social marginal cost). Externalities refer to cases where market activity imposes extra costs or benefits on bystanders, which the market fails to take into account. And non-private goods refer to any goods which are nonexcludable, non-rival in consumption, or both. 
The space pollution scenario addressed in The Times is one obvious example of an externality. Specifically, it’s a negative externality, which occurs when the market creates external costs. Negative externalities are market failures because the market fails to take into account the external costs of the goods/services it produces. This means the optimal quantity of that good is lower than the market quantity.  In this scenario, the market quantity of spacecraft launches reflects the producer marginal cost and consumer marginal benefit of space exploration, but fails to reflect the external cost of space pollution. Because of this, total surplus might be lower than at the efficient quantity of space launches, because of the external cost of “cumulative exhaust from more rockets….local ozone holes….[and] metals from re-entering spacecraft” (Hall). 
The article also features one of the three major categories of common goods—common resources. As we discussed in class, common resources are both nonexcludable and rival in consumption—everyone can access them without paying, but only one person can use a unit of the resource at a time. Because of this, common resources are prone to overuse—individuals will consume the resource until their individual marginal benefits reflect their individual marginal costs, but the resulting market equilibrium won’t reflect the social marginal cost of consuming that good. In this particular scenario, space corporations are using our atmosphere to launch rockets, but, if they don’t take the cost of overuse into account, the amount of launches and reentries could quickly ruin the quality of the upper atmosphere and the ozone layer. 
As the article also notes, there are solutions to these problems. The article explicitly identifies one solution—regulations. In addition, governments could use Pigouvian taxes to force markets to incorporate externalities into their decisionmaking. Furthermore, governments could cap the number of space launches with a quota. 
Hopefully that helps!

I am writing to you to help you understand market failure, a concept we learned
in our economics class. Market failure occurs when the market fails to maximize total
surplus within the market, which means that the market fails to be efficient. This occurs
without any external intervention, including by the government.
Market failure can be caused by positive and negative externalities. Positive
externalities, also known as external benefits, are when an individual, or a company,
unintentionally creates a benefit for an unrelated party. On the other hand, negative
externalities, also known as external costs, occur when an individual or a company, for
example, creates a cost that is imposed on an unrelated party.
One example of this is a company producing pollution in the process of
producing a product, which as a result, negatively impacts people’s health, who had no
role in producing the pollution. This example of market failure is illustrated in an article
published by NPR, where the author discusses the major problem of pollution in the US,
and the EPA’s attempt to combat this by setting stricter limits of allowable PM2.5 levels.
Pollution is a negative externality because big contributors of pollution are large
industries processes, like “agriculture, and industrial processes” (Borunda), while those
affected are citizens, who did not contribute directly to the pollution. This causes market
failure as the external cost of pollution is not taken into account into the overall market.
This means the market equilibrium does not reach the efficient outcome and fails to be
socially efficient, as it does not maximize total surplus.
Market failure can be represented graphically. With negative externalities, a new
social marginal cost curve is created as a result of the negative externality. The social
marginal cost curve in this case would be the producers marginal cost, which is the
original supply curve, plus the external marginal cost. This is shifted to the left of the
original supply curve, while the demand curve remains unchanged. This means that the
efficient quantity demanded is lower than the original market quantity, which causes a
deadweight loss, or negative total surplus. Additionally, this means that the efficient
price is higher than the price of the market. Society’s total net gain is maximized where
the social marginal benefit curve interests the social marginal cost curve, which is where
the new efficient equilibrium is. The overall positive surplus is however lower than the
total surplus before.
The government can help fix the market failure in two ways: engaging with the
externality, or engaging with the market of the good. For engaging with the externality of
pollution, the government can create emission taxes, also called Pigouvian T axes,
which creates a tax based on the amount of pollution created. For the good, the
government can create technology standards, for electricity for example, which creates
pollution, which would overall help to decrease the amount of pollution produced.
I hope this letter gave you a better understanding of how market failure works.

Subject: Understanding Market Failure: A Recent Example
The next topic in our economics class is market failure and I am writing to explain it to
you to help build my own understanding. Market failure is when the allocation of goods and
services in a free market is not efficient. Essentially this means that the free market fails to
produce the optimal outcome for society as a whole and the total surplus is not maximized. One
could perform a marginal analysis of a market failure by subtracting the total surplus of the
market outcome from the efficient outcome. Often this occurs when the failure creates an
externality. A positive externality is when there is an uncompensated benefit and a negative
externality is when there is an uncompensated cost on a third party. Market failures can be
caused by externalities, imperfect competition, information asymmetry, and public goods.
The best way of understanding a market failure is by learning to identify them. There are
many instances of market failure in the daily news. I just came across an article in the New York
Times, that talks about the rise of microplastics in the oceans, the food we eat, and the water we
drink. At first glance, this may not seem like it relates directly to market failure. However, the
article describes a form of pollution which is a negative externality. The many companies that
produce plastic products all contribute to plastic pollution. This pollution is uncompensated costs
that companies don’t have to pay for. The rest of society must suffer from microplastics in their
food and their organs due to the production of the plastic goods.
T o better understand the situation let's say that a company is producing plastic water
bottles. The company pays for the labor, materials, and transportation for producing the water
bottle. However, there is a marginal social cost that doesn’t account for the environmental
damages caused by the disposal of the water bottle. When consumers buy plastic products they
use plastic but also do not consider the environmental impact. Now that there is so much plastic
in the environment the cost of clean-up efforts falls onto the whole society. Even those who do
not consume plastic products must bear this cost.
In an efficient market, the producers and consumers would pay for these costs. For the
consumers and producers to pay these costs the government would have to intervene by
placing taxes and quotas on plastic products or by enforcing environmental standards on
businesses.
This is just one example of market failure but it shows how the pursuit of profit does not
always lead to an efficient outcome. Policymakers and economists must analyze these

To: My Friend 
Subject: Market Failure 

	I wish you and your family well through these hard times and hope this email will provide you with a better understanding of market failure. 
Market failure occurs when a market is unable to reach its efficient outcome without any government intervention. There are several types of market failure, including common resources, public goods, externalities, and artificially scarce goods. To further expand upon this concept, I will center my explanation around externalities, which are side effects exterior to the production and consumption of goods that impact third parties. There are two kinds of externalities: positive and negative. A negative externality is an uncompensated cost that unintentionally affects an outside party. This cost, combined with all private costs borne by producers, characterizes the social marginal cost, or total cost to society that arises from one additional unit of production. A positive externality is the opposite of a negative externality. It is an uncompensated benefit that affects an outside party in a way that the market does not consider. In the same way, the social marginal benefit contrasts with the social marginal cost. It is the combination of the benefits enjoyed by consumers, and the external benefits accrued to a third party. The market is always working towards an efficient standing; it is always trying to maximize its total surplus. However, external marginal costs and benefits limit this endeavor, causing the government to intervene by imposing a tax, subsidy, or regulation. The effects that these exterior costs and benefits can have on the market, and society as a whole, emphasize the profound nature of externalities. 
A real-world example of a market failure can be found in the article “Nearly Half the States Sue E.P.A Over New Limits on Deadly Production” by the New York Times. This piece expands upon the current dispute between the Environmental Protection Agency and the Republican Attorneys General over the EPA’s decision to lower annual limits on fine particulate matter production. These tiny particles are a form of air pollution that “can penetrate the lungs and bloodstream, increasing the risk of heart disease, asthma, and low birth rates”(CITE). The previous market outcome, or market efficiency, stood at 12 micrograms per cubic meter of air, but after the EPA released its decision, the efficient outcome now stands at 9 micrograms. In this case, the market failure of focus is air pollution. The production of fine particulate matter particles, arising from power plants, is a negative externality as it unintentionally imposes health costs on surrounding environments. Because producers of power do not bear these societal costs, they have had no incentive to reduce the production of pollution particles to socially optimal levels; all social costs have been greater than private costs, creating a new market efficiency problem. This incited the EPA to establish a lower environmental standard, and thus, regulate the market. 
	Hopefully, I was able to clarify the idea of a market failure through this example.  
Best, 
Your Friend

Dear friend:
I wish you well. We have recently learned about the concept of ‘Market Failure’. The word describes a situation when the market equilibrium is no longer the most efficient. The cause of the market failure can vary from externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. I will focus on externality for the example. This means that while the producer and consumer of one market is trading goods, a third party is being affected by the actions. There can be positive and negative externalities.
The example I chose for you is from the new article titled: “North Carolina ‘Forever Chemical’ Plant Violates Human Rights, U.N. Panel Says” . In the article, the reporter discussed how the repeated dumping of contaminated wastewater by a chemical plant on the Cape Fear River caused the water to be unsafe to drink for 100 miles. (Tabuchi, 2024) “We still have residents in our region who do not have access to clean, safe drinking water,” said Emily Donovan, co-founder of Clean Cape Fear(Tabuchi, 2024). Going back to the structure that I mentioned earlier, in this case, the citizens of the nearby area became the third party, suffering due to the negative externality of the factory. They were not involved in the cost that they need to face which is cleaning up the water in order to regain access to clean water again.
Looking at the externality on the graph, a new line called social marginal cost was created above the X-axis under the original consumer and producer surplus with the equilibrium. We call the area between the social marginal cost and the x-axis the total external cost. While considering the total society surplus, we need to take into account the unwanted damage the market has done. In the article, this comes in the government imposing a pollution tax for the chemical plant. In order to visualize and calculate the society surplus better, we need to move the social marginal cost line above the supply line since it is a negative externality created by the producers. While it could seem that the total surplus of the producers is lower because of this, it only represents the society surplus and thus doesn’t mean a decrease in producer or consumer surplus. The previously mentioned inefficiency comes when we look at the graph of the market equilibrium price. Due to the additional external cost, a triangle above the equilibrium becomes the deadweight loss thus indicating that the market isn’t functioning at the maximum efficiency at the equilibrium. To calculate the society surplus, we need to subtract the deadweight loss from everything else. Right next to the deadweight loss triangle is the new intersection between the social marginal cost line and the unchanged demand line. At that line, no deadweight loss is seen which means it becomes the new efficiency point considering externality effects.
Sincerely,

Dear Classmate,

To give you an update on what you missed, I will offer both an overview of market failure and an example of this from an article I recently read.

 Market failure occurs when the market does not reach the efficient outcome even if it’s in equilibrium, assuming that there is no intervention (Dudley). More precisely, this is a situation in which total surplus is not maximized due to any of the following: government intervention, an externality, or even the types of good. 

To present a deeper dive into one of these, externalities are a common catalyst of market failure within the environment. For example, in the New York Times article attached below, Catrin Einhorn shows how the shift to alternative solar energy has actually caused a negative externality; since clean solar energy takes up so much space in farms, the surrounding wildlife has been hurt by this which is the root of the negative externality (Einhorn). Since the harm to wildlife has not been taken into account by the solar energy market, it is actually over supplied; the high external cost is not factored in by the producers, and therefore the costs are actually higher than the producers think. 

When creating the supply and demand graph that includes the external cost, we can use the social marginal cost, rather than the private marginal cost (typical supply graph), that includes both the private marginal cost and the external cost that society pays by producing one additional unit of that product. To relate this back to our example in the article, the private marginal cost would be the supply schedule of solar farm producers. When you add the fact that wildlife is being harmed, the external cost that society pays for an additional solar farm is actually higher than the supplier realizes. Because of this, the social marginal cost is higher than the private marginal cost. However, a negative externality is commonly present in which the producer fails to realize that their production is causing harm, so the market still operates at the equilibrium of where private marginal cost and private marginal benefit intersect. This leads to the deadweight loss in the market because the efficient price is where social marginal cost equals the social marginal benefit since total surplus would be maximized. 

As a result of  market failure, there are ways to work towards efficiency. For example, government standards, taxes, production quotas, and permits may all be required in order to account for the externality. In the case of the solar panels’ harm to wildlife, Einhorn mentions how producers are starting to notice that change is necessary. They may have to renovate the fencing to protect the wildlife, which would cost more money to the producer, inching closer to the social marginal cost. In the future, producers of solar farms will have to account for the tradeoff of wildlife and energy, but investors and governments may look to increase regulations to account for the externality (Einhorn).

I hope this helped!

Best,
Your Friend

Dear friend,

Market failure occurs when, absent any government involvement, the market fails to reach the efficient outcome. In turn, the market is also failing to maximize total surplus and creates deadweight loss. Thus, society is not benefiting as much as it could be. 
The several factors that can lead to market failure are common resources, public goods, artificially scarce goods, and externalities. Externalities occur when a third party, who has no control or choice, is impacted by the decisions made in a market. There are two types of externalities: negative and positive. Positive externalities are benefits that an individual or firm confers on others without receiving compensation, whereas negative externalities are uncompensated costs, also known as external costs, that an individual or firm imposes on others. With negative externalities, the third party is being harmed. 
Since producers fail to recognize the external cost, the supply curve solely represents the price it takes for them to produce a good. Thus, the supply curve represents the producer’s marginal cost. To represent the producer’s marginal cost and the external cost, or the external marginal cost, a third curve is formed. This curve, which is in addition to the traditional supply and demand curve, is known as the social marginal cost curve. For a market to operate at the efficient outcome with a negative externality, it should be operating at the point that the demand curve intersects the social marginal cost curve. 
In the United States, the energy sector is facing significant challenges as it confronts the need to reduce air pollution, specifically from fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This pollution, a byproduct of burning fossil fuels, is contributing to serious environmental and health issues, including respiratory problems and heart disease. Despite the clear negative externality of PM2.5 emissions, the industry has been slow to adapt to cleaner technologies, leading to overproduction of pollution and an inefficient market outcome, characterized by significant deadweight loss.
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is stepping in to correct this market failure by proposing stricter limits on PM2.5 emissions. However, instead of directly addressing the externality through mechanisms like emissions trading or taxes, the proposed regulations focus on setting specific performance standards for emissions reductions. This approach has sparked opposition from within the industry, which argues that the new standards will impose heavy costs and could lead to job losses, particularly in manufacturing sectors that are already under economic pressure.
A potentially more efficient solution could involve the implementation of a market-based mechanism, such as a cap-and-trade system for PM2.5 emissions. This would directly target the pollution externality by creating a financial incentive for companies to reduce emissions, aligning the private cost of pollution with its social cost. Such a system could mitigate the deadweight loss by encouraging innovation and adaptation in the sector, ultimately leading to a reduction in PM2.5 emissions without imposing undue economic burdens on the industry.

I hope this helped!
Best,
Your friend

Dear friend, 
I hope all is well at home– sending my best wishes! 
For an overview, market failure describes an inefficient allocation of goods because it does not account for an external cost or benefit in the decision-making process: the market equilibrium is not equal to the efficient price and quantity. For example, a private marginal cost, accounting for these external conditions, becomes the social marginal cost curve. Because the private marginal benefit curve remains the same, the shift provides a new point that gives the efficient price and quantity for the given good. If the cost in this scenario were on an unrelated third-party, it would be considered a negative externality where there the market activity is too high. Vice-versa, the market activity is too low and is considered a positive externality. 
In addition to the externalities stated above, the type of goods being demanded can also determine the potential for a market failure. The characteristics, excludability and rivalry in consumption, dictate the category of the good (Dudley, 5). Excludability is if the consumption of the good is determined by an enforceable payment; rivalry in consumption is if one’s utilization impedes another’s ability to consume the same good. Private goods (excludable and rival in consumption) are the only category capable of achieving market efficiency without government intervention. Artificially scarce goods (excludable and nonrival in consumption), common resources (non-excludable and rival in consumption), and public goods (excludable and nonrival in consumption) are all designated as market failures and need the government to place an artificially cost to produce an efficient outcome. 
The New York Times article– “Many Laws to Protect Sharks Have Backfired, Researcher Find”– shows the consequences of a common resource market failure today. In the late 1900s, countries enforced legislation in an attempt to prevent shark finning (a practice of removing the fins and discarding the carcasses into the water). These new laws forced fishers to land the fish whole. Unexpectedly, this led to an increase in demand for shark meat, resulting in further species endangerment due to the increasing consequence disregardment. 
As a common resource (non-excludable and rival in consumption), there is no payment associated with landing a shark but catching it prevents others from consuming that same shark. Fishers tend to land as many individuals as possible because there is no guarantee the population will exist tomorrow. As a result, the social marginal cost is greater than the private marginal cost– the current market equilibrium is greater than efficiency (Dudley, 11). 
This results in “a tragedy of the commons” scenario– the overexploitation of a common resource threatens extinction for said population. The approaches of government intervention in the form of tradable licenses for access to the sharks would be most effective (Dudley, 12). Property rights or Pigouvian taxes could also be established, but there would likely be more diversity among these because of the different nations creating legislation. 
I hope this helps with understanding the concept of market failures. Please let me know if there is anything else I can help with!

I understand that you have been struggling with the concept of market failure. A recent concept that has been talked about is efficiency in the market: When total surplus is completely maximized this is an efficient market. However, when total surplus is not maximized we experience market failure, because when something is preventing a market from being in equilibrium, this is inefficient, thus it is a market failure. Some examples you most likely understand are taxes and quotas as they create limits on goods, causing inefficiency, which is a failure in the market. Some newer concepts you might need help with are types of goods and externalities. 
	Types of goods depend on whether the good is excludable and a rival in consumption. Excludable means the producer can charge people for that good and those who do not pay cannot consume the good. A rival in consumption is a good that cannot be consumed by more than one person at the same time. A private good will be both excludable and a rival in consumption, an example of this being food items or anything you need to purchase that only you can consume. Private goods are most efficient when at market equilibrium because consumer surplus and producer surplus are most maximized at equilibrium with a private good.
	These types of goods can all be efficient in the market however many goods create externalities. Externalities are the consequences that a good has on a third party (neither consumers/producers) that create inefficiency in the market, thus externalities cause market failures. There are both positive and negative externalities. Goods that cause pollution or ruin the value of a property are negative externalities because they have an external cost that affects society negatively. Because of this, there is a total external cost that shifts price and quantity, to maximize consumer and producer surpluses, and in this process it creates deadweight loss, resulting in market failure. On the other hand, a positive externality is a benefit to society, so goods that reduce pollution or improve the health of society are examples of positive externalities. This positive externality also results in inefficiency because the total external benefit of this good shifts the price and quantity of the good resulting in less external benefit than what there could be.

To: Friend
From: Econ Student
Subject: Market Failure

Hi Friend, 
   A market failure is when the market fails to reach the efficient outcome even in equilibrium, absent any intervention. This means the market does not maximize total surplus. Market failure can be measured through three steps. First, identity the total surplus at equilibrium. Second, identify the total surplus at the efficient outcome. Efficiency is where the maximum total surplus exists, and total surplus is society’s net gain from the market. Society’s total net gain is maximized where marginal benefit intersects marginal cost, so this intersection represents the efficient outcome. Finally, measure the difference between the efficient outcome and equilibrium outcome, which is the deadweight loss, and the level of market failure.  
  Externalities are an example of market failure. There are two types of externalities: negative and positive. A negative externality is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on an unrelated third party. This third party is not the buyer or seller of the good but is negatively affected through its production or consumption. When a negative externality exists, the market overproduces as it does not account for the external cost, and the efficient quantity will be less than the equilibrium quantity. A positive externality is a benefit an individual or firm confers on the unrelated third party, without any compensation. The third party is positively affected through the production or consumption of the good. When a positive externality exists, the market underproduces as it does not consider the external benefit it is providing and could create more surplus if it considered the benefit. In both cases, market equilibrium fails to account for the externality and does not generate as much total surplus as is possible, so the market is not efficient.  
  An example of a negative externality is pollution caused by petrochemical plants in Texas and Louisiana (“United States”). The plants are owned by corporations like Shell and ExxonMobil and produce chemicals that are sold to domestic and international consumers to create plastics and pesticides. The plants have exceeded air pollution limits, and the air and water pollution the plants create have caused widespread chronic health issues, like lung cancer, in the communities near the plants (“United States”). The average life expectancy is up to 20 years lower in communities closer to the plants than in communities 15 miles further away (“United States”). This is an example of a negative externality. Pollution is an uncompensated cost that the petrochemical companies are imposing on nearby residents. The residents are uninvolved with the production or consumption of chemicals, yet the firms are placing an external cost of pollution and health issues on these communities. The Coase Theorem states that the market may be able to internalize the externality, but only if the transaction costs are sufficiently low, which is rare. However, the government may intervene by engaging with the externality directly, the pollution, or by engaging with associated market for the good, the petrochemical market. The government could implement stricter environmental standards, emissions taxes, or tradable emissions permits to reduce the negative externality. 

Best,
Econ Student

Dear Friend,

concept of market failure, which can be tricky to grasp at first. I'm confident we can clear it up
together.
Market failure occurs when the allocation of goods and services by a free market is inefficient,
leading to an outcome that is not socially optimal. In simpler terms, it's when the market doesn't
work as it should. One common cause of market failure is the existence of externalities, which
are costs or benefits that affect parties who do not choose to incur them.
A recent article from The Washington Post titled "What climate scientists are predicting for the
globe in 2024" discusses predictions made by climate scientists regarding global temperatures in
2024. It points out that factors such as the El Niño climate pattern, record-high ocean
temperatures, and the potential for exceeding 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels
contribute to the scenario.
The market failure highlighted in this article revolves around negative externalities caused by
greenhouse gas emissions. When businesses and individuals engage in economic activities like
burning fossil fuels, they emit greenhouse gasses. These emissions contribute to global warming,
leading to climate change impacts such as rising temperatures, extreme weather events, and sea
level rise. However, the emitters do not accept the costs associated with these impacts; instead,
they are externalized onto society.
For example, the article mentions record-high ocean temperatures, which can devastate marine
ecosystems and coastal communities. These consequences impose significant costs on society in
terms of damage to fisheries, loss of biodiversity, and increased risk of natural disasters. Yet,
those responsible for greenhouse gas emissions do not directly bear these costs, creating a market
failure situation where the actual social cost of carbon emissions is not reflected in the market
price of fossil fuels.
In economic terms, the market for fossil fuels fails to internalize the total costs of production and
consumption, leading to overconsumption and overproduction of these goods. As a result, we see
a misallocation of resources, with too much emphasis on activities that generate greenhouse gas
emissions and too little attention paid to cleaner, renewable alternatives.
Therefore, this article demonstrates how market failure, particularly in the form of negative
externalities, leads to inefficient outcomes and the exacerbation of climate change.
Understanding this concept is crucial as it helps us recognize when and why markets don't
operate optimally, prompting the need for government intervention or policy measures to correct

Subject: Explaining Market Failure
Hey Friend,
I know you have been struggling with the concept of Market Failure, so I just wanted to help out
a bit.
First, a market failure can be defined as an inefficient distribution of goods and services in a
market with no outside government intervention (Drury). In class, we learned of the following
four different market failures: Externalities, Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially
Scarce Goods.
To better understand market failure, I included an article that represents one of the market
failures we learned in class-—externalities. There are two types of externalities—positive and
negative. A positive externality is a benefit that an individual or corporation grants to others,
such as a flu vaccine, making those without the vaccine less susceptible to contracting the flu. A
negative externality is an uncompensated cost that an individual or corporation places on others,
such as the effects of a factory’s pollution on neighboring town residents (Dudley).
In the Wall Street Journal article, “If Y ou’re Buying a Home Near a Nightmare Neighbor, Y ou
Might Want to Think Again”, various real estate agents recount the times neighbors made the
sale of the properties difficult by interrupting showings, screaming at potential buyers, etc.
Specifically, in the article, one agent recounts that even after managing to sell a property, the
neighbor would turn off the utilities of the buyer, causing countless lawsuits between the
previous owner for not disclosing the adverse conditions of the living by the neighbor. If the
previous owner had mentioned these conditions, the property would not have been sold at the
price it was valued in the market or as quickly. Another agent recounts a neighbor taping notes to
the property's front doors, spewing lies such as “rats and bugs” and “ Area under surveillance".
The neighbor's actions kept the property longer on the market and most likely lowered the value.
The market failure within the article is the negative externality the “nightmare neighbor” creates
for the property's sale. In the case of “nightmare neighbors”, their behavior may create various
costs or inconveniences for neighboring households, which they did not willingly accept, such as
the neighbor turning off the water meter or the other lying about the property’s conditions.
Although the properties themselves pose no apparent problems, the neighbor can be considered
an uncompensated cost. As I mentioned earlier, an uncompensated cost is a key feature of
negative externalities.

Dear Friend,
Based on a news article I recently read titled, "Indonesia’s Vote: Three Takeaways for Climate Change," I’m better able to explain the idea of market failure. To start, let me give you the bare definition followed by a detailed description through the use of this news article combined with my current economic knowledge. A market failure is when a market is in equilibrium, however, the total surplus isn’t maximized, making it an inefficient market/market failure. A market failure can occur from different issues, but this article focuses on a market failure through a negative externality: a negative impact to a third party (not a producer or consumer), representing a cost to society causing the market to fail.
For some context about this article, President of Indonesia Prabowo Subianto has vowed to transition to a more environmentally friendly state, by starting to build EV factories, stimulating the market for nickel mining. Although this change in the long term will cause Indonesia to be more climate-friendly, in the short term, its carbon footprint will skyrocket. Moreover, the mining of nickel and the creation of EV factories have caused a mass output of carbon, which has “violated the rights of Indigenous communities and caused water and air pollution”.
The nickel mining market and EV factory building market impact a third party, which are the communities impacted by pollution, by polluting the air they breathe and water they drink. Because this is a negative impact to a third party, it is a cost that isn’t accounted for within Indonesian society within the market of these goods; To be accounted for, this external cost is added to the cost to supply the goods in the respective markets. But, in reality this doesn’t happen: people will consume/produce without the impact in mind causing the market equilibrium to be at a quantity in which there is too much.

More specifically, Indonesia is building too many factories and consuming more nickel than it should be. Now we call this a market failure because the total surplus in the current equilibrium is less than the total surplus for the efficient quantity of these markets, which is represented by the quantity of transactions if the cost to society were accounted for (it would be less because people understand the impacts of pollution therefore consuming less). For equilibrium quantity, the total surplus is measured by the consumer and minus the unaccounted for cost to society. Next, the efficient quantity is just measured by consumer/producer surplus. Even though there is a slight consumer/producer loss at efficiency (because of lower transactions), the cost of society in equilibrium outweighs this, making total surplus lower in equilibrium than at the efficient quantity. Overall, because the market for EV factories/nickel mining externally impacts society negatively through pollution, its total surplus at equilibrium isn’t maximized: these markets are inefficient and are considered a failure. I hope this better helps you understand the idea of market failure given this specific type.
