Dear Friend,
Market failure occurs when the allocation of goods/services by a market is not efficient at
the market equilibrium, leading to deadweight loss. This can result from externalities, which are
when the actions of consumers and producers have unintended consequences on society that are
not reflected in market prices. Additionally, market failures occur through goods that differ from
private goods. Excludable means it's possible to prevent people from benefiting unless they pay,
while rival means the consumption by one individual diminishes the quantity available. Private
goods are both excludable and rival, making them straightforward to allocate. Other types of
goods such as public goods (national defense) are non-excludable and non-rivalrous, leading to
underproduction; common resources (fish stocks) are rivalrous but non-excludable, leading to
overuse; and artificially scarce goods (streaming services) are excludable but non-rivalrous,
leading to underconsumption.
Negative externalities include an overgrown front yard diminishing the value of nearby
properties, or the pollution resulting from electricity production and consumption leading to acid
rain in areas not directly involved in the transaction. The article “How air pollution prevents
pollinators from finding their flowers” specifically highlights how “air pollution alters the sweet
smell of flowers and disrupts the cues nocturnal pollinators use to find nectar” (Grandoni 2004).
As consumers and producers in the electricity market operate, they fail to account for the
external cost of their emissions, which leads to decreased pollination efficiency. This negative
externality impacts society by reducing the reproductive success of plants and the survival of
pollinator species, thereby affecting agricultural productivity and ecosystem health through
reduced biodiversity, decline in crop yields, and economic losses for pollination dependent
industries. As the cost of the negative externality is not included in the cost of producing and
consuming electricity, the supply curve does not accurately reflect the true social marginal-cost
of production. Consequently, the market equilibrium is set at producers marginal-cost and the
equilibrium is above efficiency, causing deadweight loss due to overproduction.
To internalize the externality, several strategies can be employed. The Coase Theorem
suggests bringing all affected parties together to negotiate. However, high transaction costs
associated with pollution make it impossible to gather all parties and the government must step
in. Environmental Standards allow the government to directly implement rules. A ban on
pollution emissions regulates the externality, whereas a ban on electricity production regulates
the market. Pigouvian Taxes offer an alternative approach by imposing a tax that equals the cost
of the externality, either on the emission of pollutants (taxing an amount of pollution released) or
on the production side (taxing an amount of energy produced). Tradable Emission Quotas on the
externality allow the government to issue a fixed number of permits to allow limited quantities of
emissions. Similarly, Production Quotas on the market allow the government to limit the
production of electricity to a certain quantity. Regardless, the externality must be internalized to
reflect the true cost of pollution, thereby aligning the market to the efficient outcome and
ensuring no detrimental effects associated with agriculture/pollination.

by the manufacturers. A negative externality is where an uninvolved party bears unintended costs
of a market. In this case the health risks of the gas present a negative externality on the nearby
population.
You already know what supply and demand curves look like. The social marginal cost is
how you represent negative externalities in the supply and demand model. While the supply
curve only considers the costs to the producer, the social marginal cost considers the external
costs; in this case the negative health effects of using the gas. Because of this, the social marginal
cost curve will be offset above the supply curve. In this model, the equilibrium point is the same
as what it’s always been, but the efficient outcome is actually at the intersection of the demand
and social marginal cost curves. This means that the efficient outcome is at a lower quantity and
higher price than the where the equilibrium point lies. A disparity between the efficient and
equilibrium point is what defines market failure.

released into the local environment. This has a negative effect on local populations, and this
damage has an economic cost. Because this cost is not accounted for by anyone involved in the
market, it is considered to be a negative externality. If this cost is accounted for, then the most
efficient outcome is at a higher price and lower quantity than where the equilibrium is. This is

Subject: Examining Market Failures Through the Lens of Nature: A Positive Externality
Dear: Friend in Economics 101
From: Fellow Economics 101 Student
Date: March 26, 2024
A market failure occurs when a free market inefficiently distributes goods and services.
Thus far, Dr. Dudley has covered how some types of goods and externalities—activities that
affect a third party unrelated to their production or consumption—prevent efficient market
allocation.
To the first point, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods all result
in market failures. Common resources, such as clean water, are costless but limited in quantity,
rendering them prone to over-consumption. Public goods, like snow removal, are free, and more
than one person can consume the same unit of a good at the same time, which disincentivizes the
private market from providing these goods because they cannot profit from doing so. Artificially
scarce resources, including cable television, come with an initial cost, but once created, an
infinite number of people can consume them simultaneously. These products should be
complementary because suppliers face no marginal cost in providing access to another person.
However, sellers purposefully charge a price above the efficient quantity to maximize their profit
at the expense of making artificially scarce goods under-consumed by society.
To the second point, externalities cause market failure through excess consumption or
insufficient usage. Negative externalities, such as pollution, lead to over-consumption because
polluters do not bear the cost of compromising the health of people uninvolved in their
production. Positive externalities, like environmental organizations, fall subject to under-
consumption because no one reimburses them for their work. The New York Times article
“Nature Has Value. Could We Literally Invest in It?” demonstrates this cycle by examining the
ways in which nature behaves as a positive externality (Depillis 1).
Reporter Lydia Depillis shares the recent push from a group of progressive investors to
require companies to assign a specific market value to nature. The investors argue that forests’
advantages–namely climate regulation and storage of carbon dioxide emissions– extend to all
members of society rather than just the leading NGOs supporting their preservation (Depillis 2).
In accordance with all positive externalities, these climate change organizations operate without
compensation for their good deeds and thus suffer from inefficiently low production, ultimately
disturbing the market equilibrium. The government generally intervenes to rectify externalities by
taxing production that harms others or subsidizing services that generate spillover benefits. In this
case, legislators could enforce the investors’ proposition to establish a price polluters must pay to
offset their environmental damage or fund conservation groups. An objective value for nature and
government subsidies can work in tandem to restore market equilibrium and correct this market
failure [412].

equilibrium, and comparing it to the total surplus of the efficient quantity, the difference between
the two being deadweight loss.
In a Wall Street Journal article titled “Sneaky Drivers Dodging Toll Cameras Cost
Authorities Millions”, Scott Calvert explores how some drivers are avoiding paying toll fees for
highways. While roads may normally be seen as a public good, since toll roads are both
excludable (toll booth gates) and rivalrous (more cars means more traffic and slower speed)
they therefore are private. One example mentioned in the article is that the New York City MTA
lost $21 million dollars to people avoiding paying tolls by hiding their license plates so they can’t
be fined. This creates market failure because some consumers are not paying for their fair
share of the toll roads, and while you might not think it harms anyone, it does. The New York
City MTA said that only 1.5% of all toll transactions were unbillable, yet that meant that over $20
million dollars was,
“money unavailable for electric buses and needed upgrades”
. As a private
good, if people enjoy toll ways without paying, the producer does not get compensated for
creating the good taking away from the total surplus. This imposes a cost on others that is not
compensated for, which we learned is called a negative externality. also known as an external
cost, since the people who avoid paying the toll are not factored into the price. Because of this,
toll roads fail to fully be a private good, and thus will be inefficient.

studies.

Dear Friend,
	I hope all is going well with you as you’ve been away from class. While you’ve been gone, we’ve covered the overarching concept of market failure in Econ 101. If you could just take a few minutes and give this letter as well as the attached article a read, I think I will be able to fill in most of the gaps for you. 
The first thing to know about market failure is that the efficient quantity will not be the same as the equilibrium quantity. The reason behind this is because at equilibrium in a market containing a market failure, total surplus is not being maximized. Market failures can occur in a few different situations. These include markets that pertain to any good that is not a private good, or any good with a positive or negative externality associated with it. I would like to take a little time and expand on how a negative externality ultimately causes a market failure. 
First, it's important for me to mention that a negative externality is a cost that is experienced by someone not involved in the market. In an article by the New York Times, author Max Bearak talks about a situation where the US is going to start sending gas to a port in Mexico in order to sell gas to Asia more efficiently. This strategy comes with the negative externality of harming the environment, an entity that is not involved in the gasoline market. In this particular case, the environment could be negatively affected in a few different ways, namely potential pipeline leaks as well as increased shipping traffic in the Gulf of California. 
To figure out why a negative externality classifies as a market failure, it is important to understand that the efficient outcome of a market is where the social marginal cost is equal to the social marginal benefit. In the case of a negative externality, the social marginal benefit is the same as the demand, while the social marginal cost curve has the same slope as the supply curve, but is shifted to the left. Therefore the intersection of the social marginal cost and social marginal benefit will occur at a lower quantity than the equilibrium quantity. 
To correct for a negative externality, there are a few common strategies that are generally effective. The government can impose a tax on either the good or on the amount of pollution. A tax on the good can be easier to measure, but is not always fair to people who can produce the good at a lower rate of pollution. On the other hand, a tax on the quantity of pollution can be technically hard or even impossible to accurately measure in some cases. Another common strategy is for the government to put a quota on either the good or the pollution, which has a very similar effect to that of a tax.
I hope that after reading this you have gained a better understanding of market failure.
Sincerely,
Your Friend

Dear friend,
A perfectly efficient market would be one in which all surplus is maximized.
However, this wouldn’t guarantee that everyone receives their best possible outcome, or
even receives all they need to survive. Thus, we have “market failures,” or instances in
which markets (without outside or government intervention) fail to be efficient.
A real life situation that demonstrates market failure can be found in Andreoni
Manuela’s “Many Laws to Protect Sharks Have Backfired, Researchers Find,” an article
he wrote for The New York Times. The article details the policies implemented by over
70% of countries regarding protecting sharks from “finning,” or the killing of sharks for
their fin-meat. The article presents the policies to show how they haven’t helped curb
the killing of sharks, and have been so ineffective that many species have gone
endangered.
This type of market failure can be labeled “common resource.” T o the fisherman,
and to the people in general, the sharks are a non-excludable resource, meaning that
there is no barrier and no price stopping anyone from consuming the sea’s sharks.
Furthermore, the sharks would be considered “rival in consumption” goods, meaning the
shark is a good for which the same unit cannot be consumed by more than one person
at the same time. Once a shark is hunted, gutted, and eaten, and cannot be consumed
by anyone else. The way these two characteristics of the shark as a good play off one
another can explain why the shark market is in market failure. Since sharks are rival in
consumption (and aren’t an unlimited resource), not everyone can share the same
shark. But since sharks are non-excludable, everyone has an equal right to access the
same shark deposits. The limited nature of the shark as a good gives it value )in trade
as well as being a source of food), and the non-excludability of access to sharks meant
some would over-farm the sharks for its value. The reason this continued to happen and
sharks became further endangered over time, even with policies being implemented, is
that the policies didn’t do enough. Many policies were aimed at making sharks a “more”
excludable resource, such as forcing hunters do catch them whole, but policies like this
weren’t enough–shark value was high enough and the barrier-to-access-sharks low
enough that too few people were excluded and sharks continued to be overfished.
In other common resource market failure cases, many show a similar pattern of
inefficiency to this one–a population has free access to a resource of rivalrous value,
many use this free access to hoard as much of the good as possible (either to sustain
themselves or to collect capital), until the resource has been overconsumed, there is
little-to-no supply and overwhelming demand, and the market has failed.
Works Cited
Andreoni, Manuela. “Many Laws to Protect Sharks Have Backfired, Researchers
Find.” The New York Times, The New York Times, 11 Jan. 2024,
www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/climate/shark-fins-overfishing.html.

desires. There are various reasons for market failure, and one of them is the presence of
externalities, which are costs or benefits that affect third parties not directly involved in the
economic activity.

concept from our Econ 101 class that resonates with this situation is the idea of public goods.
Public goods are non-excludable and non-rivalrous, meaning that once they are provided,
everyone can benefit from them, and one person's consumption of the good does not diminish its
availability to others.
Journalism can be considered a public good. Think about it – when a news outlet publishes a
story, anyone can access and benefit from that information, regardless of whether they
contributed financially. This creates a free-rider problem, where individuals have an incentive to
consume the good without paying for it. As a result, the market fails to provide the optimal
quantity of journalism because it's difficult for news organizations to capture the full value of
their product through traditional revenue streams like subscriptions and advertising.

investigative reporting and holding powerful entities accountable. However, the benefits of such
reporting extend beyond those who directly consume the news—society benefits from a
well-informed citizenry and a watchdog press that keeps institutions in check. Unfortunately, the
market often undervalues these positive externalities, leading to underinvestment in journalism.

lens of public goods and externalities. The market struggles to efficiently allocate resources to
produce journalism because of the inherent nature of news as a public good and the difficulty in
capturing the full societal benefits of quality reporting.

Dear Friend,
To start, it is important to know that market failure occurs when the market on its own fails to be efficient. This means that without any other interventions, the market still cannot reach efficiency. Furthermore, there are various reasons and structural failures which explain why the market equilibrium is not efficient when the market is in failure. One example of a cause of market failure is the concept of externalities. Externalities are positive or negative impacts on parties who are unaffiliated with the decision-making process. Negative externalities indicate effects which have impacted the third parties negatively, while positive externalities indicate the opposite.
I suggest reading the article “Secondhand smoke linked to rise in some dogs’ cancer risk” by Erin Blakemore to further cement your understanding of externalities and connect this concept to market failure. The real-world example of a negative externality in this article is sure to augment your learning. In this example, the market responsible for the market failure is the cigarette market (Blakemore, E.). Additionally, the market experiencing market failure is the canine cancer treatment/health market (Blakemore, E.). To reiterate, this particular market failure is classified as a negative market externality. Dogs are uninvolved in smoking yet being negatively impacted by the situation of secondhand smoke (Blakemore, E.).
The concept of positive and negative externalities is incredibly important to grasp in the context of market failure. However, there are other causes of said failure as well. Common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods are each intrinsically connected to market failure. Common resources are nonexcludable and rival goods/services. This means that nobody can be kept from the goods/services by being required to pay, for example. However, there are limited spaces. Public goods are both nonexcludable and nonrival. This means that there are no barriers to entry such as having to pay for admission, and there is also space for everyone. Lastly, artificially scarce goods are excludable and nonrival. This means that while there are barriers to access such as payment requirements, there is space for all. Common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods are all connected to market failure through various mechanisms, primarily due to the presence of externalities and the inability of markets to efficiently allocate resources or distribute goods/services evenly.
In each case, market failure occurs because traditional market mechanisms fail to allocate resources efficiently. Externalities, whether in the form of common resources, public goods, or artificially scarce goods, lead to outcomes that are suboptimal for society. As a result, alternative mechanisms may be necessary to address said failures and achieve a more efficient allocation of resources. Market failure describes an economic situation in which the allocation of resources in a market is not efficient. In a perfectly competitive market, the equilibrium price and quantity of a good is determined by the convergence of traditional supply and demand. This creates an equilibrium that satisfies the general social welfare. Market failures are created when this equilibrium is disrupted, which can be done through a couple different factors. 
One factor that creates market failure is externalities, in which consumption of a market’s products causes harm to a third party. One example of this comes from pollution, which I’ll explore with a real-world example later. Another factor is public goods, which are goods that are accessible to the public and can’t have their consumption limited. Something like national security is funded with taxes by citizens and serves to benefit everyone, but there is no way to prohibit those who don’t pay taxes from also receiving the protections of national security. This means that the government usually has to pay for these kinds of services, leaving the success of this market up to them. There are also common goods, which are similar to public goods in the fact that no one can be prohibited from their consumption. Where they differ is that they rival in consumption, meaning that no more than one person can consume a unit of this good at a time. Examples of this include clean water, because anyone can access it at any time. The final form of market failure comes with artificially scarce goods. These are goods like digitally streamed music, which are artificially limited in their consumption. Producers limit its consumption only to paying customers, when distributing additional units actually comes at no cost to the producer.

Hello friend, 
I hope that everything is well with you! I recently learned something interesting in my Introduction to Economics class, and I thought you would be interested in hearing more about it. Recently we have been discussing this idea of market failure and how we are able to see it in the real-world. In general, it is important to understand market failure to see how markets can sometimes fall short in efficiently allocating resources. 
To put it in simpler terms, market failure happens when the allocation of goods in a free market is not efficient, then resulting in a misallocation of resources. There are many reasons why this can happen and there are also many different types of market failures including, externalities, common resources, public goods, or artificially scarce goods. 
A great example of a type of market failure is one I found in a recent article published in The New York Times titled, “Can Europe Save Forests Without Killing Jobs in Malaysia?" The article mainly discusses the ongoing conflict between environmental conservation efforts and economic interests, with a focus on the palm oil industry in Malaysia. 
In this particular case, the market failure is defined as a negative externality associated with palm oil production. An externality is a misallocation of resources leading to market failure, but a negative externality is when one party makes conditions worse for a third party not associated with the original party. In simpler terms, it is when one party has to suffer an indirect cost for the actions of another party. In this case, The article states, "Palm oil production leads to deforestation, habitat destruction, and environmental degradation, imposing costs on society that are not reflected in the market price of palm oil.” (Cohen) These environmental impacts are external to the market transaction between producers and consumers of palm oil, leading to overproduction and overconsumption relative to what would be socially optimal. 
On top of all of that, the European Union’s ban on imports linked with deforestation increases this market’s failure. The use of the ban is to protect forests and combat climate change, but it also challenges the communities of small farmers in Southeast Asia, since they have a heavy reliance on the palm oil industry for income. As stated, “The ban restricts the market for palm oil produced in Malaysia and Indonesia, affecting small farmers who depend on palm oil for their livelihoods." (Cohen) 
Overall, this article illustrates a market failure driven by negative externalities in the palm oil industry. It showcases the complex ethical and economical trade-offs involved in considering environmental issues. I hope this helps you understand the basics of market failure, and how it applies in the real-world. Here’s a link to the article if you want to learn more: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/03/14/business/economy/malaysia-palm-oil-european-union.html
Talk soon!

Subject: Market Failure Clarification – Econ 101
Hello [Friend’s name]
I hope all is well for you despite the unexpected circumstances. I understand that market
failure can be a confusing concept, so I’ll do my best to clarify it alongside using a recent news
article as an example. The term market failure described by Dudley “occurs when the market on
its own fails to be efficient with no outside or government intervention” (Dudley). The market
fails to be efficient because it fails to maximize total surplus due to a misallocation of resources.
Market failures that we have learned in class so far are externalities, common resources, public
goods, and artificially scarce goods. I will explore externalities using an example where the
actions of producers or consumers have consequences for third parties not involved in the
market.
There are two types of externalities: negative and positive. A negative externality results
in an external cost due to an individual or firm imposing an uncompensated cost on others
(Dudley). In a market with a negative externality, the market equilibrium results in too many
units of the good compared to the efficient level (Dudley). However, for positive externalities,
the same reasons instead cause an external benefit, and market equilibrium results in fewer units
of the good compared to the efficient level. The efficient level would be the optimal quantity that
maximizes total surplus, but since it is at market equilibrium, the market fails to be efficient,
therefore a market failure occurs.
To clearly illustrate the concept, I will go into an example of a real-world example of a
market failure. In the article, Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns, it discusses
how the issue of microplastic pollution is becoming a bigger issue due to the increase in plastic
waste, as it is affecting various environments and the human body. The article addresses how
microplastics in recent studies pose potential health risks, such as an increased likelihood of
heart attacks and strokes associated with microplastics in the cardiovascular system. The market
failure in this article would be the production and consumption of plastics. This would be a
negative externality, as the environmental and health costs of microplastic pollution impose
external costs on third parties not reflected in the market. Furthermore, it is a negative externality
as the article addresses “very little of it has been recycled” and “microplastics are everywhere”
(Jacobs). The market fails to recognize the external costs of microplastics, leading to
overconsumption and market equilibrium not being at the socially efficient level. To address this
market failure, the government can intervene. They can impose taxes or regulations on plastic
production to “internalize the external costs” of pollution and ultimately reduce plastic use to the
optimal efficient quantity (Dudley). This may be challenging due to the scale of the issue, but if
the transaction costs of making a deal are low the economy can reach the optimal quantity.

Market failure occurs when the invisible hand of the free market doesn’t lead to the best
outcomes for society as a whole. It’s a bit like a group project where, without clear roles, some
work too hard while others don't contribute their fair share, resulting in a less than ideal outcome.
In economic terms, it can happen in a few different ways:
● Externalities: These are indirect costs or benefits that affect bystanders. For instance, a
factory might pollute a river that local communities rely on, imposing health and
environmental costs not accounted for in the product’s price.
● Public Goods: These are goods that everyone can use freely, like public parks. Since no
one is excluded from using them, the market can struggle to supply them without
government support.
● Common Resources: Similar to public goods but with the added risk of overuse, such as
fishing grounds. They're available to all, leading to depletion as each person takes more
than their sustainable share.
Now, let’s consider the article, "AI Is Ravenous for Energy. Can It Be Satisfied?" It perfectly
illustrates a market failure in the form of negative externalities. The situation is this: AI
technologies require large amounts of electricity, which contributes to global energy demand
pressures and potential environmental damage. These effects are not reflected in the cost of AI
products and services, which means the price doesn't include the true societal cost, in this case,
the environmental impact.

electricity, comparable to adding a new country’s worth of power needs. Despite this, the prices
for AI do not consider the extensive energy required to cool down AI chips or the associated
carbon footprint. This mismatch between the market price and the social cost of AI energy
consumption leads to more AI usage than is socially optimal, which is a classic negative
externality.
In the grand scheme, AI is pushing up the demand for electricity but isn’t paying for its
environmental toll, which could mean more pollution, higher greenhouse gas emissions, and

article explains a type of market failure known as an externality, specifically a negative
externality, where the costs of air pollution impact entities not directly involved in the production
or consumption of the goods causing the pollution (Krugman 123). In this case, the cost is on the
pollinators and the plants, not the industries or individuals emitting the pollutants. The market’s
inability to account for the indirect cost of air pollution on pollination and ecosystems leads to a
suboptimal allocation of resources and potential long-term detriment to biodiversity and

that their actions impose on the environment and agriculture.

Market equilibrium is achieved when supply equals demand at a specific price point,
assuming all costs and benefits are accounted for. With externalities, like air pollution, true costs,
known as external marginal costs, are not included. Therefore, the market price does not reflect
the true cost to society, rendering the market equilibrium inefficient. Pursuing efficiency, such as
with the Coase Theorem, suggests that if the affected parties can negotiate without costs, they
could reach an agreement that mitigates the externality without government intervention
(Dudley). If the pollinators were humans, they could negotiate with polluters to reduce
emissions. However, government intervention is often necessary due to the impracticality of the
negotiations, especially those involving non-human parties, and society’s welfare (Krugman 16).

limits on the amount of pollutants firms can emit. Taxes on emissions, a Pigovian tax, make it
more expensive to pollute and create an incentive to reduce emissions (Dudley). Quotas cap the

costs, forcing them to find ways to reduce their pollution. Tradable NO3 permits could lead

Excludable means that it will cost the consumer a price to consume and rival in consumption means that more than one person cannot consume at the same time. If a good is non-excludable, this means that the supplier can face a free-rider problem, meaning that many consumers will avoid paying to consume it. A good can be a non-rival when there is no change in the marginal cost of the producer to give another person access to it. For example, a Common Resource is excludable and rival in consumption. A Public Good is non-excludable and it is a non-rival in consumption. An example of a Private Good is excludable and is rival in consumption, so only one person can consume the good at a time. Dear fellow economics student,
Market failure arises when the market's distribution of goods is inefficient, causing a decrease in
overall economic well-being. When the drivers of supply and demand don't maximize efficiency,
the results lead to a mismatch where either an excess or deficit of a product occurs. This type of
failure usually happens when private interests are misaligned with the collective well-being of
society and is often the result of externalities – unfavorable costs or favorable benefits that
impact third parties (those not part of the transaction).
In the article, “Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns,” Jacobs highlights how
microplastics are polluting the environment, entering human bodies, and linked to several human
health problems – a direct example of a negative externality. Microplastics have been found not
only between the peaks of mountains and ocean sea floors, but alarmingly in human bodies: in
the lungs, blood, placenta, brain, and even in breast milk. A study published in the New England
Journal of Medicine, conducted on 312 participants, revealed microplastics within human blood
vessel walls. These individuals were 4.5 times more likely to suffer from heart attacks, strokes,
and death (Paolisso, 2024). Even more, microplastics have been linked to brain cancer,
inflammatory bowel disease, and higher risks for complications after a heart attack or stroke. If
lodged in the cardiovascular system, immune cells die three times faster (Vrisekoop, 2023).
Hazardous materials such as polystyrene (commonly found in packaging materials) and nylon (a
prevalent microplastic) harm the development of the lungs and can result in fatality (Melgert,
2023).

health. The harm caused by plastics to ecosystems and human health is not factored into the
economic equation when transactions occur. In an inefficient framework where producers and
consumers engage in a transaction, such as the production and consumption of plastics, neither
party chooses to take on the economic burden of the externalized effects/costs of a plastic life.
The true cost of plastic is not reflected in its market price, leading to overuse and excessive
production of plastic goods. Since there are health and environmental dangers that negatively
affect the health of other individuals, unseen by the individual choosing to buy or sell the plastic
product, market failure is a negative externality.
When there are market failures, governments step in to correct those failures. Subsidizing
alternatives, incidentally, is a perfect approach. An example of subsidization to reduce plastic
usage may include promoting biodegradable materials through tax credits. Offering tax credits to
companies makes it cheaper for businesses to convert to these alternatives, encouraging a
transition from plastic usage to more eco-friendly materials.

benefits; therefore, the market underproduces because market equilibrium is less than the
efficient level, and total surplus is not maximized. By contrast, negative externalities are
uncompensated costs that producers and consumers in a market impose on a third party. Market
failure occurs because the market fails to compensate for these external costs; therefore, the
market overproduces because market equilibrium is greater than the efficient level, and total

Hey Friend,
Market failure is definitely a tough subject, so I am here to help. Market failure
encompasses the idea that a market is failing when it is inefficient on its own – ie. the
government is not involved. In other words, the market is not maximizing its total surplus. Some
examples of market failure are externalities, market power, and types of goods.
Types of goods consist of four categories based on excludability, and if they are rivals in
consumption or not. Excludable means that in order to access a good you must pay for it. A
nonexcludable good is one that can be accessed for free. A rival good is one that cannot be used
while others are using it – for instance your phone – nobody can use your phone while you are. A
nonrival good is one that anyone can use simultaneously. For example the Oscars, anyone can
watch simultaneously. Using these two traits, goods are separated into 4 categories; private
goods (excludable and rival), artificially scarce goods (excludable and nonrival), common
resources (nonexcludable and rival), and public goods (nonexcludable and nonrival).
Market power occurs when a market is not perfectly competitive and there exists an
influence on a price to be higher or lower than equilibrium. A monopoly is an example of market
power.
Last, externalities are when a third party not directly involved in the market is affected. A
positive externality is one that benefits those not involved in a market. Flu shots are an example
of this. When people get flu shots their intention is to not get the flu, but it also lowers the chance
of someone who is not vaccinated contracting the flu, which is a positive externality for those
individuals. When a positive externality exists, it influences the demand curve, causing it to shift
to the right. There exists market failure because the demand of the vaccine decreases due to
lower cases of the flu as a result of those who are vaccinated. This results in a demand for the
vaccine being lower than the efficient number of recipients. A negative externality occurs when a
party imposes a cost/negative outcome on an uninvolved party. Here’s an example:

main ways in which markets are inefficient: market power, externalities, common resources,
public goods, and artificially scarce goods. Market power is when a firm or corporation has the
ability to raise the market price (Ribaudo). Externalities is when actions which are unrelated to
the market at hand have a side effect on the welfare of others. Public goods, common resources,
and private information is related to market failure as the nature of a particular good can make it
unsuitable for efficient allocation by the market (Ross).

market failure works. To sum up the article, the housing market is at an all-time low; individuals
do not want to sell their homes and as a result there is not enough homes being sold to match the
current demand for housing.
The article demonstrates how externalities potentially lead to market failure. Consumers such as
Griffin and Jessica Fisher are affected by a negative externality. The increase in rent is a result of
a lower supply of housing (Friedman). This is a negative externality as a decrease in the supply
of houses is indirectly affected by the current housing market conditions. Moreover, high
mortgage rates, a limited supply of houses, and inflated prices create uncertainty which led to a
decrease in consumer’s confidence when entering and exiting the housing market (Friedman). On
the other hand, a positive externality exists for home builders. Because there is a shortage of
houses on the market, individuals who want to build houses are positively impacted as the high
demand for homes will raise the prices for the houses being built. However, this also negatively
affects consumers as a limited supply of houses and high demand for houses increases home

Externalities a have a dual nature being as they can be positive or negative. A negative externality is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others (external Cost.) Hey friend I heard that you were having some trouble understanding the concept of market failures so I hope this email finds you well. As a baseline definition, a market failure happens when the market doesn’t maximize total surplus or in other words, reach an efficient outcome. This is at the point where the efficiency quantity and price doesn’t necessarily mean the same thing as equilibrium price and quantity. This lack of equality means that there is deadweight loss created before the government gets involved. 
	There are several types of market failures including public goods, artificially scarce goods, and common resources. A market failure occurs when there is an inefficient distribution of goods or services then ends in groups either getting too many or too little benefits. These market failures are categories based on the excludability (you have to pay to consume the good) and/or the rivalry in consumption (the same unit can’t be consumed by more than one person at a time) . Public goods are non-rival and non-excludable. Common resources are rival but non-excludable. Artificially scarce goods are excludable but non-rival. And the fourth category of goods, private goods, is both excludable and a rivalry in consumption, so it doesn’t constitute an immediate market failure. 
	The second type of market failures includes externalities, positive and negative. An externality refers to an indirect cost or benefit to a third party that occurs as an effect of another party’s activity. Positive externalities are a benefit that an individual or firm confers on others without receiving compensation. Negative externalities are uncompensated costs individuals or firms impose on others. You might be wondering why is a positive externality a market failure, isn’t it a good thing? Well, even though it is a good thing, the equilibrium price and quantity don’t account for the external benefit, so they are underproducing or consuming. On a graph, the equilibrium price and quantity are lower than the efficient price, so total surplus isn’t maximized. To maximize total surplus, the price and quantity must be raised.

So, the government is backing firms in the form of grants/subsidies to increase quantity to an efficient one above the original market equilibrium. Subject: Understanding Market Failure
Dear Friend,
To help you understand the concept of market failure, I found an example in a recent Wall
Street Journal article about the Smokehouse Creek Fire. This fire began in Texas on February 26,
2024. In an investigation, the state of Texas found that the power lines implemented by the
electric utility delivery company in the area, Xcel Energy, caused the ignition of the fire (Otis,
Marchese). In order to explain how this exemplifies market failure, I first should define a few
key concepts. As you know from this class, a specific market for a good or service is at
equilibrium when the quantity demanded by consumers and the quantity supplied by producers
are equal. The market naturally moves toward the goal of reaching an equilibrium quantity.
Equilibrium, however, isn’t always the efficient outcome (or the maximization of total surplus) in
the market. Market failure happens when the market doesn’t reach an efficient outcome, even at
equilibrium. There are a number of types of market failure, but the one I will focus on is market
failure that occurs when there is an externality present in the market. An externality is an
unintentional consequence of market activity that impacts outside parties who are not the
producers or consumers involved in the activity. When there is a benefit or cost in the market that
is uncompensated for by the equilibrium quantities supplied and demanded, total surplus isn’t
maximized and the market fails. An uncompensated cost is otherwise known as a negative
externality, and an uncompensated benefit is a positive externality.
In the case of the Smokehouse Creek Fires, we are discussing market failure caused by a
negative externality. The market we are considering is the energy utility market, in which Xcel
Energy, the producer, sells power lines, the good, to the state of Texas, the consumer. The goal of
Xcel Energy is to meet the market demand for power lines, but as they are trying to do this, there
is an unintended consequence of their power lines being used: wildfires (and thereby property
destruction). This uncompensated cost in the market results in deadweight loss, which means
there is a cost in the US energy market that is equal to the difference between the efficient
quantity and the equilibrium quantity. At an efficient quantity, the externality of wildfires would
be eliminated. Thus, equilibrium in the energy utility market isn’t efficient because, as we know
from the Smokehouse Creek Fires, at equilibrium there is still this uncompensated cost and
deadweight loss. Notably, market failure happens when there is no intervention in the market
from outside parties such as the government. With intervention in the production or consumption
of power lines, the externality of wildfires can be compensated for and the market can move
towards efficiency.
I hope this explanation is helpful. Please keep in mind that externalities are just one way
that markets fail to maximize total surplus. Still, understanding this particular situation involving
an externality will enhance your understanding of what market failure practically looks like.

Market failure occurs when a market fails to reach the most efficient outcome in the allocation of goods or services, in the absence of government intervention. Although equilibrium may be reached in this market, the total surplus has not been maximized and therefore the most efficient outcome will not be reached. Total surplus is society’s net gain from the market and is maximized when society’s marginal cost intersects (or matches) marginal benefit. Essentially, there can be an adjustment to the market that would increase total surplus, despite equilibrium being reached. 
	One economic concept that can result in market failure is positive or negative externalities. Externalities occur when the production or consumption of goods and services unintentionally affects third parties not involved in the original transaction. In positive externalities, this results in additional benefit that is conferred on the third party, without the individual or company involved in the transaction receiving any compensation. In negative externalities, this results in uncompensated cost imposed on the third party. These externalities cause equilibrium to not be the most efficient outcome a market can obtain. With a positive externality, the market could produce or consume more of a good or service to maximize the positive effect on the third party. With a negative externality, the market could product or consume less of a good or service to minimize the negative effect on the third party. 
	One tangible example of a positive externality is reflected in a recent New York Times article titled, “Older Americans Should Get Another Covid Shot This Spring, C.D.C Says” (NYT). In this article, the benefits of vaccinations for all Americans are discussed in tandem with the CDC’s recommendation for another COVID shot. The article highlights that vaccines offer genuine benefits to society that extend beyond those who actively choose to consume the product, stating “the agency recommended another round of vaccinations for Americans ages 65 and older” (NYT). A part of this reasoning from the CDC is the benefits of herd immunity. This occurs when a sufficiently large portion of a population is vaccinated against a disease. As a result, it becomes difficult for the disease to spread within the population, protecting even individuals who are not vaccinated. By recommending vaccinations to older Americans, the CDC intends to increase the number of people vaccinated and increase the effects of herd immunity to mitigate COVID-19’s spread. 
	Outside of recommendations, governing bodies take considerable steps to increase herd immunity within society. Many vaccines are free or administered for reduced costs, particularly on college campuses and places with large populations in close quarters. Although this is costly, the benefits of herd immunity mean that the government is often willing to incur these costs to maximize the positive externality of vaccines and total surplus to society in general.

quantity supplied is equal to the quantity demanded, or the place where supply and demand meet.

cost is equal to the social marginal benefit. If these two equilibrium points are the same, the
market equilibrium and efficient equilibrium are the same, and there is no market failure.
However, when these two quantities are different, the market does not allocate its resources to
the efficient outcome and thus results in a deadweight loss. This deadweight loss takes away
from the total surplus, causing a market failure. This indicates that anytime that the efficient and
market equilibrium are different that a market failure is present.

Hello Friend,
I understand that you are trying to keep up with the coursework while you are at home.
For your benefit, I would love to help you better understand market failure.
Broadly, market failure occurs when the market fails to reach an efficient outcome, thus
failing to maximize total surplus. This is caused by a failure of the market to allocate resources
efficiently. Many different factors can contribute to market failure, such as externalities, common
resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods.
I've come across an article in The New Y ork Times that provides a real-world illustration
shedding light on market failure. This article details the $500 Million Bahrain oil and gas project
recently approved by the U.S. Export-Import Bank. This project would increase the consumption
of fossil fuels, thus increasing greenhouse gas and worsening global warming. The author further
discusses criticism of the project’s disregard towards efforts to limit these fossil fuel emissions
(Tabuchi).
This oil project can be directly linked to market failure in terms of a negative externality.
In essence, a negative externality is a negative impact of an economic activity on an unrelated
third party. Individuals fail to internalize an externality when they are not able to take the
externality into account. In the case of the article, the oil project will pose a negative effect on
the general public through the creation of greenhouse gasses and its subsequent effect on the
public’s well-being.
The burning of fossil fuels releases pollutants that can harm an individual’s health. This
can lead to heart attacks, stroke, asthma, respiratory disorders, and even death (Harvard T.H.
Chan School of Public Health). This creates larger costs for the general public through increased
healthcare expenses. This inevitably leads to market failure since the U.S. Export-Import Bank
does not account for the higher healthcare costs experienced by unrelated individuals.
Furthermore, the cost of healthcare for treating illnesses caused by fossil fuel pollutants is
external to the market transaction between producers and consumers of fossil fuels. Thus, the
market fails to internalize the externality and account for this cost of fossil fuel consumption,
resulting in inefficient resource allocation.
Despite these issues, there are solutions to market failure. Specifically, government
intervention can assist a market in finding an efficient outcome. A few methods include taxes,
subsidies, quotas, and standards. For example, to better address the negative externality
associated with fossil fuel use, the government can impose an emission tax—a form of Pigouvian
tax—based on the quantity of pollution emitted. This will ensure that the price of fossil fuels
takes into account healthcare expenses related to fossil fuel pollutants. It would also guarantee
that producers and consumers of fossil fuels will bear the full cost of their actions. This example
serves as just one instance of how government intervention can be beneficial in addressing
market failure.
I hope this explanation and example were helpful to your understanding of the course
material.

Hello!

I am more than happy to help you better understand market failure.

First, it is important to understand market efficiency. Market efficiency occurs when resources are put to their most effective possible use or where total surplus is maximized. Market failure occurs when these resources are allocated inefficiently. One main source of market failure is due to externalities. An externality occurs when there is a cost or benefit due to an activity that affects a third party. In a situation where there is a positive externality, an activity by one party creates a benefit for another party that they don’t have to pay for. Not all the social benefit of the activity is accounted for in the market. When this occurs, the efficient quantity is higher than the market quantity because the social marginal benefit is higher than demand. This means that the market will not do enough because the party creating the benefit is not being fully compensated for its benefit. However, when there is a negative externality, the opposite occurs. There is an uncompensated cost. The party creating this cost does not compensate for the harm they impose. In settings where this occurs, the social marginal cost is greater than the supply. This means that the market is going to do too much because the party creating the costs to society does not pay for them. Market failure occurs with externalities because resources are being inefficiently allocated: the market underproduces with a positive externality and overproduces with a negative externality.

In a New York Times article written by Hiroko Tabuchi, we can look at a real-life example of a negative externality. The article explains that due to human activities, such as mining and burning coal, there have been significant levels of mercury pollution (Tabuchi). In turn, microorganisms convert it into a toxic form in which many tuna fish become contaminated by (Tabuchi). People then consume the contaminated tuna and can suffer from nervous, digestive, and immune system-related health issues (Tabuchi). This is a negative externality because these costs are not accounted for in the market price of tuna and the polluters do not bear the cost of the mercury pollution. The polluters are overproducing because the efficient quantity, where the social marginal cost meets the demand, is less than the market quantity where this cost is not taken into account. 

One potential solution to this could be for the government to tax tuna products that contain mercury to lessen the demand for them. This could shift the market quantity towards the efficient quantity. Another way would be for the government to impose a regulatory tax on emissions of mercury from human sources of the pollution. This would help decrease further levels of mercury contamination, and therefore the number of humans affected.

I hope this helped your understanding of market failure.

Sincerely,
Your fellow student

Writing Assignment 3
My friend,
Let me catch you up on market failure.
There are many things that can cause market failure, but let’s start with positive and
negative externalities. This is when the production/sale of a good has an additional effect on
society. With a negative externality, there is a cost being incurred on a third party that the
individual or firm is not paying for (ex. pollution). A positive externality is when incurs a benefit
on others without receiving compensation from third parties, like how vaccinations help
everyone, not just the person vaccinated.
If you open the article I provided, you will see an example of a negative externality. The
Willow Project is allowing more oil drills to be constructed in Alaska. By doing this there is
incredible harm on the environment; not only from the oil drills themselves but from increased
transportation to that area, construction, building and flying from an airport, etc. (Herz). This is a
negative externality because the company is paying for the rights and ability to drill in that area,
but they aren’t paying for the negative impact that the pollution will have on society, so the
market is not working efficiently.
Another way to experience market failure is through different types of goods. Every good
is classified in two ways: if the supplier can prevent certain people from using it, it is excludable.
If one unit of the good can only be consumed by one person, it is a rival in consumption. A
private good is the only efficient type because it is rival in consumption and excludable, so every
individual pays for their unit(s). But there are some other types.
A common resource is something that is rival in consumption but nonexcludable. Clean
water, for example. At least here, clean water is available to anyone, however, only one person
can drink a specific cup of water. Because it’s nonexcludable but rival, there is going to be a
social cost that is not paid for by the consumers.
A public good is something nonexcludable and nonrival — it’s available and can be used
by everyone. An example is snow removal. Snow removal is available to everyone, and more
than one person can benefit from it at one time. Even if someone isn't paying the taxes used to
fund the service, they would still be receiving the benefits. This issue is called free-loading, and
it causes the market to fail because not everyone is paying their part.
Finally, artificially scarce goods are goods that are excludable but non rival in
consumption. Take Netflix for example. It’s excludable because you have to pay for your
account, but millions of people can be using Netflix at the same time, making it non-rival. This is
a problem because the marginal cost of someone watching the show is zero, so the efficient price
would be zero. However, companies want to cover production costs and make profit, so in this
case MC will not equal MB.
Sincerely,
Y our Friend

Subject: Market Failure
Good afternoon friend, I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to explain the
concept of market failure that we are currently learning in economics, as well as share a good
example I found that could be helpful.
First, It is important that you understand what market failure is. As you already know, a
market is in equilibrium when the quantity of supply and demand are equal. However, if a
market is in equilibrium it does not necessarily mean that it is efficient. This is where the concept
of market failure comes in. If a market in equilibrium is not efficient, then total surplus is not
being maximized. This would mean that the equilibrium quantity is different from the efficient
quantity, which is the quantity at which marginal benefit intersects marginal cost as you may
recall from marginal analysis. This can happen as a result of several different factors:
externalities, common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. An externality is an
indirect cost (negative) or benefit (positive) that is an unaccounted for effect on society. Common
resources are rival in consumption and non-excludable, which can result in overuse. Public
goods are both nonrival in consumption and non-excludable, which can result in a lack of
incentive for providing these goods as no one has to pay. Artificially scarce goods are excludable
and nonrival in consumption, and led to inefficiency because the marginal benefit would be
maximized if they were free for everyone, yet must have a price. These market failures can be
fixed by government intervention in the form of a subsidy or taxes and restrictions based on what
kind of failure it is. For positive externalities or public goods where the efficient quantity is
higher, the government may subsidize these goods so that more are produced. For negative
externalities and common resources, the government may impose regulations or Pigouvian taxes.
A solution for artificially scarce resources could be an alternative revenue stream that would
allow all consumers to enjoy the benefits.

Sources of Air Pollution: Farms” that I will cite below so you can access. This article is about the
pollution that farms generate and the negative impacts that pollution has on the environment.

externality because the pollution generated by farms is an uncompensated cost that they are
imposing on their environment. This uncompensated cost of pollution is not accounted for in the
market equilibrium, meaning that the efficient quantity for produce will actually be less then the
equilibrium. The government could help this market reach efficiency by directly focusing on the
pollution by setting environmental standards or taxing the amount of pollution emitted, or by
focusing on the production by setting production quotas or taxing the produce.

March 25, 2024
Dear friend,
A real-world scenario regarding microplastics can help you better understand market failure.
Market failure occurs when, absent government intervention, the market fails to reach an
efficient outcome where total surplus is maximized, and society gets maximum net gain.
However, when total surplus is not maximized, a dead weight loss is incurred, hence the market
fails to achieve efficiency.
To better understand this concept, microplastics are an example of market failure. Microplastics
come from plastic goods, food containers, PVC pipes, clothing, etc., and end up in our
ecosystem. As a result, these microplastics end up in our bodies, causing an array of health
issues. For example, microplastics are now found in the human placenta, breast milk, brains, and
cardiovascular systems. As a result, "these synthetic, foreign bodies pose a threat to human
health" (Jacobs). The negative impact on human health poses a market failure.
The microplastic's impact on human health is a negative externality, an example of market
failure. A negative externality incurs an uncompensated cost that the individual or firm imposes
on a third party. The two parties, producers and consumers of plastic goods, fail to consider
non-participants that microplastics could negatively impact. In this situation, the private marginal
cost is considered; this is the supply curve or the marginal cost curve, but the social marginal
cost is not accounted for. The social marginal costs consider total external costs, which are the
non-participants and the health issues that could be incurred due to the consumption and
production of plastic. This results in inefficiency, negative total surplus, or deadweight loss,
which harms the third party. With negative externalities, the market quantity exchanged is greater
than the efficient quantity exchanged. This is because efficiency is when total surplus is
maximized when social marginal cost is equivalent to social marginal benefit. However, because
the excess marginal cost is not accounted for, equilibrium occurs at a higher quantity. However,
the quantity is lower at efficiency because the external cost is considered.
Regarding the example with microplastics, the amount of plastic being exchanged is greater than
the efficient quantity because the detrimental health impacts are not being considered. When
producers and consumers engage in the market, they do not account for when their microplastics
end up in "marine life" or "fisheries" (Jacobs). They are then found in another person's "fatty
plaque that clings to the walls of blood vessels," which can "block the flow of blood in a smaller
vessel and prompt a heart attack or stroke" (Jacobs). Monetarily, this can result in hospital bills,
an uncompensated cost that the consumer/producer brought upon someone not considered part of
their private marginal cost.
The market for plastic will only be considered efficient or not a market failure if the private
marginal cost curve meets the social marginal cost curve; this can be achieved by taxing plastic
itself or the microplastic pollution it creates. Hopefully, this helps your confusion regarding
market failure, as microplastics result in an uncompensated cost that the market fails to consider,
resulting in inefficiency.
Sincerely,
Your friend

Understanding market failure can be a difficult task, but I am here to help clarify it for you. Market failure is defined as when the market has an uneven distribution of goods and services, which leads to inefficiency. As a result, this causes deadweight loss because the supply and demand are not in equilibrium.
There are many causes of market failure, with two common effects being negative and positive externalities. A negative externality impacts someone, not involved in a certain situation, negatively. An example of this would be pollution from a factory. The people who live nearby get affected by the pollution while the companies make money from the production inside the factories. On the other hand, a positive externality is the opposite in that the people are positively affected by something outside their control. A common example of this would be if someone were to work very hard on their front yard to make it look better. This would only help the surrounding houses by making their value go up without doing anything. 
If you are still confused about market failure, I will give you an example that will hit home for you. I know that you are someone who uses insulin daily. I understand you have missed class, so I will do my best to explain a market failure to you. In general, a market failure occurs when the equilibrium quantity traded does not equal the efficient quantity for society in a given market, even when unregulated by the government. Another way to put it is that society as a whole would benefit if the given market were to trade more or less than the quantity they are trading at equilibrium. 

Market failures can take many forms. Some examples are classified as Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods. Common resources are when the resource is unregulated but limited, so people often take more than they should in efficacy. Artificially Scarce Goods are when the good could be accessible to everyone, but there is a price to receive access. Those goods should theoretically be given access to everyone once they are made. Last is Public Goods, which have no restriction access or limit. These are extremely inefficient, as the provider can’t possibly receive compensation from the receiver. 

 One example of a market failure that we covered in class was externalities. An externality is when a third party is affected by a certain market without ever having anything to do with the transition or with the buyer/seller keeping them in mind. There can be positive and negative externalities. 

A positive externality means that a third party is benefiting from a market, but because the buyer/seller does not have them in mind the trade is done at a lower quantity than the quantity that would be best for society as a whole. Vaccines are an example of a positive externality because society as a whole benefits from people getting vaccinated, not just those receiving the vaccine. A negative externality is the opposite. That means a third party is negatively affected and therefore the market equilibrium quantity is higher than would benefit society as a whole. A common example used in class was pollution. firm imposes an unintentional benefit (positive externality) or cost (negative externality) on some
unrelated third party (Dudley, 4). Here, plastic productions continued high demand results in
high plastic company production. Although beneficial for transactional parties, this negative
externality production creates an unaccounted for cost on nonplastic users (unrelated third party)

offputing the market from efficiency (how much less plastic we should produce) (Dudley, 12).

the “Coase Theorem”, which implies individuals reach efficiency if transaction costs are low, the
government can also intervene. Through standards or regulation (more expensive option), taxes,

optimal efficiency point thus resolving the externality (Dudley, 16-17).

those for which the supply is restricted through artificial means, such as intellectual property
rights, which may lead to suboptimal outcomes by restricting access and hindering innovation

To: My friend
Subject: Market Failure Knowledge

Hi, my friend!
If you are having trouble understanding the idea of market failure from Dudley's lecture, I am giving you an example to help you better understand it. In economics, a market failure happens when society suffers a loss due to the ineffective distribution of goods and services by a free market (Dudley). Various forms of market inefficiency lead to situations where individual interests do not coincide with the common good or, more precisely, when society does not receive the best possible exports from the market. When prices act as a signal to bring supply and demand into equilibrium, leading to the most efficient distribution of goods and services, and consumers enjoy a marginal benefit, we can say that the market is efficient and free of monopolies. In certain cases, when the market is unable to function normally, the equilibrium between supply and demand is upset, and the distribution of resources according to societal standards does not match what the market determines.

Common resources are a contributor to market failure, whether they are natural or artificial. An individual's use of another's capacity to access the same resource, as well as the difficulty in preventing others from doing the same, are both characteristics of common resources that make their identification non-excludable and rival. There is a widespread issue with shared resources known as the "tragedy of the commons," which occurs when one person's actions go against the benefit of everyone (Krugman and Wells 503). Along with non-excludable and non-rival goods, public goods contribute to market failure. In this market failure model, their use does not affect the availability of other users, and no one can be stopped from using them. The issue of free-riding arises in relation to public goods because individuals can enjoy them without contributing to their upkeep, meaning they have no incentive to pay for them (Krugman and Wells 495). An easily observable feature of market failure is an externality, which happens when the production of a product or service impacts the costs or benefits of parties outside of the market transaction.

Article: With TikTok Under Fire, Brands That Rely on It Worry 
The proposed limits on TikTok show how government laws intended at security may have far-reaching economic effects on stakeholders outside the government. These trends surprise fashion and beauty companies, which use TikTok for promotion and sales (Creswell). These firms now face hurdles after using TikTok's unique feature to reach a huge audience at little cost (Creswell). This is an externality, when entities pay for acts they cannot control. A ban could also hinder innovation and market dynamics, where TikTok has helped businesses compete with larger ones through creative content, weakening competition and reducing consumer benefits from a diverse and innovative marketplace, worsening negative externalities. A TikTok ban might cost people jobs and revenue, hurting the economy beyond companies.

Best regards,
Your friend

Hello Absent Classmate,
I know you missed the last Econ 101 lecture and understand you are confused
with the concept of “market failure”, so let me catch you up to speed!
Market failure is when the market fails to reach the efficient outcome, which is when
total surplus is maximized, due to an inefficient distribution of goods and services. Typically, we
see the efficient outcome at the market equilibrium, but in this case, the efficient outcome is
slightly different. It is located where the Social Marginal Benefit (SMB) and Social Marginal
Cost (SMC) lines intersect. I understand these concepts may be foreign to you, so let’s further
understand what causes the market to fail.
Externalities are one of the main concepts that cause market failure. There are two types
of externalities we must understand: Negative and Positive. Negative externalities are the
uncompensated costs that an individual or firm imposes on others. This includes things like air
pollution, industrial waste, and deforestation. Conversely, positive externalities are the benefits
that an individual or firm casts upon others without recurring compensation. Disease
management and education are some examples of external benefits. We represent externalities
within the Supply and Demand diagram by utilizing the external marginal cost/benefit coming
from the externality. In the case of negative externalities the market equilibrium results in too
many units of the good being produced, so the efficient outcome is where the market accounts
for the externality imposed on society. We get this by adding our marginal cost (MC) to our
2
external marginal cost (EMC), giving us our Social Marginal Cost (SMC). Similarly, for positive
externalities the market equilibrium results in too few units of the good being produced
compared to the efficient level. To find our Social Marginal Benefit we simply add our marginal
benefit (MB) to our external marginal benefit (EMB). For both externalities, at the point where
SMB=SMC society’s total net gain is maximized and we are at the efficient outcome.

Dear friend,
Market failure is a common occurrence within economies, which happens when the market fails
to maximize total surplus independently. Essentially, without government intervention, the
market fails to produce the socially optimal quantity. This leads to an inefficient use of total
social surplus. The four primary types of market failure include Externalities, Common
Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods.
A negative externality signifies an unaccounted cost that is imposed by individuals or producers
on others. An example where we see this is CO2 emissions, which represent a negative
externality due to the social marginal cost incurred by burning gas, leading to negative
environmental effects. Pollution, as a consequence, imposes societal costs on health and
environmental well-being. These costs are typically not factored into producer pricing strategies,
constituting a negative externality, therefore producers tend to overproduce the good, as the
actual production costs are understated. Government intervention, often in the form of taxes or
quotas, is necessary to rectify such externalities. In the case of CO2 emissions, quotas are
preferred over taxes due to the difficulty in precisely assessing the cost of each unit of gas
produced.
A scenario which we can see this is Joe Biden’s initiative to encourage more Americans to use
electric vehicles. In order to make electric cars cheaper, he is planning on giving support and
loans to mining companies so they can get the materials they need for batteries. Right now, there
is not enough lithium for batteries because mining companies do not have the backing they need.
This is creating an artificial scarcity which causes electric car prices to go up. Joe Biden wants to
fix this problem while also promoting the positive things that electric cars bring like helping the
environment. We recognize the relation to market failure because we are not seeing nearly as
many electric cars as we should be in order to maximize social welfare. Biden’s initiative
encourages a positive externality by promoting environmentally beneficial transportation.
We can see the market failure occurs when optimal outcomes without government intervention
are not achieved. Joe Biden’s plan to strengthen the market for electric vehicles shows the point
that the shortage of battery materials such as lithium has led to rises in prices. Through backing
these mining companies, Biden will overcome this challenge and grow environmentally friendly
transportation. We must recognize market failure in order to maintain social welfare and a
sustainable economy.
Sincerely,
An Econ 101 Student

Hello,
I heard that you would like to know more about market failures. A market failure usually
happens because of a lack of government intervention, which causes the market to be inefficient.
This inefficiency could be overproduction, underproduction, or a slew of other problems (like
monopolies). The reason why it’s inefficient is that surplus is not maximized so while the market
is in ‘equilibrium’ it doesn’t consider external costs(externalities).
There are two types of market failures: negative and positive externalities. There are
many types of externalities but the two classic ones are for cigarettes and vaccines for negative
and positive respectively. The way to fix an externality is through government intervention, and
is usually done through subsidies or taxes. One example of an externality are the two new Lyme
disease vaccines discussed in the NY Post. This is a positive externality, which is the benefit
consumers/producers give to society without return. A positive externality can be building better
roads like what Michigan is doing or a good public school. The positive externality here is that if
people take the vaccine the risk of the disease is reduced and in cases like polio, the disease is
wiped out. People taking vaccines protect their community from getting that same virus which is
a benefit not rewarded by a free market. It’s external because neither the consumer nor the
producer are receiving these benefits rather it’s society as a whole improving due to more
vaccines in supply.
How is a good thing a market failure? As I said earlier, the benefits of vaccines are a
benfit that is not rewarded by a free market which doesn’t give incentive to producers to produce
enough to get maximum benefit for society. In fact, we are seeing this problem arise now in the
measles outbreak which is exacerbated by anti-vaxxers (Blum). In the free market for vaccines,
there are too few vaccines for the people who need them. Since we fail to account for the
positive externality, we can’t maximize total surplus, the goal of the free market. To do so, we
need to give incentive to producers so that the supply curve shifts right and they make enough.
For a negative one we would need to disincentivize consumers so that the demand curve shifts
left and there's less in the market. With the vaccine, there is a gap between marginal private
benefit (free market demand) and marginal social benefit, the actual demand. Supply curve shifts
should be able to account for this gap and help correct the market and get rid of deadweight loss.
There is a simple solution to this market failure. Since we want producers to make more,
we can reduce their costs so that market efficient production costs are the same as before. The
way to do this is through a per-unit subsidy which would shift the supply curve and meet it at the
marginal social cost.
Hopefully you learned more about market failures. Go through the links below for reference.
Regards,
Econ101 Classmate
