Dear friend,
In this letter I hope to explain to you how a market failure occurs, as well as provide a realistic example to help alleviate any confusion.
To begin, a market failure occurs when, without any government or outside intervention, the market does not reach efficiency. This means that it does not maximize total surplus at that time. This could be caused by anything from an externality to a public good, to common resources or artificially scarce goods. An externality is an unintended external consequence or benefit caused by something, and this is the kind of market failure I will explain further in depth below.
To better explain how a market failure works, let me give you a real life example from recent news. In the New York Times on March 9th, reporter Andrew Jacobs wrote an article discussing the recent discoveries of microplastics in the human body. Microplastics are very small fragments of plastic that have been found all over the world as a result of the growing plastic industry and poor recycling practices. These microplastics have now even been discovered inside of the human body, including the lungs, blood, placenta, and brain (Jacobs). This synthetic material is very harmful inside the human body, and although little is known for certain about the health effects, research points to the possibility of it creating health problems such as cardiovascular complications and disease.
This problem surrounding microplastics and their negative health effects would be considered a negative externality due to the plastic industry. This is a negative externality because the harm from these microplastics (the health problems) is an unintended outcome of the development of plastics on an external group (everyone and everything), making it a negative externality.
`	Overall, the market is performing with this consequence added to it, and so this external cost is subtracted from the total surplus, reducing the total surplus. This makes the market fail because it is not maximizing total surplus, and is therefore not performing efficiently at its equilibrium point. On the graph this can be seen by the total external cost added to the supply curve (the producer’s marginal cost), creating a social marginal cost curve that consists of the producer marginal cost and external marginal cost together. The place where the demand curve intersects the social marginal cost curve is the efficient quantity, which is lower than the equilibrium quantity and priced more expensively, with a decrease in total surplus. This shows that the market failed. 
The plastics industry is extremely useful in numerous ways. Whether it be for containers, single use items, pipes, or polyester, we utilize plastics daily and the benefits of them are not forgotten. That being said, the market is still failing in reality due to the negative externality seen in the microplastics being found in our bodies and their poor health effects.
I hope this example helps to clear up any confusion surrounding market failure! Let me know if you have any questions. 

Best,
Victoria

Dear Friend,
I hope you are doing well. Since market failure can be difficult to fully grasp, I thought I
would help explain it. Market failure occurs when the market, without any intervention, does not
reach an efficient outcome when it is in equilibrium. The efficient outcome is when total surplus
is maximized. There are several different examples that lead to market failure. However, today I
thought I would explain negative externalities. A negative externality is an unaccounted cost that
a person or company imposes on others. To account for or internalize a negative externality, the
external cost produced by the market should be laid on top of the supply curve. In other words, at
equilibrium, supply is only the producer’s marginal cost. However, by adding the external cost to
the supply curve, the new supply curve is now the social marginal cost. To make it less abstract, I
have found an article from the New Y ork Times about Stanley cups. The article focuses on the
unintended impacts of the Stanley tumbler. The product itself is meant to be reused and serves as
a better alternative to other plastic bottles, yet people have dozens of them, and researchers are
worried they will soon become useless. Additionally, Stanley Cup production requires stainless
steel as one of its inputs. The production of stainless steel cups pollutes the environment and
relies on dirty fossil fuels. As a consequence, Stanley cup production affects not only the
producers or consumers in the market but also bystanders across the world who breathe in
polluted air. So, now, imagine a graph that shows the equilibrium outcome; supply and demand
only account for the producer and consumer’s marginal cost and marginal benefit, respectively.
Y et, a third party, those who breathe in contaminated air, are also facing consequences from the
production of Stanley cups. By adding this external cost on top of the supply curve, or the
producer’s marginal cost, the market now internalizes the previously unaccounted-for
consequence. At this new intersection, between demand, or social marginal benefit, and supply,
social marginal cost, the quantity exchanged lowers and price rises. At equilibrium, there is total
surplus that is consumer surplus, the area beneath the demand curve and above the market price,
added to producer surplus, the area above the supply curve and below the market price. Y et, there
is also negative surplus, or deadweight loss, that is equal to half of the difference between prices
in the efficient outcome versus equilibrium and the difference in quantity. Therefore, equilibrium
cannot be the efficient outcome since total surplus is not maximized, and there is overproduction
of the good.
Hope that helps!
Sincerely,
A Friend.

The New Y ork Times, The New Y ork Times, 9 Feb. 2024,

Hello,
Market failure occurs when absent any outside intervention, including government intervention,
the market doesn’t reach efficiency. The market doesn’t maximize total surplus, even in
equilibrium.
Market failures often occur when externalities are present. Externalities are added benefits or
costs to a third party outside of the market. A third party is outside of the group of
decision-makers in the market (producers and consumers) yet is impacted by decisions. The
market does not account for such externalities in equilibrium, therefore failing to be efficient.
An example of market failure in the real world is the PFAS chemical factory in North Carolina.
The factory produces PFAS chemicals which are used in water and grease resistant products. The
market for PFAS chemicals includes the producers (the factory owners) and the consumers
(people and corporations buying the chemicals). However, a United Nations panel recently
reported that chemical waste has previously been dumped into the river next to the factory. This
pollution has harmed those living along the river since PFAS chemicals accumulate in the
environment, human and animal blood, and organs. This accumulation causes water
contamination and harms human health (Tabuchi, 2024). The pollution is therefore a negative
externality since it is harming a third party (people along the river).
The companies producing the chemicals have denied the harm caused by the chemicals and
refused to take accountability for their damage, despite reports it exists. The companies are
therefore not accounting for the additional cost of their product on society. Total surplus is then
not maximized at equilibrium. There will be deadweight loss associated with the market
equilibrium.
Social marginal cost is the total marginal cost to society and is made up of producer marginal
cost, which is accounted for in equilibrium, combined with external marginal cost, which in this
case is the cost of pollution on people living along the river. The efficient quantity in a market
that has an externality is where social marginal benefit (which in this case is equal to the
consumer’s marginal benefit) intersects the social marginal cost. In this case, this would be
where the marginal benefit for the factory owners intersects the cost to buyers of the PFAS
chemicals added to the cost to people living along the river. In the case of a positive externality,
where a third party is benefiting from the market, the social marginal benefit is equal to the
consumer's marginal benefit added to the external marginal benefit.
With a negative externality, the market equilibrium results in too many units of the good
compared to the efficient level while a market with a positive externality has too few units of a
good at equilibrium compared to the efficient level. Here, more chemicals will be produced than
is efficient. To account for the effects of pollution, production of chemicals should be lower. The
efficient quantity of chemicals produced may not be zero since there is still benefit to society
(through benefit going to producers and consumers).
I hope this helps,
Y our friend

I heard you've been struggling with understanding the concept of market failure, so here's
a quick explanation of market failure and the concepts that contribute to it. A market failure
occurs when, without government intervention, the market fails to reach the efficient outcome of
maximizing total surplus.Different types of goods can contribute to market failures. Public goods
are freely accessible to all, reducing the incentive for private production and often necessitating
government intervention. Likewise, common resources, while free, are limited, leading
consumers to use them more extensively due to concerns about depletion. Both positive and
negative externalities can also contribute to market failure. A negative externality causes a
market failure because it does not account for the social marginal cost incurred. For example,
pollution is a negative externality because it affects a third party, in this case the neighboring
communities, this cost is not accounted for in the equilibrium. In the case of a positive
externality, the market is not accounting for all the benefits in the decision it makes, meaning that
the efficient outcome is not the same as the market outcome. A positive externality is a form of
market failure that occurs when a third party benefits as a result of an indirect effect of a
transaction by another party. A market failure occurs because the equilibrium results in too few
units of the good compared to the efficient level. In order to maximize total surplus in a market
experiencing a positive externality we need to account for the external benefit. By accounting for
the external marginal benefit and combining it with the consumer marginal benefit we are able to
draw the social marginal benefit, creating a curve to the right of the demand curve. In the case of
Paradise V alley, a desert in central Arizona, large palatial houses are being built. This drives the
values of property in the area up and the property owners are receiving an external benefit as a
result of the increase in neighboring property. The market as it stands does not account for this
extra benefit the current homeowners receive in the form of increased property value. This extra
benefit along with the marginal benefit the consumer receives creates our Social marginal benefit
curve. In this instance, since there's no negative externality, supply is also the social marginal
cost. The efficient outcome occurs where the social marginal benefit and the supply curve
intersect. The deadweight loss is formed within the triangle between where the market quantity
intersects the consumers MB and the Social marginal benefit, and where social Marginal Benefit
crosses the supply curve. Since any unit beyond the market equilibrium quantity has to get
subsidized in order for it to be produced, we need to subsidize the purchase of property to build
palatial houses. The subsidy imposed should equal the external marginal benefit in order to
achieve the efficient outcome.

Dear friend,
I hear that you have been wanting to learn more about market failure. T o provide
background, market failure is the inefficient allocation of goods/services in the market, caused
by either a positive or negative externality. Externalities occur when a good or service’s price
equilibrium doesn’t match the accurate costs or benefits associated with it. Positive externalities
are benefits that someone gives others without receiving compensation for it, like vaccinations,
education, or scientific research. The market equilibrium represents fewer units of the good than
the efficient level. Positive externalities can be resolved by providing a subsidy (equal to the
external marginal benefit), shifting the demand curve (consumer marginal benefit) to meet the
social marginal benefit. Negative externalities are costs that someone gives others that are
uncompensated, like pollution, secondhand smoke, or traffic congestion. The market equilibrium
represents more units of the good than the efficient level. Negative externalities can be resolved
by enacting a tax (equal to the external marginal cost), which shifts the supply curve (producer
marginal cost) left to meet the social marginal cost.
Efficiency can be reached by either directly addressing the externality or the market for
the good/service. The government can address the externality (ex. pollution) by enacting
environmental standards, establishing emissions taxes (Pigouvian tax), or creating tradable
emission permits: essentially limiting the quantity of externality emitted by increasing the cost of
emissions. The government can also target the market for goods/services (ex. leather) through
environmental standards, Pigouvian taxes, or production quotas, again, limiting the quantity of
the goods/services produced. Additionally, by Coase's Theorem, market failure can be resolved
if the transaction costs are relatively low.
No example provides a better understanding than Hiroko T abuchi’s NYTimes article
about the recent methane emission finding. T abuchi discusses the human-caused methane gas
emissions in the atmosphere, finding that oil and gas producers in major oil fields across the US

Market failure isn’t just a plain definition. There are key concepts that you need to understand
and remember to fully define it.
To start off, externalities. There are two types of externalities - negative and positive. A negative
externality is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others (ex: pollution).
A positive externality is a benefit that an individual or firm confers on others when receiving
compensation (ex: vaccines).
Next, we have types of goods. Goods can be categorized in four categories: private goods,
common resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods. When thinking of types of goods,
the first thing to ask yourself is whether they are excludable and/or rivals in consumption. Firstly,
private goods are excludable and rivals in consumption. Think of food items - not everyone can
afford them and not everyone can buy them because there is a limited amount. Secondly,
common resources. These types of goods are rivals in consumption, but are non-excludable.
Think of fishing for this one. When you go fishing you’re trying to catch fish, and so is the
person next to you. That makes it a rival in consumption. Although, it is non-excludable because
you aren’t paying a price for it, therefore everyone can afford it.

excludable. Think of a streaming media like netflix. Netflix is excludable because not everyone
can afford it, but everyone who has it can watch it at the same time, making it a non-rival in
consumption.
Fourthly and lastly, public goods. These types of goods are non-rivals in consumption and
non-excludable. A public good could be something like snow removal. Snow removal is done on
the streets so whether you paid for it or not, you’re technically still getting it.

Dear Friend,

I’m glad you reached out, I’m always happy to help. You haven’t missed much in class, the only major concept we’ve covered is market failure, but it’s pretty complex. The main thing with market failure is that its all about total surplus. Market failure occurs when the market does not generate as much total surplus as possible due to an externality. An example of this would be a well-maintained front yard, because someone will get the pleasure of looking at it, while not having to take care of it. A negative externality is a cost someone gets imposed upon them, without any compensation. An example of this would be pollution. We can see how externalities cause reductions in total surplus by using a supply and demand graph. In this graph, our supply is the producer’s marginal cost, and the demand is the consumer’s marginal benefit. When the graph is at equilibrium, total surplus is maximized. However, when a negative externality occurs, external cost is added to the producer marginal cost, which shifts the supply curve to the left, and creates a triangle of deadweight loss. Similarly, when a positive externality occurs, external benefit is added to the consumer marginal benefit, which shifts the demand curve to the right, and as a result creates a triangle of deadweight loss.
Market failure occurs so commonly in our everyday life. In fact, I was just reading about an example of market failure in the news. Recently in the Klamath river in Oregon, thousands of salmon died because of a “gas bubble disease”. To: Classmate in Econ 101
From: A friend from the class
Hey there! As previously agreed, I’m writing you this email to help you catch up with
some course material we covered while you were away addressing your family emergency.
During your absence, our class went over the idea of a market failure which occurs when absent
any intervention, the market fails to reach an efficient outcome even in equilibrium. In other
words, when we say that the market fails it is simply unable to attain a maximized total surplus
on its own, without any outside intervention. Typically, this trend occurs in markets where
externalities, public goods, common resources, and artificially scarce goods are involved. While
the way we demonstrate market failure will look different for each abovementioned case, I’ll
narrow down my focus on the market failure with externality, because, in my opinion, it is the
one that is seen most often and is the easiest to understand. Luckily, I’ve recently found an
interesting article that I think will give you a better grasp of the concept. Throughout it, the
author argues that “the extreme droughts all around the Global South hindered the countries’
hydroelectric production capabilities and as a result, they increased their consumption of fossil
fuels for electricity generation as a strategy to resolve the energy deficit created by the problems
in the hydroelectric sector” (Petroni). From this excerpt, you can essentially draw out that while
the producers undertook an economically rational decision to increase the usage of fossil fuels to
compensate for the energy that was not delivered by the hydropower industry, their action will,
unfortunately, lead to greater air pollution levels and ultimately impact the third party that is not
even a part of the Global South manufacturers’ market. As such, this is a clear example of the
market failure resulting from the negative externality that imposes an uncompensated, or external
cost on a part of the society who is not even a part of the examined market.
Ultimately, with the example mentioned above, you can see that the way negative
externality leads to a market failure is that it imposes an unintended cost on a third party and
decreases the market’s efficiency. Particularly, when we draw the effect caused by the negative
externality (a total external cost drawn above the supply curve as a rectangle) in our market
model, we can notice that at the market equilibrium quantity, the market is, in fact, inefficient
because there is a negative total surplus present there, which we need to combine with the
positive total surplus to get our real total surplus at that precise quantity. Instead, what ends up as
an efficient quantity where society’s total surplus is maximized is a point where the social
marginal cost (Producer’s MC + Total External Cost) intersects the social marginal benefit
(Consumer’s MB) which interestingly is not the market equilibrium quantity. Thus, the market
failure creates an entirely new point where the market is considered to be efficient. ((487))

real-world example through the New Y ork Times article “Anxiety, Mood Swings and Sleepless

Dear Friend,
As you told me that you're not understanding the concept of market failure in our Economics 101 class, I thought I'd explain it to you using a real-world example from a recent news article. Market failure is the situation where the free market fails to use resources efficiently, leading to an outcome for society that is not the best possible outcome.
One of the first causes of market failure is externalities. Externalities are the uncompensated costs or benefits that come from an economic trade and are carried out by third parties not directly involved in the transaction. In other words, the production or consumption of a good or service makes external costs or benefits that are not in the market price.
A recent article in The New York Times, titled "The Hidden Air Pollution Costs of Industries in Europe" (Venkataramanan, 2023), highlights the issue of externalities caused by industrial air pollution in Europe. The article discusses a report by the European Environment Agency (EEA) that estimates the external costs of air pollution from industries in the European Union (EU).
According to the report, industrial air emissions in the EU had an estimated external cost of between €2.7 to €4.3 trillion over the last decade (2012-2021), with an average of €268 to €428 billion per year (Venkataramanan, 2023). These external costs are primarily made by society in the form of bad health effects, such as increased diseases, and environmental damage, including crop losses and worsening of ecosystems.
The article explains that while Europe's industry has made progress in reducing its environmental and climate impacts, the external costs caused by air pollution from industry remain significant. Most importantly, the energy sector (thermal plants generating electricity and heat) was responsible for nearly 80% of the decrease in total external costs over the last decade, driven by the implementation of best available techniques and a shift toward less polluting and carbon fuels (Venkataramanan, 2023).
The market failure in this case is a thing because the production costs of industrial goods and services do not include the external costs imposed on society and the environment. As a result, the market prices of these goods and services are lower than their true social costs, leading to overproduction and overconsumption. This situation is a classic example of a negative externality, where the social costs of production are not fully made by the producers or consumers.
To address this market failure, the article suggests that the European Green Deal and the Zero Pollution Action Plan can further support the objective of decreasing pollution impacts from the industrial sector (Venkataramanan, 2023). By internalizing these external costs through appropriate policies, such as pollution taxes, emissions trading schemes, or regulatory measures, the market can start to want to produce and consume at socially optimal levels.
In summary, the article effectively illustrates the concept of market failure due to negative externalities, specifically in the context of industrial air pollution in Europe. It highlights the need for policy interventions to correct this market failure and ensure that the true social costs of production are reflected in market prices.

Dr. Dudley

Econ 101 classmate,
I hope everything is well with you! I understand how the concept of “market failure” is
confusing, so I want to explain it further to help you keep up with the coursework. I figured
using a recent news article would help explain market failure in a comprehensible way.
First, the general concept of market failure occurs when the allocation of goods and services is
not efficient. It occurs when the equilibrium price and quantity in a market are not optimal for
society, leading to an overall social welfare loss. When market failures occur, the market does
not allocate resources efficiently and leads society to outcomes and prices that are not ideal.
Market failures can happen due to various reasons, including negative externalities, artificially
scarce resources, public goods, and other factors as well.
In Y oko Kubota’s, “The Blacklisted Component That’s Disrupting the Luxury Car Market”, she
reports how a commonly used magnetic component made by a blacklisted Chinese company is
behind the holdup of thousands of luxury car shipments to the US. The part itself, a LAN
transformer, is used to connect cars and computers to networks and was inside a control system
for vehicles being shipped by V olkswagen. The tiny part was made by a Chinese company called
Sichuan Jingweida Technology which supplied the part to another supplier, not directly to
V olkswagen. The company’s blacklisting, and therefore limited supply, caused the carmaker to
hold back imports of the LAN transformer to Porche, Audi, and Bentley cars into the U.S. This
will hold until V olkswagen finds a way to ensure their supply chain complies with standards and
replaces the scarce part.
The limited supply of LAN transformers has led to a market failure, specifically because it
results in artificially scarce goods. The company is holding back production of the LAN
transformer to keep the supply limited and taking advantage of the situation by raising prices for
consumers. By restricting the supply of cars through the part, manufacturers can increase prices.
Consumers pay more than they would in a competitive market, so the price distortion leads to a
misallocation of resources and a consumer welfare loss. This supply chain disruption is a market
failure, harming consumers and leading to an inequitable distribution of resources. Artificially
scarce goods result in waste and inefficiency, as manufacturers can intentionally limit the number
of products to encourage demand and distort prices. This leads to waste, the inefficient allocation
of resources, and a loss of consumer welfare. Artificially scarce goods lead to market failures
due to the misallocation of resources and the heavy distortion of prices.
When market failures happen, there is room for government intervention to improve social
welfare. This government interference can occur in various ways, including taxes, subsidies, and
different forms of regulation. I hope this information helped clear up the concept of market

Dear Friend,
	I hope all is well. I understand that market failure has been difficult for you to grasp and that you would like a specific example of this in effect. Market failure, defined according to Professor Dudley, is when the market, minus intervention, fails to achieve the efficient outcome at equilibrium. The efficient outcome is when Total Surplus is maximized. The types of market failure discussed in class so far have been Externalities, Public Goods, Common Resources, and Artificially Scarce Goods. 
The best way I can explain market failure to you is through an externality example from the New York Times. The article describes how microplastics have extreme negative impacts on society, despite their economic convenience. The market on its own demands high quantities of microplastics at equilibrium because “plastics have indeed been a game changer for humanity, and the enormous range of cheap, durable plastic goods, from food containers and PVC pipes to polyester clothing and single-use medical products, have inarguably improved life” (Jacobs). However, the market equilibrium quantity has produced an external cost for third parties. The article references how microplastics contaminate our oceans and environment, as well as human cardiovascular and neurological systems, which ultimately causes diseases and brain tumors (Jacobs). This burden on these outside parties must be considered as a part of Total Surplus, and therefore, it must be subtracted from consumer and producer surplus. Hence, the market equilibrium quantity does not maximize Total Surplus, which results in market failure. To achieve market efficiency, the market must consider this external cost and operate at a lower quantity. This was expressed in the article as the solution, “We just have to use less plastic” (Jacobs). 
	The example provided above is a negative externality, where the efficient quantity is less than the market quantity and there is an external cost for third parties. There is a second type of externality called a positive externality, which operates the same way except in reverse. The efficient quantity is more than the market quantity because the market produces an external benefit for a third party. In order to find where these efficient quantities exist for both externalities, you must find where Social Marginal Benefit intersects Social Marginal Cost. This requires you to add the external cost or external benefit to the marginal cost or marginal benefit, depending on the type of externality. 
	Externalities are market failures, so in most cases they would require government intervention to achieve the efficient quantity. A positive externality can only be solved with a government subsidy, but a negative externality could be solved a few different ways. In the case of the microplastic market referenced earlier, the government could intervene in three different ways. They could impose environmental standards, taxes, or quotas to reduce the market quantity, and in all three of these scenarios they have the option to utilize them on either the externality itself or the market. I hope this helps and let me know if you have any questions!

Best,
Student

I found an article that will help you understand market failures; it deals with the
deployment of State Police officers and National Guard soldiers to patrol NYC subway
platforms, in response to concerns about safety and crime in the subway system. First, let’s go

A market failure occurs when a market fails to produce the efficient quantity necessary
for equilibrium—causing the demand and supply curves to not meet at the market’s true
equilibrium point, often leading to high prices (Dudley, 2024). To explain examples of market
failures, you need to understand how goods can be classified. A good that’s excludable is one in
which the supplier of a good can prevent people, who don’t pay for the use of that good, from
consuming it (Dudley, 2024). A good that’s rival in consumption is one in which the same unit of
a good cannot be consumed by more than one person at a time (Dudley, 2024). An example of a
market failure is a public good.
A public good is non-excludable, but it’s also non-rival in consumption—you don’t have
to pay for it, and multiple people can use it at the same time. This is a prominent example of a
market failure because consumers do not have to pay producers for the service, leading to people
avoiding payment–which causes the free-rider problem. The free-rider problem is when
consumers are enjoying a good or service without paying for it (Dudley, 2024). This is also a
good example of a market failure because the marginal cost, the cost incurred of producing one
more good, of allowing an additional consumer to use it is zero; it doesn’t cost anything for
companies to provide additional units of the goods. This is seen with services, watching sporting
events, or national defense.

the subway system is a vital public transportation system, ensuring safety in the subways is hard
due to limited resources. To comply with the dangers, Mayor Eric Adams, ordered national guard
soldiers and state police officers to patrol NYC subway platforms and check passengers bags,
aiming to strengthen safety (Dudley, 2024). This is a prime example of a public goods market
failure because the security from the national guard is non-rival in consumption: one person
experiencing the safety doesn’t prevent others from being able to also receive safety. The
marginal cost of providing treatment to another person is essentially zero, so the efficient price to

non-excludable. Everyone is receiving the benefit from the implementation and they are not able

Market failure occurs when there is an inefficient allocation of resources in the free
market. Therefore, the efficient point, or where total surplus is maximized, does not equal the

resources, public goods, and artificially scarce goods.
Externalities, which can be positive or negative, are a type of market failure in which the
market does not account for a cost (in the case of a negative externality) or benefit (in the case
of a positive externality) that affects a third party separate from the producers or consumers. For
example, a positive externality would be if all of your coworkers get vaccinated against the flu
but you do not, you will still benefit because they cannot spread the flu to you. Climate change is
an example of a negative externality, because its effects are felt by everyone even though only
some of the population are contributing to its acceleration.
Types of goods are also market failures. Goods are defined as excludable when the
supplier of that good can prevent people who do not pay from consuming it, and are defined as
rival in consumption when the same unit of the good cannot be consumed by more than one
person at the same time. Artificially scarce goods, such as cable television, are non-rival in
consumption and excludable. Common resources, such as clean water, are non-excludable and
rival in consumption. Public goods, such as national defense, are non-excludable and nonrival
in consumption.

chemical plant in North Carolina is highly contaminated and as a result is becoming extremely
unsafe for the surrounding communities. This is an example of externalities as a market failure.

marginal cost curve. The existence of the social marginal cost curve adds external marginal cost
to the producer’s marginal cost, which creates a new curve above the existing supply curve.

To refresh your memory, remember that the term “market failure” refers to the occurrence
when a given market fails to reach its efficient outcome. We can identify the efficient outcome as
when the market produces the maximum total surplus possible. It is important to remember that
the “efficient outcome” is not the “equilibrium outcome,” as a market can be at equilibrium but
be inefficient if it is not maximizing total surplus. Market failures can be created by externalities,
or when a third party is affected by the market, by market power, or by the distribution of
non-private goods.
We’ve been focusing on externalities in class, so I’ll elaborate on those. There are two
kinds of externalities. A negative externality is an external cost that negatively impacts a third
party outside of the producer and consumer, and a positive externality is an external benefit that
positively impacts this third party. Participants in a market with a negative externality will
overproduce the good or service as they do not consider the external costs that are borne on a
third party. Similarly, participants in a market with a positive externality will underproduce the
good or service as they are not aware of the external benefit that is gained by a third party. Both
will lead the market to stray from the efficient quantity for the market and create a market
failure.
To put this concept into perspective, I found a recent article from the Wall Street Journal
that illustrates a relevant market failure and negative externality. The article, titled “How the
Housing Market Slowdown Is Rippling Through the Economy in Five Charts,” discusses how
the increase in housing interest rates and consequential decrease in purchases of new housing
negatively impacts four other related markets: home furnishings, labor for home-improvement
businesses, home construction, and residential building permits. The negative externality in this
scenario is the increasing interest rates on housing as the four markets above bear a negative
external cost due to fewer consumers for homes and a corresponding lack of need for these
markets. Thus, these four markets fail to be efficient as they cannot maximize total surplus while
bearing the external cost of the increasing interest rates. This “failure to be efficient” is
manifested in unemployment as these markets cannot compensate for the external cost.
To solve this problem, the government could either engage directly with the externality or
with the market to push towards efficiency. In most cases, it is more effective to engage directly
with the externality. A possible solution via direct engagement with the externality would be to
lower the interest rates on homes, which would increase home consumption and demand and
thus increase demand in the four markets above, eliminating the external cost. Engaging with the
market directly in this scenario would mean more unemployment and layoffs, as this would
allow the markets to accommodate the external cost without eliminating it; this would not be
smart or effective.

Dear Friend,
In economics, it is often assumed that individual decisions motivated by self-interest
ultimately benefit society as a whole. However, market failure arises when individual incentives
fail to align with the maximization of society’s overall welfare, challenging this notion.
Essentially, market failure is when the market does not produce at the efficient quantity naturally,
necessitating government intervention. This imbalance causes a reduction in total surplus,
creating deadweight loss, which serves as a clear indicator of market failure. Market failure
manifests in various forms namely, public goods, artificially scarce goods, common resources,
and externalities.
Specifically, an externality refers to the unintended cost or benefit that impacts a third
party due to the production or consumption of a good. Graphically, the marginal social benefit
and cost curves illustrate the nature of market failure and the impact of an externality on society.
For instance, if the social benefit exceeds demand, a third party is receiving an unintentional
benefit. On the other hand, a negative externality arises when the social cost surpasses supply,
signifying an external cost that the market overlooks and therefore overproduces, such as
pollution.
In recent years, the fashion industry has been criticized for its overproduction,
overconsumption, and role in environmental degradation. Due to a failure to read the market
coupled with economic interests, brands often produce more than they sell, resulting in as much
as 40% of clothing made each year or 60 billion unsold garments that create large accumulations
of waste and misused resources (Tonti, 1). Carbon emissions expelled in the atmosphere during
the production and consumption of clothing contribute to climate change leading to individuals,
communities, and future generations to bear the brunt of these impacts such as health impacts,
environmental degradation, and infrastructure costs. Clearly, there is a significant social cost
related to the consumption and production of clothing that the market is unable to alleviate
without government intervention showing that the market for clothing produces too much.
In theory, to address the externality and enhance efficiency, the market should operate at
the point where the marginal social cost intersects with the marginal social benefit. While this
approach decreases transaction costs by limiting production and increasing prices, it also impacts
total surplus. According to Tonti’s article, government initiatives that place a quota on
greenhouse gas emissions could be helpful, however the question of whether to place this quota
on the producers or consumers is controversial (Tonti, 2). Furthermore, one organization in the
article argues that a tax of 6 cents per item paid by the producer may assist, however others argue
the tax must be higher for a meaningful reduction. In general, directly taxing the externality is
the most efficient strategy for addressing negative externalities. By imposing a tax the market is
moved away from the equilibrium point towards the optimal quantity and price level, effectively
discouraging both production and consumption. In this case, a tax of sufficient quantity on
clothing items and funds going to vulnerable communities will help subside the effects of
clothing production. (498 words)

Dear Lucas,

I hope you and your family are doing well!

Market failure occurs whenever the allocation for goods & services does not meet efficiency in a free market, even in equilibrium, absent any intervention (even government intervention.) This occurs as the total surplus is not maximized, resulting in deadweight loss and inefficiency. Market failures can be produced for multiple reasons, including Positive Externalities, Negative Externalities, Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scarce Goods. A positive Externality is a “benefit that that an individual or firm confers on others without receiving compensation. Also known as an external benefit.” On the other hand, a negative externality is “an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others. Also known as an External Benefit.” 

In order to make it easier for you to understand the concept of market failure, I found an article which clearly demonstrates the presence of a negative externality. The article discusses The Smokehouse Creek Fire in Texas, which was ignited by power lines belonging to the Xcel Energy company. As a result of the fires, hundreds of structures were left in ruins and more than 1 million acres were burned in the Texas Panhandle. This is a perfect example of a negative externality, as the Xcel Energy company, a private “firm”, imposed an uncompensated cost, the destruction of hundreds of structures, on many individuals, with the sole purpose of increasing profits. Negative externalities are classified as market failures, as the market equilibrium, the point where supply (producer marginal cost) and demand (consumer marginal benefit) meet, is inefficient and does not maximize total surplus. In this case, society is made up of consumers, producers, and the 3rd party which is harmed by the externality / fire. In order to reach efficiency, the supply, in this case the Marginal Cost of the Xcel Energy company, must shift left or decrease, to reach the reach the point where social marginal cost ( Producer Marginal Cost + External Marginal Cost) is equal to Demand (Consumer's Marginal Benefit.)  As a result, total surplus would be maximized as the positive total surplus will remain while the negative total surplus will be eliminated. In order to reach this efficient point, the government should intervene and implement one of the three policies: standardization, taxation, or a quota / limit on the amount of a good or service that can be bought or produced. 

I hope my example of a negative externality was able to help you grasp the broader understanding of market failures.

Dr. Dudley
Writing Assignment 3: Market Failure
Dear Friend,
Market Failure happens when the Market Equilibrium Price and Quantity are not
efficient, meaning that Total Surplus is not maximized. Total Surplus is society’s Total Net Gain
produced by the market which in this case is the sum of Consumer and Producer Surplus. This
can happen for multiple reasons including Externalities and Artificially Scarce Goods (Dudley,
Consumer and Producer Surplus).
Externalities occur when the production or consumption of a good/service affects
individuals who are not directly involved. There are two types of Externalities: Positive and
Negative. Positive Externalities occur when an individual benefits from a good without
compensating for their benefit. Negative Externalities occur when an individual has an
uncompensated cost imposed on them. In either case since these effects are not reflected in the
price of the goods or service, the market fails to allocate resources efficiently and maximize
society’s Total Benefit (Dudley, Externalities).
Artificially Scarce Goods are goods that could be produced in abundance but are
intentionally restricted in supply to maintain high prices and exclusivity. They are non-rival in
consumption and excludable, meaning a unit of the good can be consumed by multiple people at
a time but the supplier can prevent people who do not pay from accessing the good. By
artificially limiting the supply of a good, producers can charge higher prices, leading to an
inefficient allocation of resources (Dudley, Public Goods and Common Resources).
A good example of a Market Failure is highlighted by a Wall Street Journal article
detailing how restaurants are increasingly reluctant to accommodate large parties due to staffing
shortages and increasing food costs, which leads to frustration among diners struggling to secure
reservations for large parties (Dizik).
The primary Market Failure in this scenario is the noise pollution inherent with large
parties, which imposes costs on other diners by disrupting their dining experience and reducing
their enjoyment. This leads to inefficiency because the Negative Externality of noise pollution is
not fully accounted for in the market, resulting in an inefficient allocation of resources and a
failure to maximize total surplus for all parties involved.
This type of Market Failure is classified as a Negative Externality, as noise pollution is
the uncompensated cost that the restaurant would impose on its other customers if they were to
have reservations for large parties.
Another Market Failure apparent in this article is Artificially Scarce Goods as large party
reservations are non-rival in consumption and excludable. Since one party's use of a large table
doesn't diminish the ability of another party to use it at the same time, and large table
reservations can be controlled by the restaurant.
The scarcity of large table reservations is not inherent but rather created by the
restaurant's policies and operational constraints. Restaurants limit the availability of large tables
to manage their resources, particularly in the face of staffing shortages and the need to maximize
profitability by increasing table turnover.
Best,
Y our Friend

Market failure occurs when, absent any intervention, the market fails to reach the eﬃcient
outcome. At the eﬃcient outcome, total surplus is maximized and thus, there is no deadweight
loss present. It is important to note that the eﬃcient quantity for a good is not always equal to the
market equilibrium quantity!
Coincidentally, I just recently read an article from the Washington Post that explains a
real world scenario involving market failure! For reference, this is the article link:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2024/02/07/epa-soot-limit-rule/. The
article highlights a negative externality, which is a type of market failure. A negative externality
is an uncompensated cost that an individual or firm imposes on others, and can be referred to as
an external cost. Because of this uncompensated cost, the market actually ends up producing too
much of the certain good/service, and the market equilibrium quantity ends up being greater than
the eﬃcient quantity within society.
The focus of the article is about the recent regulations that the Environmental Protection
Agency (EPA) has imposed on the emission of soot into the atmosphere, stemming from the
excess amounts of air pollution that cement plants produce. This emission of air pollution
imposes an uncompensated cost on the society, as many citizens have experienced respiratory
issues and incurred healthcare costs. These citizens can be referred to as a “third party”
, and are
not directly related to the market for cement, which the cement plants produce. The market for
cement production is where the negative externality actually occurs, and the market equilibrium
for cement exceeds the eﬃcient equilibrium.

external costs such as healthcare costs are impacting many individuals. At the current market
equilibrium, there is deadweight loss and total surplus is not maximized. However, there are
ways to attempt to correct this market failure and ultimately reach eﬃciency.

Dear Econ 101 friend,
While you’ve been gone, we’ve learned all about market failure. The term “market failure” is when a market of a good or service is not at the efficient level. There are many ways a market can be inefficient; the first way is externalities. There are two types of externalities, positive and negative. A positive externality occurs when there is an external benefit outside of the producer and consumer. This makes the efficient quantity greater than the market equilibrium. A negative externality is the opposite where there is an external cost not accounted for at the market equilibrium. Making the market quantity greater than the efficient level. Another inefficient cause depends on the type of good. These include Common Resources, Public Goods, and Artificially Scare goods. A Common Resource good is inefficient because it is non-exclusive (free to gain access to the good). This causes a “free-rider” problem where consumers can enjoy the good for free therefore making the good overused. Next is Artificially Scare goods, these are non-rival in consumption (doesn’t impact anyone’s enjoyment of good when another person uses) which makes the efficient price for another unit $0. This makes it impossible for the producer to stay in business since it costs money to produce that good. Lastly is a Public Good, which is non-excludable and a non-rival in consumption, this has both problems of the two goods before this. The government usually provides these goods. 

In the article “Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns” it describes a current negative externality happening right now. The article talks about how plastics are “a game changer for humanity” (Jacobs) and how the world has doubled production since 2000. With this, though, came a negative byproduct, microplastics. These are not good for humans and the environment. “People who had microplastics in their cardiovascular systems were at heightened risk for complications from heart attacks and strokes” (Jacobs). This is one of the many harmful impacts microplastics cause. Since the production of plastic has a byproduct that doesn’t only impact the producer and consumer of that product, but the entire world it is a negative externality. The producer and consumer doesn’t have the intention of making it a world problem but “plastics are forever and very little of it has been recycled” (Jacobs) which brings the good outside of its own market. This makes a negative external cost, that gets added to the price of the good, and makes a SMC curve shifted left to the supply curve. There are ways you can limit negative externalities though. These include a tax on plastics, a production quota, or an internalized fix. In the article they recommend an internalized fix “that means encouraging consumers to reduce their reliance on single-use plastics” (Jacobs) and also a possible quota, “a treaty proposal that would curb the explosive growth of plastic pollution” (Jacobs). Hope this helps your understanding of market failures. 
From,
Your Econ 101 friend

Dear friend,
This past week during your absence we covered market failure, the different types of it, and how it may affect society. Markey failure occurs when the allocation of goods and services is not efficient, so even if a market is at equilibrium, it may not be operating efficiently, failing to maximize social welfare. An inefficient market can be caused by a multitude of things like externalities, and the consequences of each type of good. 
Let me explain a little further, starting with externalities; there are two types, positive and negative. A positive externality is a benefit a firm or individual imposes on others, also known as an external benefit, increasing the efficient quantity and raising the price, moving away from market equilibrium. A negative externality consists of an uncompensated cost that a firm or individual imposes on others, also known as an external cost. This raises the efficient price while reducing the efficient quantity. 
There are also different types of goods and services that may cause market failure, like public goods, private goods, artificially scarce goods, and common resources. There are two important concepts when thinking about these goods, whether they are excludable or non-excludable, or rival in consumption or non-rival in consumption. Excludable means that the good or service can be withheld from consumers if they do not pay for it, like movies on Netflix. If a good or service is rival in consumption, then that means it cannot be consumed more than once, like a t-shirt. A public good is both non-excludable and non-rival, a private good is both excludable and rival in consumption, an artificially scarce good is excludable but non-rival in consumption, and a common resource is non-excludable but rival in consumption. These goods introduce market failure as firms or individuals manipulate the market in order to obtain profit, and if these goods or services' prices and production are not properly managed then market failure will occur.

In economics, market failure is a difficult concept to understand. The general idea is that
market failure happens when the free market, operating on its own, does not allocate resources
efficiently. Therefore not maximizing total surplus.

phase out the use of “forever chemicals”, known as PFAS, in food packaging. PFAS are, “man

concerns, yet they're prevalent in fast food wrappers and other containers due to their oil- and
water resistant properties. PFAS are still constantly being used.
When companies use PFAS, they do so because the chemical properties are seen as
beneficial for their products. However, they don't bear the costs of this decision, the public does.

environmental cleanup expense, and the depletion of natural resources. All of these are not taken
into account for the price of packaging. These costs are then taken in by society at large, not just

packaging results in overproduction and overuse of these chemicals. Because individual
consumers and producers are not bearing the total cost, they have less of an incentive to avoid

is that because it is non excludable and non rivalrous private firms have little incentive to provide
or maintain these goods because there is no benefit for them.

eliminate this market failure. It is an action to internalize an externality by reducing the future

To: My Friend
From: Your Friend in Econ 101
In lecture and discussion, we have been discussing and learning about market failures and
exploring different examples that portray them in real-life scenarios. Market failure is when the
market fails to reach an efficient outcome [without government intervention] and does not
maximize total surplus. This inefficient outcome can be explained through the concept of
externalities which can either be negative or positive. Negative externalities are uncompensated
costs imposed on an uninvolved third party, either by an individual or a firm. An example of this
is pollution where the perpetrator of the pollution will only make decisions based on the direct
cost of and profit from production, such as a coal manufacturer, without considering how people
can be indirectly harmed by the pollution through poor air quality. A positive externality, while
seemingly beneficial, also leads to market failure because the benefit that someone receives can
affect others indirectly as they are unable to experience the benefit. Vaccinations exemplify this
concept because they benefit the person receiving them, but the people that are left without them
due to limited supply, are indirectly negatively affected because they are not protected against
diseases and viruses.
The New York Times article, “The Most Overlooked Reason Black Americans Are
Moving South” provides a real-world example of how negative externalities can be truly
detrimental to the market. This article discusses the issue of poor air quality due to pollution
causing Black Americans to migrate away from big cities in certain states and move to other
states to escape such toxic conditions. Using Detroit as an example, car factories only think
about the direct costs and profits of running their businesses without considering how their
actions are affecting nearby citizens in the areas surrounding their plants. A woman in Detroit
was even forced to wear a mask in her house due to such poor air quality. These factories are in
the areas of Detroit where there is a predominantly African American population (because of
redlining by the government), causing them to move to other states where the conditions are
more livable. Due to this, Detroit will see their tax base receding and be unable to pay for public
city improvements such as road repairs, building upkeep, and citywide street cleaning. Tourists
will feel the effects of this too and choose different cities to visit, which will also contribute to
profit loss in Detroit’s local tax base. However, Southern states that Black Americans are moving
to are not the safe haven they want it to be, as they are also facing their own issues of climate
change and more extreme weather events. Clean air should theoretically be classified as a public
good where it is free and can be enjoyed by all, but this proves to be more challenging with
manmade circumstances such as factories and power plants polluting the atmosphere and making
environmental conditions nearly impossible to live in. (481 words)

Good afternoon,
	I hope you are well! I’d love to help clear up any confusion regarding market failures from Econ 101 that you missed while away. Understanding market failures is crucial as they occur when, without any intervention, the market fails to reach an efficient outcome, leading to other, less desirable outcomes. This can even apply when in equilibrium. The efficient outcome corresponds to where there is maximum total surplus and resources are allocated to their best possible value. 
	An example of a market failure that might resonate with you is the recent news story “Doctors’ Group Offers Free Measles Vaccines in Philadelphia to Fight Outbreak” from ABC News by Mary Kekatos. This real-life scenario describes doctors offering free measles vaccines in Philadelphia in response to a recent measles outbreak. By making the vaccines free, the doctors hope to increase the number of vaccinated individuals to prevent the spread of measles. According to the article, “One dose of the measles vaccine is 93% effective at preventing infection if the recipient is exposed to the virus and two doses are 97% effective…” (Kekatos). Therefore, given the unpredicted rise of the highly contagious disease in Philadelphia and the effectiveness of the vaccine, doctors strongly encourage people in Philadelphia to get vaccinated by making the vaccine more accessible.
	This story is a market failure because the situation represents an externality. An externality is when some costs or benefits impact third parties who aren’t directly involved. In this case, the vaccines in Philadelphia pose a positive externality.  A positive externality is a benefit an individual or firm indirectly imposes on others without receiving compensation or acknowledgment. Positive externalities can cause market failure when the benefits of the positive externality are not realized or accounted for within the market. This leads to a less effective allocation of resources, leading to an inefficient outcome. 
Free vaccines create a positive externality because society benefits when more people are vaccinated to stop measles from spreading. However, when the people of Philadelphia do not realize the benefits of the vaccine and how getting vaccinated could improve the health and safety of the community, there is a market failure. The misallocation of resources present in this market failure is that the gain of herd immunity from an increase in measles vaccinations is not accounted for and internalized within the people of Philadelphia. 
	Thank you for reaching out. I'm here to help, and I encourage you to ask any more questions or if you need further clarification on these concepts!
Sincerely,
Econ 101 Classmate
